div1.head: D

div2.entryFree:
alphabetical letter D *
The fifteenth letter of the alphabet: called DaAdN: it is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]; (TA;) and of the letters termed $ajoriy~ap, ('Eyn, Mgh, TA,) from Al$~ajoru, which is the place of the opening of the mouth: ('Eyn, Mgh, TA on the letter j:) its place of utterance is from the extremity of the tongue [extended so as to reach] to the part next to the [lateral teeth called] A^aDoraAs; and it is more usually pronounced from the left side than from the right: the vulgar [sometimes] pronounce it as ZaA=', making its place of utterance to be between the extremity of the tongue and the central incisors, which pronunciation is peculiar to a dialect, as mentioned by Fr on the authority of El-Fadl: he says [also] that some of the Arabs substitute it for ZaA=', saying Dahor for Zahor; but that the doing thus, though allowable in speech, is not allowable in the reciting of the Book of God, which follows the rule, or usage, of the Prophet: (Msb in art. Dwd:) or its place of utterance is from the foremost part of the edge of the tongue and the part next to the ADrAs; and it has no sister [or analogue] accord. to Sb; but accord. to the 'Eyn, it is a sister of * and v, and these three letters are termed livawiy~ap [or gingival], because proceeding from the gum; the substitution of any of these, however, for another of them, vitiates prayers: (Mgh:) it is of the class termed AlHuruwfu AlmusotaEoliyapu: (L in art. Dwd:) and is a letter peculiar to the Arabs, (L and K in that art.,) accord. to the general and correct opinion; (TA in that art.;) [whence the saying of Mohammad, A^anaA A^afoSaHu mano naTaqa biAlD~aAdi I am the most chaste in speech of those who have pronounced the letter dád; i. e., of the Arabs, agreeably with another saying, ascribed to him, mentioned voce bayoda;] or it is a letter rarely occurring in the language of any other people. (L in that art.) ― -b2- It is always a radical letter; and is [said to be] not substituted for another letter; (L in art. Dwd;) [but it is so substituted in some cases of A_idogaAm, as, for instance, for the l of the article Al, and in yaD~ar~aEu for yataDar~aEu, and the like; and] it is sometimes substituted for S, as in maD~a Alr~um~aAnapa for maS~ahaA, as Ibn-Osfoor says, and Ks mentions manaADN for manaASN; (TA;) and also for l, as Ibn-Málik says in the Tes-heel, an instance of which is rajulN jaDodN for jalodN, mentioned by J; (MF, TA;) and sometimes it is changed into l, as in the instance of AiloTajaEa for AiDoTajaEa. (S and L &c. in art. DjE.) -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Eight hundred.]
Duw^oDuw^N * : see the next paragraph but one, in two places. -A2- Also The bird called A^axoyal [q. v.]: (O, K:) so says ISd: but IDrd doubts its correctness. (TA.)
Diy^oDaA^N * : see the next paragraph.

Diy^oDiy^N * (S, O, K) and ↓ Diy^oDiYo'N and ↓ Duw^oDuw^N and ↓ DuwoDuwo'N (O, K) and accord. to ISd ↓ Diy^oDaA^N, which is of an extr. measure, (TA,) Origin, root, race, or stock; syn. A^aSolN: (S, O, K:) and the place in which a thing originates; syn. maEodinN: (K:) hence, in a xuTobap of Aboo-Tálib, AlHamodu lil~`hi Al~a*iY jaEalanaA mino *ur~iy~api A_iboraAhiyma wazaroEi A_isomaAEiyla waDiy^oDiy^i maEad~K waEunoSuri muDara i. e. [Praise be to God, who made us to be of the offspring of Abraham and of the seed of Ishmael and] of the stock of Ma'add [and of the race of Mudar]: and yaxoruju mino Diy^oDiy^i h`*aA, occurring in a trad., i. e. There shall spring from the stock, or race, of this; or, as some relate it, it is [Siy^oSiy^,] with the unpointed S, which means the same: and you say Diy^oDiy^u SidoqK and SidoqK ↓ Duw^oDuw^u [An excellent origin or race]: (TA:) [see an ex. voce buw^obuw^N, in art. bA^: and see also Dino'N:] or Diy^oDiy^N &c. signify multitude, and abundance, of offspring or breed; (K, TA;) whence the Diy^oDiy^ of sheep. (TA.)

DaA^oDaA='N * , [in the CK AlDaA^oDaA^u is erroneously put for AlD~aA^oDaA^'u,] as also ↓ DawoDaA='N (O, K, TA) and DawoDFY, (CK,) [which belong to art. Dw and the last of which is mentioned in the K in art. DwD,] The voices, cries, or shouts, of men, (AA, O, K, TA,) in war, * or fight. (O, K, TA.)
DawoDaA='N * : see the next preceding paragraph.
Duw^oDuwo'N * : see Diy^oDiy^N.
Diy^oDiYo'N * : see Diy^oDiy^N.

muDawoDiy^N * or muDawoDK, (accord. to different copies of the K,) the former app. the original of the latter, [which is mentioned in the K in art. DwD, but in the CK there written maDawoDiY~N,] (TA,) applied to a man, Crying out, shouting or clamouring. (K.)

Diy^obilN * , and Diy^obulN, (S, M, O, K,) like ziy^obirN and ziy^oburN, (S, O, K,) the latter mentioned by IJ, (M,) but the former the more usual, (S, M,) Calamity, or misfortune: (S, M, O, K:) [it is said that] ziy^oburN and Diy^obulN are the only instances of the measure fiEolulN: (K:) but accord. to Th, there is no word of this measure in the language; therefore, if these two have been heard, they are extr., unless, as Ibn-Keysán says, the ' be augmentative [and there is no reason for supposing it to be so as there is no known unaugmented word from the root Dbl]: (S, O:) Siy^obulN, however, with S, has been mentioned in the K, as having the same meaning, and is said to be of the dial. of Dabbeh, but not so well known as Dy^bl, with D; and IB mentions niy^odulN, meaning [likewise the same, or] “ incubus, ” or “ nightmare: ” [but one of these four instances may be excepted; for] it is said in the K [in art. zaA^br] that ziy^oburN may be incorrect. (TA.)

1 DaA^aza * , aor.
DaAa^a , inf. n. DaA^ozN and DaA^azN, He deviated from the right course; or acted unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically; (K;) like DaAza, aor. yaDuwzu and yaDiyzu. (TA.) ― -b2- DaA^azahu Haq~ahu, (K,) aor.
DaAa^a , inf. n. DaA^ozN and DaA=zN, (TA,) [but the latter is probably a mistake for DaA^azN,] He deprived him, or defrauded him, of a part, or the whole, of his right, or due: (K:) he refused it to him; or withheld it from him: (TA:) like DaAzahu A_iy~aAhu, aor. yaDiyzuhu (S * and K * and TA in art. Dyz) and yaDuwzuhu. (K * and TA in art. Dwz.)
DaA^ozaY * : see what here follows.
Duw^ozaY * : see what here follows.

qisomapN Diy^ozaY * , and ↓ Duw^ozaY, and ↓ DaA^ozaY, (K,) the first mentioned by AZ (S in art. Dyz) and IAar, (TA,) and the second by Fr (S ubi suprà) and IAar, (TA,) and the third by Fr, (S ubi
suprà,) A defective, (K,) or an unjust, (TA,) division: (K, TA:) as also DiyzaY (IAar, K) and DuwzaY. (IAar, TA.)

1 Daw^ula * , [aor.
DaAu^a ,] (S, M, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. DaA=lapN (S, M, O, Msb) and Duw^uwlapN; (Msb;) and ↓ taDaA='ala; (M, Msb, K;) He, or it, [accord. to the S and O app. said of a man or of a man's body, and accord. to the Msb said of a thing,] was, or became, small in body, or small, and lean: (S, O, Msb:) or small, slender, or thin, and despicable, abject, or ignominious: and also [simply] lean, or spare: (M, K:) and in like manner ↓ AiDoTaA^ala: (M:) [or lean, or spare, and weak: or weak, small, and slender, or thin: (see the part. n., Day^iylN:)] or Duw^uwlapN signifies the being lean, or emaciated; and base, abject, or despicable. (TA.) Accord. to AZ, (S, O, TA,) Daw^ula, said of a man, (TA,) or Daw^ula raA^oyuhu, (S, O;) signifies He was, or became, small, or little, [in estimation,] and weak in judgment. (S, O, TA.)

3 DA='l $axoSahu * , (M, TA,) [in the O, and in copies of the K, DaA^ala, but the former is the right,] He made his person small, (M, O, * K, TA,) in order that he might not appear. (TA.) Zuheyr says,
fabayonaA na*uwdu AlwaHo$a jaA='a gulaAmunaA
yadib~u wayuxofiY $axoSahu wayuDaAy^iluho
[And while we were driving the wild animals, our young man came, creeping, and hiding his person, and making it small]. (M, TA.)

6 taDaA='ala * : see 1. In a verse of Aboo-Khirásh, taDaAla lahaA jisomiY [meaning My body became lean, or spare, by reason of it,] occurs for taDaA='ala: or, as AA relates it, he said taDaA^'al l~ahaA, with idghám. (M.) ― -b2- Also He became small, or thin; he shrank, or became contracted; (O, * TA, and Ham * pp. 653 and 658;) by reason of abasement, (TA,) or from fear: (Ham p. 658:) he hid his person, sitting, and shrank, or became contracted. (M, K, TA.) And It (a thing) shrank, became contracted, or drew itself together. (TA.) AHn has used it [in this sense] in relation to a herb, or leguminous plant. (M, TA.)
8 AiDoTaA^ala * : see 1.

Duw^ulapN * , (S, O, TA,) like tuwadapN, (O, TA,) in the copies of the K Duw^olap, but the former is the right, (TA,) an epithet applied to a man, (S, O,) Lean, or spare: (S:) or weak, (K, TA,) lean, or spare, and despicable, abject, or ignominious. (TA.) [See also Day^iylN.]

huwa Ealayohi Duw^olaAnN * , (M, K, TA,) with damm, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, DawalAnN,] He, or it, is a burden upon him; syn. kal~N. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- And Hasabuhu Ealayohi Duw^olaAnN His grounds of pretension to respect, or honour, are a cause of reproach to him. (M, TA.)

Day^iylN * (also pronounced [by some] Diy^iylN, like $iEiyrN [for $aEiyrN, q. v.], Ham p. 129) Small in body, and lean; (Msb;) or so Day^iylu Aljisomi, applied to a man: (S, O:) or small, slender, or thin, and despicable, abject, or ignominious: and also [simply] lean, or spare: and so ↓ muDoTay^ilN, (M, K,) in both senses: (K:) or lean, or spare, and weak: (TA:) or weak, small, and slender, or thin: (Lth, TA:) and ↓ mutaDaAy^ilN [likewise] signifies thin, or slender; applied to a man; syn. $axotN: (S, O, TA:) the pl. of Day^iylN is Duw^alaA='u and Diy^aAlN (M, K, TA) and Day^iyluwna: (TA:) and the fem. is Day^iylapN. (M, TA.)
Day^iylapN * fem. of Day^iylN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also [as a subst.] A slender serpent: (S, O, K:) or a serpent resembling the viper. (M.) ― -b3- And The lahaAp [or uvula]. (Th, M, K.)
muDoTay^ilN * : see Day^iylN.
mutaDaAy^ilN * : see Day^iylN. ― -b2- It is also applied as an epithet to the weaving of a coat of mail [app. as signifying Delicate, or fine; or small, or contracted, in the rings]. (TA.)

1 DaA^anotu AlD~aA^ona *
I set apart the sheep [from the goats]. (Az, TA, and K in art. mEz.) One says, AiDoA^ano DaA^onaka waA@moEazo maEozaka Set apart thy sheep from the goats, and set apart thy goats from the sheep. (Az, TA.)
4 ADA^n * , (S, M, K,) said of a man, (S,) or of a party of men, (M,) His, or their, DaA^on [or sheep] became numerous. (S, M, K.)

DaA^onN * (S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ DaA^anN (S, M, K) and ↓ Day^iynN, (S, M, Msb, K,) which is also pronounced ↓ Diy^iynN, with kesr to the first letter because of the kesr following, agreeably with a general rule applying to a word [of the measure faEiylN] having any faucial letter [for its second radical], and ↓ DiynN and ↓ DayonN, which are mentioned by IAar, without ', and therefore extr., (M,) [Sheep;] such as have wool, of what are termed ganam; one of which is called ↓ DaAy^inN; (Msb;) [i. e.] they are pls., (S, K,) or [rather] quasi-pl. ns., (M,) of ↓ DaAy^inN, (S, M, K,) which signifies one that has wool, (M,) or the opposite of maAEizN, (S, K,) of what are termed ganam: (M, K:) DaA^onN is of the fem. gender; (IAmb, Msb;) and has for its pl. A^aDow^unN [properly a pl. of pauc.] (IAmb, M, Msb) and A=DunN, which occurs in poetry, and is formed by transposition from A^aDow^unN: (M:) the fem. of ↓ DaAy^inN is DaAy^inapN; (S, M, Msb, K;) the pl. of which is DawaAy^inu. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- DaA^onN also signifies A certain species of [the lizards called] DibaAb [pl. of Dab~N]; opposed to the maAEiz. (TA.) And A certain species of jerboas, also called $ufaAriY~N; (T voce tadomuriY~N, q. v.; and TA in art. $fr;) differing from the maAEiz thereof. (T and TA in art. dmr.)
DaA^anN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
DayonN * and DiynN: see DaA^onN.

DaA^onapN *
A [ring for the nose of a camel, such as is termed] xizaAmap, when made of sinew. (Sh, K.) [But see DaAnapN, in art. Dwn.]

Diy^oniY~N * is an extr., distorted, rel. n. [from DaA^onN]. (M.) You say miEozFY Diy^oniy~apN Goats that keep to the DaA^on [or sheep]. (M.) And siqaA='N Diy^oniY~N A wide, (M,) or large, (K,) skin, of the hide of a sheep, (M, K,) in which [milk such as is termed] raAy^ib is churned. (K.)
Day^iynN * and Diy^iynN: see DaA^onN.

DaAy^inN * : see DaA^onN, in three places. ― -b2- It is also used as an epithet: one says kabo$N DaAy^inN [app. meaning A ram: kabo$N alone having several meanings]. (M.) ― -b3- And it signifies also (tropical:) Weak: (K, TA:) [opposed to maAEizN:] or a soft man, as though he were a ewe: (M, TA:) or one who ceases not to be goodly in body while a scanty eater: (M, K: *) or soft and flaccid in the belly. (M, K. *) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Such as is white and broad, of sands. (K, TA.)

1 Dab~a * , aor.
Dabi3a , (K,) inf. n. Dab~N, (S, K,) He, or it, clave to the ground: (S, * K:) [like DabaA^a:] this is the primary signification. (S.) ― -b2- And, aor. and inf. n. as above, It flowed: (K, TA:) like baD~a: or it flowed gently, or scantily; as blood when it does not drop, or issue in drops, so as to require the repetition of the ablution for prayer: (TA:) or it is only said of blood and of saliva: (K:) or, aor. as above, inf. n. DabiybN, said of water and of blood, it flowed. (S.) And Dab~ato $afatuhu, aor. as above, inf. n. Dab~N and DubuwbN, His lip flowed with blood, from a tumour &c. (TA. [See also another meaning in what follows.]) And Dab~ato livatuhu damFA His gum flowed with blood: (S:) or Db~t biAld~ami: and in like manner, yaduhu [his hand or arm]: (A:) and tarakotu livataha taDiyb~u mina Ald~ami, inf. n. DabiybN, I left his gum flowing with blood. (TA.) Dab~atE livatuhu, aor. as above, inf. n. Dab~N, means His gum watered, or flowed with saliva. (TA.) And one says, jaA='a fulaAnN taDib~u livaAtuhu (tropical:) [Such a one came with his gums watering] (S, A *) lika*aA waka*aA [for such and such things], (A,) when the person spoken of is vehemently eager, or greedy, for a thing, (S, A,) or when he is affected with very inordinate desire to eat, or with vehement lust, or carnal desire, or with vehement eagerness, or greediness, for the accomplishment of an object of want. (L, TA.) Bishr Ibn-Abee-Kházim says,
wabaniY tamiymK qado laqiynaA minohumu
xayolFA taDiyb~u livaAtuhaA lilomagonami
(assumed tropical:) [And the sons of Temeem, we have found, of them, horsemen whose gums water for spoil]: in
which taDib~u is said by AO to be formed by transposition from tabiD~u. (S.) [See another ex. in a verse cited voce A^azomalN.] Another poet says,
A^abayonaA A^abayonaA A^ano taDib~a livaAtukumo
EalaY xur~adK mivoli AlZ~ibaA='i wajaAmili
(assumed tropical:) [We disallow, we disallow, that your gums should water for virgins, or bashful virgins, like gazelles, and for camels]. (TA.) One says also, Dab~a famuhu, aor. as above, inf. n. Dab~N, meaning His mouth watered, or flowed with saliva: (TA:) and yaDib~u fuwhu (tropical:) [His mouth waters] is said of him who is vehemently eager, or greedy, for a thing. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Dab~ati Ald~aAb~apu, aor. as above, inf. n. DubuwbN, means The beast staled while running. (TA.) -A2- See also 4, in five places. -A3- Dab~a said of a boy, or male child, He became a youth, or young man; he attained to the state termed $abaAb. (TA.) -A4- Dab~ati Al$~afapu, aor. as above, (Msb, K,) inf. n. Dab~N and DubuwbN, (K,) The lip became affected with the disease termed Dab~. (Msb, K. [See also another meaning in what precedes.]) -A5- Dab~a, (S, K,) sec. pers. Dabibota, (TA,) aor.
Daba3a , inf. n. DababN, said of a camel, He became affected with the disease termed Dab~ (S, K) in his firosin [i. e. in his foot, or the extremity of his foot]. (S.) -A6- Dabiba Albaladu, (ISk, S,) or Dabibati AlA^aroDu, aor.
Daba3a ; and Dabubat; (K;) [instances of reduplicative verbs preserving their original forms;] and ↓ A^aDab~a, (S,) or A^aDab~at; (Msb, K;) The country, or land, abounded with [the lizards called] DibaAb, pl. of Dab~. (S, Msb, K.) -A7- Dab~a Aln~aAqapa, aor.
Dabu3a , (S, O,) inf. n. Dab~N, (O, K,) He milked the camel with five fingers [i. e. with his thumb and four fingers together]: (S, O:) or with the whole hand: (K: or this mode of milking is termed Daf~N: TA:) or by putting his thumb upon the teat and turning the fingers over the thumb and the teat together: (Fr, S, O, K: this is done when the teat is long: when it is of middling length, the mode termed bazomN is adopted, with the joint of the fore finger and the extremity of the thumb: and when it is short, the mode termed faTorN, with the extremity of the fore finger and the thumb: TA:) or by taking the two teats together in the hand: (K: [or this mode of milking is termed Daf~N:] and the milking with a hard squeezing is termed ↓ Dab~apN: TA:) or by contracting the hand upon the udder, and putting the thumb in, or upon, (fiY,) the middle of the palm. (L, TA.) -A8- [Dab~a and ↓ Db~b, each probably followed by EalaY, seem to signify sometimes It covered a thing, and became intermixed with it: the inf. ns. AlDbb (which I think to be a mistranscription for AlD~ab~u) and AltDbyb are expl. in the TA as signifying “ the covering a thing, and the entering of one part, or portion, of it into another: ” see two explanations of each of these verbs, followed by EalaY, voce A^aDab~a.]

2 Dab~a3a see above, last sentence: ― -b2- and see 4, in two places. -A2- Db~b EalaY AlD~ab~i He moved about his hand at the mouth of the hole of the [lizard called] Dab~, in order that it might come forth tail-foremost, and he might lay hold upon its tail. (TA. [See also muDab~ibN.]) -A3- Db~b AlbaAba, (S, Msb, K, * TA,) and Alxa$aba, (TA,) (tropical:) He put [or affixed] a Dab~ap [q. v.] upon the door, (S, Msb, K, * TA,) and upon the wood. (TA.) And Db~b AlA_inaA='a (assumed tropical:) He made a Dab~ap for the vessel. (Msb.) And Db~b A^asonaAnahu biAlfiD~api (assumed tropical:) He clamped his teeth ($ad~ahaA) with silver. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [taDobiybN also signifies The putting the numeral or &c. over each of two words, to indicate that the latter of those words in connected with, or refers to, the former of them.] -A4- Db~b AlS~abiY~a He fed the child with Dabiybap [q. v.]. (S, K.)

4 ADb~ EalaY $aYo'K *
He kept, or clave, to a thing, and did not quit it: (TA:) and ADb~ fulaAnFA He kept, or clave, to such a one, and did not quit him: (K:) and ADb~ Ealayohi He retained him, detained him, or held him in custody: (AZ, K, TA:) and ADb~ maA fiY yadayohi He grasped, or kept hold of, that which was in his hands; like A^aDobaA^a and A^aDobaY. (TA in art. DbA^.) And the first of these phrases, (TA,) inf. n. A_iDobaAbN; (K, TA;) as also ↓ Dab~a, [aor.
Dabi3a ,] (TA,) inf. n. Dab~N; (K, TA;) and ↓ Db~b, (TA,) inf. n. taDobiybN; (K, TA;) signifies AiHotawaY Ealayohi [i. e. He grasped it; got, or gained, possession of it; took it, got it, or held it, within his grasp, or in his possession: or it comprised, comprehended, or contained, it]: (K, TA:) and EalaY $aYo'K ↓ Dab~, inf. n. Dab~N, He took, seized, or grasped, a thing with the hand: (TA; but only the inf. n. in this case is there mentioned:) and EalaY $aYo'K ↓ Db~b, inf. n. taDobiybN, He took, seized, or grasped, a thing violently, or firmly, lest it should escape from his hand. (ISh, O, TA. [See also 1, last sentence.]) ― -b2- [It is said that] ADb~ Ealayohi also signifies He was at the point of getting possession of it, namely, a thing (O, K) that he sought, or desired. (K.) [But it seems from a passage in the TA, in which is an evident mistranscription, that this is a mistake, originated by Lth, for A^aDobaY.] -A2- ADb~ Als~iqaA='u The skin shed, or poured forth, its water, from a seam, or suture, (xurozap,) therein, (K, TA,) or from a cut. (TA.) [And ADb~ app. signifies He had a bleeding of the gums: for] mA zAl mDb~FA [app. ↓ muSib~FA] occurs in a trad. said of one whose gums bled [incessantly] when he spoke. (TA.) ― -b2- ADb~ fiY AlgaArapi He arose, and made a hostile incursion: (TA:) or ADb~, alone, he made a hostile incursion. (K.) And ADb~ Alqawomu The people, or party, rose, or rose and hastened and went forth, all together, to do a thing. (O, K.) ― -b3- ADb~wA lifulaAnK They dispersed themselves to seek such a one: and ADb~ Alqawomu fiY bagiy~atihimo The people, or party, dispersed themselves in search of their stray beast. (T, TA.) And ADb~ Aln~aEamu The camels, or cattle, approached, or came, in a scattered state. (K.) ― -b4- ADb~wA Ealayohi They multiplied against him. (S, O.) ― -b5- ADb~t AlA^aroDu The land became abundant in its plants, or herbage. (K. [But the only meaning of this phrase commonly known is one which will be found indicated below.]) Accord. to Ibn-Buzurj, (TA,) one says, ADb~t AlA^aroDu biAln~abaAti, meaning The land put forth all its plants, or herbage. (O, TA.) And ADb~ Al$~aEaru The hair became abundant, or much. (K) -A3- A^aDobabotuhu I made it to flow; namely, water, and blood. (S.) And ADb~ livatahu He made his gum to flow [with blood]. (S, O.) ― -b2- And ADb~ He spoke; (AZ, S, O, K;) as though meaning he made speech to issue: (S, O: [in both of which it is implied that it is app. from what here next precedes:]) or he spoke uninterruptedly: (TA:) or he talked loudly; as also ↓ Dab~a [aor.
Dabi3a ]: (AA, TA in art. hDb: [but it will be seen in what follows that both of these verbs have also a contr. meaning:]) and he called out, or cried out, (K, TA,) and raised a clamour, or confused noise. (TA.) And ADb~ Alqawomu The people, or party, spoke, one to another: (TA:) or spoke; and entered, or launched forth, into discourse, or were profuse therein: (AHát, TA:) or spoke all together. (Har p. 543.) And ADb~ maA fiY nafosihi He uttered, or expressed, what was in his mind. (As, TA. [See also the same phrase with EalaY after the verb in what follows.]) ― -b3- Also, (TA,) inf. n. A_iDobaAbN; (K, TA;) and ↓ Dab~a, (TA,) [aor.
Dabi3a ,] inf. n. Dab~N; (K, TA;) He was silent. (K, TA. [Thus both of these verbs have two contr. meanings.]) And ADb~ Alqawomu The people or party, were silent, and abstained from talking. (AHát, TA.) And ADb~ EalaY Al$~aYo'i, and ↓ Dab~a; and ADb~ bihi; He was silent respecting the thing [and concealed it]: like A^aDobaA^a. (TA.) And ADb~ EalaY maA fiY nafosihi He was silent respecting that which was in his mind: (As, S, K:) like A^aDobaA^a. (S.) And ADb~ EalaY gil~K fiY qalobihi He concealed rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, in his heart. (S, O.) And ADb~ Al$~aYo'a He hid, or concealed, the thing. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- ADb~ Algayomu The clouds covered [the earth]. (TA.) ― -b5- And ADb~ said of a day, (S, O, Msb, K,) and ADb~t said of the sky, (A, TA,) It became cloudy, or misty, with DabaAb [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) -A4- ADb~ Albaladu and ADb~t AlA^aroDu: see 1, latter half.

5 tDb~b * (assumed tropical:) He (a child) became fat, and his armpits became chapped, or cracked, (Ainofataqato,) [in the creases,] and his neck became short: (S:) or (tropical:) he (a child) began to grow fat: (A, TA:) and accord. to AHn, it is said in this sense of a camel as well as of a human being. (TA.)

10 xu*o maA A@sotaDab~a *
Take thou what is easily attainable; what offers itself without difficulty. (AA, TA in art. ndb.)

R. Q. 1 DaboDba *
He bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or hid enmity, and violent hatred, in his heart. (O, TA.)

Dab~N * [A species of lizard; termed lacerta caudiverbera, from its habit of striking with its tail; (see jara$a;) Forskål (Descr. Animalium,
p. 13,) terms it lacerta Aegyptia; referring to Hasselquist, p. 302; and adds the following description: “ femora teretia sine verrucis: cauda verticillata non longa: squamæ patentes, subconicæ mucronatæ: corpus nudum, rugosum: ”] a certain reptile, or small creeping thing, (S, TA,) of those termed Ha$araAt, (TA,) well known; (K, TA;) resembling the waral [q. v., but not so long]: (TA:) or resembling the Hiro*awn [q. v.]; of which there are two species, one of the size of the Hr*wn, and one larger: (Msb:) accord. to 'Abd-El-Káhir, of the size of a little young crocodile; having a tail like the tail of the latter: it assumes various colours when exposed to the sun, like as does the chameleon; lives seven hundred years; drinks not water, being satisfied with the air; voids one drop of urine in every forty days; its teeth consist of one curved piece; when it has quitted its hole it knows it not; and it lays eggs, like a bird: so say IKh and Dmr and others: AM says, the waral is of a lank make, with a long tail; the latter resembling that of a serpent; and the length of some exceeds two cubits; but the tail of the Db~ is jointed, and its utmost length is a span: the Arabs deem the wrl a foul and filthy thing, and do not eat it; but they are eager to hunt and eat the Db~: this animal has a rough tail, serrated with jags resembling vertebræ; its colour inclines to a blackish dusty hue; and when it becomes fat, its breast becomes yellow; it eats nothing but [the locusts called] janaAdib, and young locusts before their wings have grown (dabFA), and herbage, not venomous or noxious reptiles; whereas the wrl eats scorpions and serpents and chameleons and beetles: its flesh is an antidote against poisons, and women grow fat upon it: (L, TA:) it is the longest, of the animals, in retaining the remains of life: (O:) [see also muTab~ixN:] the fem. is with p: (S, O, Msb, K:) and the pl. [of pauc.] is A^aDub~N and [of mult.] DibaAbN (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K) and Dub~aAnN, (K,) which last Lh particularizes as used to denote a great number, but ISd sees no reason for this distinction, (TA,) and [quasipl. n.] ↓ maDab~apN, (O, K,) like as ma$oyaxapN is of $ayoxN, (O,) this last on the authority of As, as heard by him from more than one of the Arabs. (TA.) Hence one says rajulN xab~N Dab~N (tropical:) [A very deceitful or mischievous, and] an abominable, guileful, ireful man: (TA:) or a very deceitful or mischievous or wicked, and guileful man: (S:) likened to the [lizard called] Dab~ on account of his guilefulness: and in like manner, AimoraA^apN xab~apN Dab~apN. (A, TA.) And A^axodaEu mina AlD~ab~i More guileful than the Db~: (A, TA:) a prov. (TA.) And A^aEaq~u mino Dab~K [More undutiful to kindred than a Db~]; because the Db~ often eats its Husuwl [or young ones when they have just come forth from the eggs]: another prov.: (S:) A^abuw HisolK is a surname of the Db~. (TA.) One says also A^aTowalu *amaA='F mina AlD~ab~i, another prov. [expl. in art. *mY]. (O.) And A^aHoyaru mino Dab~K, which is likewise a prov. [expl. in art. Hyr]. (Har p. 166.) And A^atuEolimuniY biDab~K A^anaA Hara$otuhu, another prov. [expl. in art. Hr$]. (TA.) And laA A^afoEaluhu Hat~aY yaHin~a AlD~ab~u fiY A_ivori AlA_ibili AlS~aAdirapi [I will not do it until the Db~ utters a yearning cry at the heels of the camels returning from water]: and laA A^afoEaluhu Hat~aY yarida AlD~ab~u [I will not do it until the Db~ comes to water: i. e. I will never do it:] because the Db~ does not drink water. (S, O.) kaf~u AlD~ab~i [means The paw of the Db~]: to this the Arabs liken the hand of the niggard when he fails to give: (TA:) and it is also applied by way of comparison to (tropical:) a niggard himself: and to denote (tropical:) shortness and littleness. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] (tropical:) Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, (S, A, O, Msb, K, TA,) latent in the heart; (A, TA;) like the [lizard called] Db~ hiding itself in the furthest extremity of its hole: (A:) and anger, wrath, or rage: (K:) or rancour, &c., or vehement rancour, &c., and enmity: (TA:) and ↓ Dib~N signifies the same: (K:) the pl. is DibaAbN, and [app. DibabN also, for] the phrase kul~N minohumaA HaAmilu DibabK liSaAHibihi [Each of them a bearer of latent rancours &c. towards his fellow] occurs in a trad. (TA.) -A2- Also A certain disease in the lip, (S, O, Msb, K,) in consequence of which it flows with blood, (S, O, Msb,) or swells, and becomes hard, or dry and hard, and flows with blood. (TA.) ― -b2- And A tumour in the breast of a camel. (O, K.) ― -b3- And A tumour (S, O, K) in the xuf~, (so in copies of the K [i. e. foot], in the TA Anf [which is, I doubt not, a mistranscription],) or in the firosin, [which means the same, or the extremity of the foot,] (S, O,) of the camel. (S, O, K.) ― -b4- And A disease in the elbow of a camel; (K, TA;) said to be its cutting into his skin [by rubbing against it]; or its being distorted, and falling against his side, so as to gall it. (TA.) ― -b5- And A chapping, or cracking, (AinafitaAqN,) [in the crease] of the armpit [of a child, or of a camel], and abundance of flesh: (S, O, TA:) El- 'Adebbes El-Kinánee gives the same explanation, and says that this is what is also termed DaAgiTN. (TA. [See 5.]) -A3- Also The TaloE [i. e. the spadix, or the spathe,] of the palm-tree: pl. DibaAbN: (S, O:) or ↓ Dab~apN signifies, (K, TA,) and so Dab~N, (TA,) [but the latter seems to be a coll. gen. n., and the former its n. un.,] a TaloEap [meaning spathe of a palm-tree] before it cleaves open (K, TA) from [around] the gariyD [or spadix]. (TA.)
Dib~N * : see the next preceding paragraph, latter half.

Dab~apN * [an inf. n. un. of Dab~a: as such signifying] A single bleeding of the gum [&c.]. (Ham pp. 28 and 274.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence but one. -A2- Also A single [lizard of the species termed] Dab~ [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And The skin of a [lizard of the species termed] Dab~, tanned for clarified butter (K, TA) to be put into it. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A broad piece of iron with which a door (or wood, TA) is clamped or strengthened (yuDab~abu): (S, Mgh, O, K, TA:) or a piece of iron or brass or the like, with which a vessel is repaired: (Msb:) [a word still used in these senses; commonly applied to a flat piece of iron or the like, which is nailed across a crack in a wooden vessel or a similar thing: and a band of metal which is affixed around a cracked vessel: (see an ex. voce EaSaba:) also to a kind of wooden lock, figured and described in the Introduction to my work on the Modern Egyptians:] what is first described above is so called because it is broad, like the reptile so termed; and also katiyfapN, because it is broad, like a katif [or shoulder-blade]: (AM, TA:) pl. Dab~aAtN (A, Msb, TA) and DibaAbN. (A, TA.) The Dab~ap of a knife is The juzo'ap [thereof; app. meaning a ferrule, or similar thing, affixed around the handle, next the blade, like the band of metal thus called which is affixed around a cracked vessel (as mentioned above); though juzo'apN generally means the “ handle ” itself]: thus called because it strengthens, or binds, the handle (ta$ud~u Aln~iSaAba). (A, TA.) ― -b4- See also Dab~N, last sentence. ― -b5- And see DabiybN.
A^aroDN DabibapN * : see maDab~apN.

DabaAbN * [Mist; i. e.] moisture (nadFY), (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) like clouds, (A, K,) or like dust, covering the earth in the early mornings: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) or thin clouds, like smoke: (A, K:) or thin clouds; so called because they cover the horizon: n. un. with p: (TA:) or pl. of DabaAbapN, [but it is rather a coll. gen. n., and DabaAbapN is its n. of un.,] (S, Mgh, O,) and this latter signifies a cloud that covers the earth, resembling smoke: (S, O:) or a vapour rising from the earth in a rainy, or cloudy, day, like a canopy, preventing vision by its darkness. (TA.)
DabuwbN * A beast that stales while running. (K.) ― -b2- And A ewe, or she-goat, having a narrow orifice to the teat, (O, K,) whose milk will not come forth but with difficulty. (O.)
DabiybN * The point, or edge, (syn. Had~, [in an. ex. in the O, the former is meant by it,]) of a sword; (O, K;) and so ↓ Dab~apN. (El-Khattábee, TA.)

DabiybapN *
Clarified butter, and rob (rub~), which are put into a skin (Euk~p), for a child, that he may be fed with it. (S, K.)
bnAt Dbybp * [app. banaAtu DubayobapK; the latter word, dim. of Dab~apN;] A species [or variety] of the [lizards called] DibaAb [pl. of Dab~N]. (Ham p. 61.)

DiboDibN *
Fat, as an epithet; (K;) and so [without DubaADibN] applied to a woman: (TA:) and ↓ DubaADibN, applied to a man, short and fat. (S, O.) And Very foul or obscene, and bold or daring; as also ↓ DubaADibN: (K:) the latter thus expl. by IDrd: (O:) the former applied to a man, and with p applied to a woman, accord. to AZ, bold, or daring, in deed: (O, TA:) and proud; or bold, or daring, in wickedness: and with p, a woman bold, or daring; who glories over her neighbours. (TA.)

DubaADibN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. Also, applied to a man, Strong;
(IDrd, O, K;) and so buDaAbiDN: (IDrd, O:) or short, and very foul or obscene: or hard, or hardy, and strong: (K:) and sometimes applied as an epithet to a camel. (TA.)
A^aDab~u * , fem. Dab~aA='u, A camel affected with the disease termed Dab~ (S, K) in the xuf~ (K) or in the firosin. (S.) [See Dab~N.]
muDib~N * : see 4, in the former half. -A2- A^aroDN muDib~apN: see the next paragraph.

maDab~apN *
A piece of land abounding with [the lizards called] DibaAb [pl. of Dab~N]: pl. maDaAb~u: you say, waqaEonaA fiY maDaAb~a [We found ourselves in pieces of land abounding with DibaAb]. (S, O.) And A^aroDN maDab~apN, (K,) or ↓ muDib~apN, (S, IAth, Mgh, Msb,) and ↓ DabibapN, (S, K,) the last being one of those [reduplicative] words that preserve the original form, (S,) A land abounding with DibaAb. (S, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K.) -A2- See also Dab~N, [of which it is a quasi-pl. n.,] in the former half of the paragraph.

muDab~ibN *
A hunter of the [lizard called] Dab~, who pours water into its hole, in order that it may come forth and he may take it: (S, O:) or one who seeks to catch the Dab~ by moving about his hand at its hole in order that it may come forth tail-foremost and he may lay hold upon its tail. (K.)

1 DabaA^a * , (As, S, K,) aor.
DabaAa , inf. n. Dabo'N and Dubuwo'N, (K,) He (a man, TA) clave to the ground, (As, S, K, TA, [like Dab~a,]) or to a tree: (TA:) or DabaA^a biAlA^aroDi, aor. and inf. n. as above, he clave to the ground, and hid, or concealed, himself: and in like manner one says of a wolf, meaning he clave to the ground; or he hid, or concealed, himself in a covert of trees, or in a hollow in the ground, to deceive, or circumvent: (M:) and DabaA^a alone, he hid, or concealed, himself; (M, K;) as also ↓ ADTbA^: (K:) and the former, he concealed himself (K, TA) in a covert of trees, or in a hollow in the ground, (TA,) to deceive, or circumvent, (K, TA,) the game, or prey: (TA:) you say, DabaA^otu fiY AlA^aroDi, inf. n. as above, I hid, or concealed, myself in the land, or country. (AZ, S. [See also DanaA^a.]) ― -b2- DabaA^otu A_ilayohi I had recourse, or betook myself, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, or covert. (S, O, K. *) ― -b3- And DabaA^a, alone, He came forth from a place unexpectedly, and ascended [upon an eminence], (O, K, TA,) to look. (TA.) ― -b4- DabaA^a minohu He was abashed at, or shy of, or he shrank from, him, or it; (M, K, TA;) as also ↓ ADTbA^. (TA. [See also ADTnA^.]) -A2- DabaA^otu bihi AlA^aroDa I made him to cleave to the ground. (As, S, O, K. *)

4 ADbA^ maA fiY nafosihi *
He concealed what was in his mind: (K, * TA:) or ADbA^ Alqawomu EalaY maA fiY A^anofusihimo the people, or party, concealed what was in their minds. (M.) And ADbA^ EalaY Al$~aYo'i He was silent respecting the thing, (S, M, O, K,) and concealed it. (S, O.) And ADbA^ EalaY Ald~aAhiyapi i. q. A^aDab~a [i. e. He was silent respecting the calamity]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And ADbA^ EalaY maA fiY yadayohi, (M, TA,) or, accord. to Lh, ADbA^ maA fiY yadayohi, like A^aDobaY and A^aDab~a, (TA,) He grasped, or kept hold of, that which was in his hands. (Lh, M, TA.)
8 ADTbA^ * : see 1, in two places.

DabiYo'N *
Cleaving to the ground, (M, K, TA,) or to a tree; applied to a man. (TA.)
DaAbiy^N * [act. part. n. of 1, Cleaving to the ground: &c.:] expl. by El-Harbee as meaning a sportsman concealing himself. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Ashes; (M, K;) because they cleave to the ground. (TA.)
DaAbiy^apN * : see the last paragraph.

maDobaA^N *
A place where one conceals himself, (S, TA,) in a covert of trees, or in a hollow in the ground, to deceive, or circumvent, the game, or prey: pl. maDaAbiy^u. (TA.)

maDobuwo'N bihi *
Made to cleave to the ground. (As, S.)

muDaAbiy^N * , (O,) or muDaAbiy^apN, (K, [and so in the O in an instance mentioned in what here follows, in the next sentence,]) and ↓ DaAbiy^apN, (TA, as from the K, but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K,) A [large sack such as is called] giraArap that oppresses by its weight, and conceals, him who carries it (O, K, TA) beneath it. (O, TA.) ― -b2- The second of these words is also applied in a poem recited by [its author] Aboo-Hizám El- 'Oklee, to ISk, to the said poem, which is one abounding with hemzehs [and difficult to pronounce]. (O, * TA.)

1 Dabava bihi * , (S, K,) aor.
Dabiva , (K,) inf. n. DabovN, (S,) He grasped, seized, or laid hold upon, him, or it, with his hand; as also ↓ ADTbv: (S, K:) or, accord. to an explanation of the inf. n. by Ibn-Es-Seed, he did so with the utmost vehemence, or strength: (TA:) or he grasped, seized, or laid hold upon, and took, him, or it: (Sh, TA:) or Dabava Ealayohi has the first of these meanings; (A, L;) as also Dabavahu: (A:) and Dabava bihi signifies he seized him violently, or laid violent hands upon him. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also, i. e. Dabava bihi, aor. and inf. n. as above, He applied his hand to it, namely, a thing that he was making, or doing, diligently, earnestly, or with painstaking. (TA.) ― -b3- And Dabavahu He beat, struck, or smote, him, namely, a man. (K.) ― -b4- And He felt, for the purpose of testing, him, or it, with his hand. (TA.) One says, of a she-camel, tuDobavu, meaning She is felt with the hand, when one doubts of her fatness. (S, A, K.)
8 ADTbv bihi * : see the preceding paragraph.
DabivN * : see $abivN: ― -b2- and see also DubaAvN.

DabovapN *
A grasp, or seizure. (O, TA.) [See also A^aDobaAvN.] ― -b2- And AlD~abovapu, (K,) or Dabovapu AlA^asadi, (A, TA,) is the name of A certain brand, upon a camel, (A, K, TA,) in the form of a ring with some lines before and behind: (A, TA:) it is on the side of the thigh. (TA.)
DubavapN * : see $ubavapN.

DubaAvN * The nails of the lion. (K, * TA.) [See also maDaAbivu.] ― -b2- And AlD~ubaAvu, (O, K, TA, in the CK AlD~abAvu, but it is) like guraAb, (TA,) [is a name of] The lion; as also ↓ AlD~abuwvu, and ↓ AlD~abivu, and ↓ AlmiDobavu, and ↓ AlmuDoTabivu. (O, K.)

naAqpN DabuwvN * (tropical:) A she-camel of which one doubts whether she be fat, and which one therefore feels with the hand: (S, A, K:) and so naAqapN DaguwvN. (S and K in art. Dgv.) ― -b2- AlD~abuwvu: see DubaAvN.

DubaAviY~N *
Strong in the grasp; applied to a man; and in like manner to a lion. (O.) And DubaAviy~apN, (O, K, TA,) with damm, and with teshdeed to the Y, (TA, [in the CK without teshdeed,]) A fore arm (*iraAE) big, broad, and strong. (O, K.)

DaAbivN * [act. part. n. of Dabava]. One says, layovN biA^aqoraAnihi DaAbivN wabiA^arowAHihimo EaAbivN (tropical:) [A man like a lion, seizing violently his adversaries, and making sport with their souls]. (A, TA.)

A^aDobaAvN * [as though pl. of DabovapN, q. v.,] Grasps; syn. qabaDaAt. (S, K: but in copies of the K qaboDaAt.) So in the following words of a trad.: laA yadoEuwniY waAlxaTaAyaA bayona A^aDobaAvihimo [i. e. They shall not invoke Me when sins are in their grasps]; (S, * TA;) meaning, while they are still bearing the burden of their sins, not desisting therefrom: said by revelation to David: but it is also related otherwise, with n [i. e. A^aDobaAnihimo]. (TA.)
miDobavN * : see maDaAbivu: ― -b2- and DubaAvN.
maDobuwvN * A camel marked with the brand mentioned above, voce DabovapN. (A, K.)
maDaAbivu * The nails, or claws, (S, A, K,) of the lion: (S, A:) a pl. having no sing., or its sing. is mDbv [i. e. ↓ miDobavN]. (TA.) [See also DubaAvN.]
AlmuDoTabivu * : see DubaAvN.

1 DabaHati Alxayolu * , (AO, S, O, K, * [in the K DabaHa,]) aor.
DabaHa , (K,) inf. n. DaboHN (AO, S, K) and DubaAHN, (K,) i. q. naHamat, i. e. [The horses breathed pantingly, or hard, with a sound from the chest; or] made the breathing to be heard when running: (S, O:) [or breathed laboriously, when fatigued; and in like manner one says of camels; for] DaboHN signifies the breathing of horses and of camels when fatigued: (Suh, TA:) or caused a sound to be heard from their mouths, different from neighing, and from the sound termed HamoHamapN, (K, TA,) in their running: (TA:) [or it signifies also the horses neighed; for it is said that] AlD~ubaAHu is
also syn. with AlS~ahiylu: (TA:) or, [but probably only with the former of the two inf. ns. mentioned above,] ran a pace less quick than that which is termed taqoriyb: (K, TA:) or i. q. DabaEat, (AO, S, O, TA,) which means they stretched forth their arms, (AO, TA,) going along, (AO, S, * O, TA,) or running: (AO, TA:) accord. to I'Ab, one does not say DabaHato daAb~apN except in speaking of a dog or a horse: [he app. means that this verb is used thus only as denoting the uttering of a sound, or a manner of breathing:] some of the lexicologists say that those who use it in relation to a camel make DaboHN to have the meaning of DaboEN. (TA.) ― -b2- DabaHa, (L, TA,) inf. n. DubaAHN, (S, A, O, L, K, TA,) as meaning He, or it, uttered a cry, or sound, is also said of the fox, (S, * A, * O, * L, K, * TA,) and of the hare, and of the serpent called A^asowad, and of the owl, and of what is termed AlS~adaA [which see, for it is variously explained]: (L, TA:) and is also expl. as meaning nabaHa [he barked, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And DabaHati Alqawosu, aor. as above, inf. n. DaboHN, (assumed tropical:) The bow [twanged, or] made a sound. (TA.) ― -b4- And DabaHa is also used as meaning (tropical:) He cried out, and entered into an altercation for a person who had given him money. (IKt, O, * TA, from a trad.) -A2- DabaHatohu Aln~aAru, (S, O, K, TA,) and Al$~amosu, aor.
DabaHa , inf. n. DaboHN, (TA,) The fire, and the sun, altered it: (TA:) or altered its colour: (T, TA:) or altered it, but not in a great degree; (S, O, K, TA;) namely, a thing, (K, TA,) such as a stick, and an arrow, and flesh-meat, &c. (TA.) And DabaHahu biAln~aAri, aor.
DabaHa , inf. n. DaboHN, He altered it in colour by fire; namely, an arrow: and he burned it in a portion of its upper parts; namely, a stick, and flesh-meat, &c. (L, TA.) And DaboHN is expl. by AHn as meaning The act of roasting, broiling, or frying. (TA.)
3 muDaAbaHapN * The act of mutual reviling, or vilifying, and encountering, (K, TA,) and contending, or striving, to repel. (TA.)
6 tDAbH * [It sent forth a sound]. (Ham p. 615 [q. v.: it is there said to be from AlD~aboHu meaning AlS~awotu].)

7 AnDbH *
It became altered, (K, TA,) or altered in colour, (TA,) but not in a great degree, by fire, (K, TA,) and by the sun. (TA.) And AnDbH lawonuhu His, or its, colour became altered a little towards blackness. (S, TA.)
DaboHN * , (so in three copies of the S, and in the O,) or ↓ DiboHN, with kesr, (so accord. to the K,) Ashes: (S, O, K:) so called because of the alteration of their colour. (TA.)
DiboHN * : see what next precedes.

DaboHapN *
A cry of a fox [&c.: an inf. n. un.]. (TA.)

qawosN DaboHaA='u *
A bow upon which fire has taken effect (K, TA) so as to alter its colour: (TA:) like DahobaA='u. (TA in art. Dhb. [See also what next follows.])

DabiyHN * An arrow altered in colour [by fire]; as also ↓ maDobuwHN. (TA. [See an ex. of the latter in a verse of Tarafeh cited voce mujomidN: and see also what here next precedes.]) It is also applied, (S, O,) in the same sense, (O,) to roasted flesh-meat. (S, O.) [And Freytag explains it as meaning, in the Deewan of Jereer, “ Cutis nigra, usta vulneribus. ”]

DaAbiHN * A man raising his voice in reading or reciting: pl. DawaAbiHu, which is anomalous, like fawaArisu [pl. of faArisN]. (TA.) ― -b2- And xayolN DawaAbiHu Horses stretching forth their arms in their going along: (A:) or running vehemently; like DawaAbiEu. (TA in art. DbE.)

maDobuwHN * : see DabiyHN. ― -b2- Also The stone that is in the [kind of ground called] Har~ap [q. v.]: because of its blackness. (TA.) And maDobuwHapN Stones from which one strikes fire, (S, O, K,) appearing as though burnt. (S, O.)
maDaAbiHu * [a pl. of which the sing. is most probably miDobaHN] Frying-pans. (AHn, TA.)

1 Dabara * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
Dabira , inf. n. DaborN (A, Msb, K) and DabaraAnN, (K,) He (a horse, S, Msb, K, and a person having his legs shackled, K, in running, TA, or a horse having his legs shackled, A) leaped with his legs put together; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) and so too, accord. to Zj, ↓ ADbr, said of a horse: (O:) or he ran: (TA:) or DaborN signifies a horse's leaping, and alighting with his fore legs put together. (As, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, A, K,) aor. as above, (S,) inf. n. DaborN, (S, K,) He made books, or writings, into a bundle: (S, A, K:) and ↓ Db~r, (A, TA,) inf. n. taDobiyrN, (K,) signifies the same: (A:) or he collected together (K, TA) books, or writings, (A, TA,) &c. (TA.) And the former verb, He collected together an army for war. (S, TA.) And Dabara Ealayohi AlS~axora, (S, A, K, *) aor. as above, (S, TA,) and so the inf. n., (K, TA,) He piled up the rocks, or great masses of stone, (S, K,) upon him, or it. (S.) ― -b3- DaborN also signifies The act of binding, or tying, firmly, fast, or strongly. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And [hence, app., as inf. n. of Dubira], (TA), and so taDobiyrN [as inf. n. of ↓ Dub~ira], (K, TA,) The being very compact and strong in the bones, and compact and full in flesh. (K, TA.) [See maDobuwrN.])
2 Dab~ara see the preceding paragraph, in two places.
4 A^aDobara see 1, first sentence.

DaborN * an inf. n. used as an epithet: see maDobuwrN. -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) A company of men engaged in a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition, (S, O, K, TA,) on foot. (TA.) And Footmen [app. meaning foot-soldiers]; syn. raj~aAlapN [quasi-pl. n. of raAjilN]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also [The musculus, or testudo; a machine made of] skin covering wood, (Lth, O, K,) within which are men, (K,) and which is brought near to fortresses, for the purpose of fighting, (Lth, O, K,) i. e. for fighting the people thereof: (Lth, O:) pl. DubuwrN, (Lth, O, K,) which means what are termed dab~aAbaAtN: (Lth, A, O: [see dab~aAbapN:]) [or it is a coll. gen. n.; for it is said that] one such thing is called DaborapN. (TA.) -A3- Also [The species of nut called] the wild jawoz (jawozu Albar~i), which is a hard sort of jwz, not the wild pomegranate, for this is called the maZ~: (S, O:) or the tree of what is called jawozu Albar~i; as also ↓ DabirN: (K:) or, accord. to [AHn] Ed-Deenawaree, each of these words, the latter being a dial. var. of the former, is applied to the tree of a sort of jawz found in the mountains of the Saráh (Als~araAp), which blossoms, but does not organize and compact any fruit (lAa yaEoqidu); and the n. un. is ↓ DabirapN [and DaborapN]: he says also that the Dabir was described to him by an Arab of the desert, of Saráh, as a great tree, as big as the great walnut-tree, having round leaves, as big as the hand, and very numerous. (O.) And the Dabor is [also] What is called jawozu baw~aA [i. e. the nutmeg]: (K:) IAar says that it is what the people of the towns and villages call jawozu baw~aA. (O.) -A4- And i. q. faqorN [Poverty, &c.]. (IAar, TA.)
DiborN * The armpit: (O, K, TA:) and so DibonN: thus says Ibn-El-Faraj. (TA.)
DabirN * ; and its n. un., with p: see DaborN.
Dibir~N * , applied to a horse, (S, O, K,) and to a lion, (O,) and to a man, (TA,) That leaps much: (S, O, K:) and so Timir~N. (O.) ― -b2- See also DabuwrN.
DibaArN * and DubaArN Books, or writings: [each a pl.] without a singular. (K.) [See also A_iDobaArapN.]

DabuwrN *
A lion; as also ↓ Dibir~N, and ↓ muDab~arN: (K:) or a lion that leaps much to the animals upon which he preys. (O.)

DabiyrN *
Hard, firm, or strong: syn. $adiydN; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) and so ↓ DanobarN. (TA.) ― -b2- And (hence, TA) The penis. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

*uw DabaArapK * , (S, O, K,) or *uw DabaArapK fiY xaloqihi, (TA,) A man having firmness of make: (S, O:) or having compactness and firmness of make: (K:) and so ↓ DubaArimN and ↓ DubaArimapN applied to a lion; (K in this art.;) the m in these being augmentative, accord. to Kh; (TA;) or the former of them, thus applied, strong in make; (S in art. Dbrm;) or the former of them signifies a lion, (ISk, K and TA in that art.,) as also DubaArikN, (ISk, TA ibid.,) and so the latter of them; (K ibid.;) and the former of them, applied to a man, courageous; (ISk, TA ibid.;) or each, (K ibid.,) or the latter of them, (TA ibid.,) thus applied, bold against the enemies. (K and TA ibid.)

DibaArapN * and DubaArapN: see A_iDobaArapN, in four places. ― -b2- DabaAy^iru is pl. of the former [or of each]: (Mgh, Msb:) and, as though pl. of the former, signifies Companies of men in a state of dispersion. (TA.)

A^m~u Dab~aArK *
i. q. AlHar~apu, q. v. (T in art. Am.)

Dub~aArN *
A sort of tree resembling very nearly that of the bal~uwT, [i. e. the oak,] (AHn, O, K,) the wood of which is good as fuel, like that of the maZ~: its fresh firewood, when kindled, sends forth a sound like that of maxaAriyq [pl. of mixoraAqN, q. v.]; and therefore they use it to do so at the thickets wherein are lions, which flee in consequence: (AHn, O:) the n. un. is with p. (AHn, O, K.)
DubaArimN * and DubaArimapN: see DabaArapN.
DanobarN * : see DabiyrN.

A_iDobaArapN *
A bundle (Huzomap, Lth, Mgh, Msb, K, or A_iDomaAmap [q. v.], S, O) of books or writings; (Lth, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also A^aDobaArapN, (K,) and ↓ DibaArapN: (Lth, Mgh, Msb:) or of arrows: (Lth:) and ↓ DibaArapN signifies a bundle [absolutely]; as also ↓ DubaArapN: (O, K:) Lth alone explains DibaArapN as applied to a bundle of books or writings; others saying A_iDobaArapN: the pl. of A_iDobaArapN is A^aDaAbiyru; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) and that of ↓ DibaArapN is DabaAy^iru. (Mgh, O, Msb.)
muDab~arN * : see the following paragraph in three places: ― -b2- and see also DabuwrN.

maDobuwrN * A camel very compact and strong in the bones, and compact and full in flesh; as also ↓ muDab~arN: (K:) or both signify compact in make, and smooth: (Lth, * TA:) and Alxaloqi ↓ muDab~aru a horse firm in make: and Alxaloqi ↓ muDab~arapu the same applied to a she-camel: (S:) and ↓ DaborN a horse compact in make; an inf. n. used as an epithet. (Msb.)

div2.head: Quasi Dbrm
div2.entryFree: DubaArimN * and DubaArimapN: see art. Dbr.

1 DabaTahu * , (Lth, IDrd, S, Msb, K,) aor.
DabiTa , (Msb, MS, PS,) or
DabuTa , (TA, TK,) inf. n. DaboTN (IDrd, Msb, K) and DabaATapN, (K,) He kept it, preserved it, guarded it, maintained it, or took care of it, (Lth, S, Msb, K,) namely, a thing, (Lth, S,) with prudence, precaution, or good judgment, (Lth, S, K,) or effectually: (Msb:) and hence, (assumed tropical:) he managed its affairs (namely, the affairs of a country &c.,) thoroughly, soundly, not imperfectly: (Msb:) [he managed it; namely, an affair, and his soul or self, his disposition or temper, &c.:] he kept to it inseparably, or constantly; namely, anything: (Lth:) he took it, or held it, or retained it, strongly, vehemently, or firmly: (IDrd:) and DabaTa Ealayohi [has this last signification, likewise; or signifies simply he detained it, or withheld it, or restrained it, or the like;] i. q. Habasahu, namely a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- fulaAnN laA yaDobuTu Eamalahu [or lA yaDobiTuhu] (tropical:) Such a one does not, or will not, act vigorously in his work, or employment, which is committed to him; syn. laA yaquwmu bihi. (TA.) And DabaTa A^amorahu [He managed his affair thoroughly, or well]. (A in art. bd, &c.) [And DabaTa alone, He (a camel) was strong to work or labour: and he (a man and a camel) was strong, or powerful. (See the act. part. n.)] ― -b3- huwa laA yaDobuTu qiraA='atahu [or lA yaDobiTuhaA] (tropical:) He does not, or will not, perform well [or accurately] his reading, or reciting. (TA.) ― -b4- [DabaTa lafoZFA, or kalimapF, (assumed tropical:) He fixed the pronunciation of a word; by adding the syllabical signs, which mode is termed DaboTN biAl$~akoli, and biAlHarakaAti, and biAlqalami; or by stating it to be similar in form, or measure, to another word which is too well known to admit of doubt, which mode is termed DaboTN bimivaAlK; or by adding the measure, which mode is termed DaboTN biwazonK.] ― -b5- DabaTa also signifies (assumed tropical:) He registered, or recorded, [a name, or] a matter of science, [or any other thing,] in a book or the like; syn. qay~ada; (L in art. qyd;) i. q. A^aHoSaY; (Jel in xxxvi. 11, and Bd and Jel in lxxviii. 29;) and kataba. (Bd in lxxviii. 29.) ― -b6- DabaTahu wajaEN (tropical:) A pain seized him. (TA.) ― -b7- DubiTati AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The land was rained upon. (IAar, K, TA.) [See also maDobuwTN.] -A2- DabiTa, aor.
DabaTa , (S, Msb,) inf. n. DabaTN, (Msb,) He was, or became, ambidextrous; he worked with each of his hands. (S, Msb.) IDrd knew not this verb. (TA.)

5 tDb~Thu *
He took it with detention and force. (K, TA.) ― -b2- tDb~Tt AlD~aA^onu The sheep obtained somewhat of herbage: or hastened, or were quick, in pasturing, and became strong (K, TA) and fat. (TA.) The Arabs say, A_i*aA taDab~iTati AlD~aA^onu $abiEati AlA_ibilu [When the sheep obtain somewhat of herbage, or hasten, &c., the camels become satiated with food]: for the former are called the smaller camels, because they eat more than goats; and when the former become satiated with food, men [and camels] live [in plenty], by reason of the abundance of the herbage. (IAar.)
DaboTN * inf. n. of 1. ― -b2- [It is often used as signifying (assumed tropical:) Exactness; correctness; honesty; and faithfulness: and particularly in an author or a relater.]

AlD~aboTapu *
A certain game of the Arabs; (K, TA;) also called Almas~apu and AlT~ariydapu. (TA. [See the last of these words.])

rajulN Dab~aATN liloA^umuwri * (assumed tropical:) A man having much care, prudence, or precaution, [or good judgment,] with respect to [the management of] affairs; (TA;) [a man who manages affairs with much care, &c.]
DabanoTFY * : see the next paragraph.

DaAbiTN * [Keeping, preserving, guarding, maintaining, or taking care of, a thing, with prudence, precaution, or good judgment, or effectually: (see 1:) and hence,] (assumed tropical:) one who manages his affairs with prudence, precaution, or good judgment; or soundly, taking the sure course therein, and exercising caution, or care, that they may not become beyond his power of management: (S, TA:) [keeping to anything inseparably, or constantly: (see, again, 1:)] taking, holding, or retaining, a thing strongly, vehemently, or firmly; applied to a man; as also ↓ DabanoTFY: (IDrd:) or the latter of these, (S,) which is like HabanoTFuY, (K, [in some copies of the K erroneously written without tenween,]) the n being augmentative, to render the word quasi-coordinate to safarojalN; (S;) or both; applied to a man and to a camel; (K;) strong, or powerful: (S, K:) or [a man] great in might, or valour, and power, and body: (T, TA:) and the former, a camel strong to work or labour: and in like manner, applied to a man, DaAbiTu AlA^umuwri (tropical:) the strong [and resolute or firm-minded] in the performance or management of affairs. (TA.) See also A^aDobaTu. ― -b2- [It often signifies (assumed tropical:) Exact; correct; or accurate; (like muHaq~iqN, with which it is said to be syn. in Har p. 254;) and honest; and faithful: and particularly as applied to an author or a relater.] -A2- As a conventional term, DaAbiTN, (Msb in art. qEd,) or ↓ DaAbiTapN, pl. DawaAbiTu, (TA,) is syn. with qaAEidapN, (Msb, TA,) signifying (assumed tropical:) A universal, or general, rule, or canon: (Msb:) or a DAbT is one that comprises subdivisions of one class only; whereas a qAEdp comprises [sometimes] subdivisions of various classes. (Kull, p. 290.)

DaAbiTapN *
A place in land, or in the ground, to which the rain-water flows, and which retains it; syn. mas~aAkapN. (TA.) -A2- See also DaAbiTN, last sentence.

A^aDobaTu * [More, and most, strong, or firm, of hold]. It is said in a prov., A^aDobaTu mino *ar~apK [More strong, or firm, of hold than a little ant]: because it drags along a thing several times larger than itself, and sometimes both fall from a high place, and the ant does not let go the thing. (K.) And A^aDobaTu mino EaAy^i$apa boni EavomK; (K;) so accord. to Hamzeh and Abu-n-Nedà; but accord. to ElMundhiree, EaAbisap; (Sgh;) [More strong, or firm, of hold than 'Áïsheh the son of 'Athm; or than 'Ábiseh;] because he laid hold of the tail of a young she-camel, and pulled her by it out of a well into which she had fallen. (K.) And A^aDobaTu mina AlA^aEomaY [More strong, or firm, of hold than the blind]. (TA.) ― -b2- Ambidextrous; who works with each of his hands; (S, Mgh, Msb;) i. q. A^aEosaru yasarN; (Mgh, Msb;) who works with his left hand like as he works with his right; an explanation given by the Prophet; as also that next following; (AO, TA;) who works with both his hands: (AO, K:) fem. DaboTaA='u. (S.) ― -b3- AlA^aDobaTu The lion; (K;) who makes use of his left paw like as he makes use of his right; but some say that he is so called because he seizes his prey vehemently, and it hardly, or never, escapes from him; (TA;) as also ↓ AlD~AbiTu. (K.) DaboTaA='u is also applied as an epithet to a lioness; and to a she-camel. (TA.)

maDobuwTN * [pass. part. n. of DabaTa in all its senses. ― -b2- In the present day often used as signifying Well-regulated; exact; correct; honest; and faithful.] Applied to a book, or writing, (tropical:) Having its defects, faults, or imperfections, rectified. (TA.) [Applied to a word, (assumed tropical:) Having its pronunciation fixed, by any of the means described above in one of the explanations of the verb.] ― -b3- baladN maDobuwTN biAlmaTari (tropical:) A country covered by the rain:
so in the A: in the O, A^aroDN maDobuwTapN (tropical:) land rained upon in common, or throughout its whole extent. (TA.) [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.]

1 DabaEahu * , aor.
DabaEa , (S, K,) inf. n. DaboEN, (TK,) He (a man, S) stretched forth towards him (another man, S) his upper arm (DaboEahu), for the purpose of striking. (S, K.) A poet says,
walaA SuloHa Hat~aY taDobaEuwanA wanaDobaEaA
i. e. [And there shall be no peace] until ye stretch forth towards us your upper arms with the swords and we stretch forth our upper arms towards you: or, accord. to AA, until ye stretch forth [towards us] your upper arms for the making of peace and the joining of hands [and we do the same]. (S.) And one says, DabaEa yadahu A_ilayohi biAls~ayofi, meaning He stretched forth his arm towards him with the sword. (K.) And DabaEa EalaY fulaAnK, (S, * K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He stretched forth his upper arms for the purpose of uttering an imprecation against such a one: (S, * K, TA:) and hence, DaboEN is metaphorically used to signify (tropical:) the act of supplicating or imprecating; because the person supplicating or imprecating raises his hands and stretches forth his upper arms: and DibaAEN, also, [app. an inf. n. of ↓ DaAbaEa,] signifies the raising the hands, or arms, in supplication or imprecation. (TA.) And DabaEati Alxayolu, and AlA_ibilu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
DabaEa , (S, Msb,) inf. n. DaboEN (S, K) and DubuwEN and DabaEaAnN, (K,) The horses, and the camels, stretched forth their arms (A^aDobaAEahaA, S, Msb, K, i. e. A^aEoDaAdahaA, S, Msb) in their going along; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Db~Et, inf. n. taDobiyEN: (S, K:) in [a copy of] the A expl. as meaning mad~ato A^aEonaAqahaA [stretched forth their necks; but this is probably a mistranscription, for md~t A^aEoDaAdahaA]: (TA:) DabaEat said of horses is like DabaHat, (K, TA,) which is a dial. var.: (TA:) and DabaEat said of a she-camel, inf. n. DaboEN, signifies the same as ↓ Db~Et, as also ↓ A^aDobaEat, on the authority of IKtt: (TA:) [or,] accord. to As, DaboEN signifies the lifting, (S,) or bending, (TA,) of the hoof, (S, TA,) by a horse, and the lifting of the foot, by a camel, (TA,) towards the arm: (S, TA:) or it signifies the running a pace above that which is termed taqoriyb: (O, K:) or DabaEa said of a camel signifies he hastened, or was quick, (K, TA,) in pace, or going: (TA:) or he went along shaking his arms. (K.) DabaEahu also signifies He (a camel) took him (another camel) by his arms, and threw him down. (L in art. EDd, and TA in the present art.) ― -b2- DabaEuwA lilS~uloHi, (K, TA,) and llomuSaAfaHapi; (TA;) or DabaEuwA A_ilaY AlS~uloHi; and DabiEuwA, inf. n. DabaEN; (Et-Toosee, TA;) They inclined to peace, (Et-Toosee, K, TA,) and the joining of hands; they desired peace, &c. (TA.) ― -b3- DabaEuwA lanaA AlT~ariyqa, (S, K,) or mina AlT~ariyqi, inf. n. DaboEN, (TA,) They gave us a share of the road: (S, K:) so says ISk: (S:) and in like manner one says, *araEuwA lanaATariyqFA. (TA.) And DabaEuwA Al$~aYo'a, (K, TA,) or mina Al$~aYo'i, (TA,) They gave a share of the thing (K, TA) to every one. (TA.) ― -b4- And DabaEa, (K,) inf. n. DaboEN, (TA,) He (a man) acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: (K:) on the authority of Aboo-Sa'eed. (TA.) -A2- DabiEat, aor.
DabaEa , inf. n. DabaEN (S, K) and DabaEapN; (S, * K; [this latter is said in the TA, on the authority of IAar, to have been used by an Arab of the desert in relation to a woman; and is, accord. to the S, app., a simple subst.;]) and ↓ A^aDobaEat, (S, K,) and ↓ AstDbEt; (K;) She (a camel) desired (S, K) vehemently (S) the stallion. (S, K.)

2 Dab~aEa see above, in two places. -A2- Db~E fulaAnFA He intervened between him and the object at which he desired to shoot or cast. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) -A3- And Db~E, inf. n. taDobiyEN, He was, or became, cowardly, or weak-hearted: (Lth, K:) thus say the vulgar; derived by them from AlD~abuEu, because this beast becomes still when one comes in upon it, and then it goes forth. (Lth, TA.)

3 DaAbaEonaAhumo biAls~uyuwfi *
We stretched forth our arms towards them with the swords, they stretching theirs forth towards us [therewith]: so in the “ Nawádir ” of AA. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in the former half. ― -b3- [The inf. n.] muDaAbaEapN also signifies The joining of hands; syn. muSaAfaHapN. (TA.)
4 A^aDobaEa see 1, near the middle of the paragraph: -A2- and also the last sentence of the same.

8 AlAiDoTibaAEu * , which the circuiter round the House [of God, i. e. the Kaabeh,] is commanded to perform, (S,) or in the case of the muHorim, (K,) is The putting the [garment called] ridaA=' under one's right armpit, and turning back the extremity thereof over his left [shoulder], exposing to view his right shoulder [and arm] and covering the left; (S, K, TA;) like the man that desires to labour at a thing and prepares himself for doing so; (TA;) thus termed because of exposing to view one of the two upper arms: (S, K:) or the putting one's garment (Mgh, Msb) under his right arm, (Mgh,) or under his right armpit, (Msb,) and throwing [a portion of] it upon his left shoulder: (Mgh, Msb:) or the taking the A_izaAr or the burod, and putting the middle of it under one's right armpit, and throwing the extremity thereof upon his left shoulder, over his breast and his back: (IAth, TA:) Alt~aA^ab~uTu and Alt~awa$~uHu likewise signify the same: so says Az: (Msb:) and so says As of the former: (S:) and it is also written AlAiT~ibaAEu. (Thus in the TA in explanation of Alt~aA^ab~uTu.) You say, AiDoTabaEa bivawobihi [He attired himself with his garment in the manner described above]. (Mgh, Msb.) And ADTbE Al$~aYo'a He put the thing under his upper arms. (TA. [But accord. to the Mgh, the verb is trans., correctly, only by means of bi.])
10 A_isotaDobaEa see 1, last sentence.

DaboEN * The EaDud [i. e. upper arm of a human being, and arm of a quadruped], (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) altogether: (K:) or the middle thereof, (Lth, Mgh, O, K,) with its flesh: (O, K:) and the inner side thereof: (Mgh:) or (so in some copies of the K, but in others “ and, ”) the armpit: or the portion, of the upper part of the EaDud, that is between the armpit and the half of the former: (K:) it is of man and of other than man: (TA:) pl. A^aDobaAEN. (S, Msb, K.) One says, A^abad~a DabEayohi, [expl. in art. bd,] speaking of a man praying. (O, TA.) And A^axa*otu biDaboEaYo fulaAnK falamo A^ufaAriqohu and madadotu biDaboEayohi, meaning I seized the middle of the upper arms of such a one [and did not relinquish him]. (Lth, O, TA.) And ja*abahu biDaboEayohi (tropical:) He raised him, or set him up, and rendered his name famous: and in like manner, A^axa*a biDaboEayohi, and mad~a biDaboEayohi. (TA.) -A2- Also Any [hill such as is termed] A^akamap that is black and somewhat oblong. (IAar, K.) -A3- *ahaba bihi DaboEFA laboEFA means baATilFA [i. e., app., He took it away with a false pretence; or in play, or sport]; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA;) namely, a thing; (O, TA;) laboEFA being an imitative sequent. (TA.) -A4- See also DabuEN. -A5- And see what here next follows.

kun~aA fiY DuboEi fulaAnK * (S, O, K) and flAn ↓ DaboEi and flAn ↓ DiboEi (K) We were in the protection, or quarter, (kanaf, and naAHiyap,) of such a one. (S, O, K: but in the K, huwa is put in the place of kun~aA.)
kun~aA fiY DiboEi fulaAnK * : see what next precedes.

DabuEN * (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and ↓ DaboEN, (Msb, K,) the former of the dial. of Keys and the latter of the dial. of Temeem, (Msb,) [The female hyena; or the hyena, male and female;] a certain animal of prey, (sabuEN, [but see what follows,]) (K,) well known, (S, O,) the worst, or most abominable, of sibaAE, (Mgh,) resembling the wolf, except that, when it runs, it is as though it were lame, wherefore it is called AlEarojaA='u: it flees from him who holds in his hand a colocynth: [and they assert that] the dogs bark not at him who retains with him its teeth: if its skin is bound upon the belly of her that is pregnant, she casts not her young: if seed is measured in a measure covered with its skin, the seed-produce is secure from the banes thereof: and the application of its gall-bladder as a collyrium sharpens the sight: (K:) it is not reckoned among the hostile animals to which the appellation of sabuEN is applied, wherefore the Sunneh allows that its flesh may be eaten, and requires that a compensation be made for it [by the sacrifice of a ram] if it be smitten [and killed] in the sacred territory by a person in the state of ihrám: (TA voce sabuEN:) the word is of the fem. gender, (S, * Mgh, * O, * Msb, K, *) and is [said to be] applied peculiarly to the female; (Msb;) the male being called ↓ DiboEaAnN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) of which the pl. is DabaAEiynu; (S, O, Msb, K;) but AHát disapproved this pl.; (O;) and the female is called [also] ↓ DiboEaAnapN, of which the pl. is DiboEaAnaAtN; (S, O, K;) or DiboEaAnapN has not been heard applied
to the female, but DabuEN only, and it seems that J has mentioned DiboEaAnapN as applied to the female from his having supposed DiboEaAnaAtN to be pl. of DiboEaAnapN, whereas it is pl. of DiboEaAnN, being like rijaAlaAtN and jimaAlaAtN: (IB in a marginal note in one of my copies of the S:) but some say that DabuEN or DaboEN is applied to the male; and the female is termed DaboEapN, thus with a quiescent letter: (Msb:) or, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, the female is termed DabuEapN, and its pl. [or rather the coll. gen. n.] is DabuEN; (O, K;) or DabaEapN is not allowable: (S, K:) the pl. of DabuEN or DaboEN is A^aDobuEN, (K,) a pl. of pauc., (TA,) and DibaAEN, (K,) or the former is pl. of DaboEN, (Msb,) and the latter is pl. of DabuEN, (Mgh, Msb,) and is of the male and of the female, (S, K,) and DubuEN, (K,) as though this were pl. of DibaAEN, (AAF, TA,) and DubEN [a contraction of DubuEN] (K) and DubuEaAtN and DubuwEapN (TA [in which it is indicated that this last is pl. of DaboEN]) and [quasi-pl. n.] ↓ maDobaEapN. (O, K.) One says A^amodaru ↓ DiboEaAnN, [in the CK, erroneously, DaboEaAnu,] meaning, [A male hyena] inflated in the sides, big in the belly: or, accord. to some, whose sides are defiled with earth, or dust. (S.) And sayolN jaAr~u AlD~abuEi A torrent that draws forth the DabuE from its den; (O, K; in the CK, jAr~N AlS~abuEa;) hence meaning (assumed tropical:) a torrent produced by vehement rain. (TA.) And dalojapu AlD~abuEi [The night-journeying of the hyena]; because the DabuE goes round about until midnight. (O, K.) And maA yaxofaY *`lika EalaY AlD~abuEi [That is not unapparent to the hyena]: because the DabuE is deemed stupid. (TA.) A^aHomaqu mina AlD~abuEi [More stupid than the hyena] is a prov. (Meyd.) And A^akalatohumu AlD~abuEu (tropical:) [The hyena devoured them] is said of such as are held in mean estimation. (TA.) [But this may be otherwise rendered, as will be seen from what follows.] The saying of a poet,
tafar~aqato ganamiY yawomFA faqulotu lahaA
yaA rab~i sal~iTo EalayohaA Al*iy^oba waAlD~abuEaA
[My sheep, or goats, dispersed themselves, one day, and I said in relation to them, O my Lord, set upon them the wolf and the hyena], is said to mean an imprecation, that the wolf might kill the living of them, and the hyena devour the dead of them: or, as some say, it means that the speaker prayed for their safety; because, when both fall upon the sheep, or goats, each of them is diverted from the sheep, or goats, by the other; and thus means the saying, Aall~`hum~a DabuEFA wa*iy^obFA [O God, send a hyena and a wolf]: but the more probable meaning of the poet is an imprecation, the consequence of his anger and fatigue; and the word sal~iTo imports a notification of this meaning. (IB, TA.) ― -b2- [The pl.] AlD~ibaAEu is applied to (assumed tropical:) Numerous stars below banaAt naEo$: (O, K:) or [the stars beta, gamma, delta and mu, of Bootes; i. e.] the star upon the head, and that upon [each of] the shoulders, and that upon the club, of AlEaw~aA=': and the name of A^awolaAdu AlD~ibaAEi is given to [The stars θ, ι, κ and λ, app. with some other faint stars around these, of Bootes; i. e.] the stars upon the left hand and fore arm, and what surround the hand, of the faint stars, of AlEaw~aA='. (Kzw.) ― -b3- AlD~abuEu also signifies (tropical:) The year of drought or sterility or dearth; (S, IAth, O, Msb, K, TA;) that is destructive; severe: of the fem. gender. (TA.) So in a verse cited in art. AmA [voce A^am~aA, and again, with a variation, voce A_im~aA]. (S, O. [But it is here said in the TA that AlD~abuEu in this instance means the animal of prey thus called.]) [Hence also,] it is related in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, that a man said, yaA rasuwla A@ll~`hi A^akalatonaA AlD~abuEu (tropical:) [O Apostle of God, the year of drought has consumed us]: and he prayed for them. (TA.) [See also two other exs. voce *iy^obN.] ― -b4- Also (tropical:) Hunger. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Evil, or mischief. (TA.) El-'Okeyleeyeh said, “ When a man whose evil, or mischief, we feared removed from us, we used to light a fire behind him: ” and being asked “ Why? ” she said, liyataHaw~ala DabuEuhu maEahu, i. e. (assumed tropical:) In order that his evil, or mischief, might go away with him. (IAar, TA.)

DabiEapN * A she-camel desiring [vehemently (see 1, last sentence,)] the stallion; (Lth, K;) as also ↓ muDobiEapN: (L, TA:) pl., accord. to the copies of the K, DabaAEN and DabaAEaY; but in the L, DibaAEaY and DabaAEaY: (TA:) and sometimes it is used in relation to women. (K.)
DiboEaAnN * ; and its fem., with p: see DabuEN, in three places.

DaAbiEN * A she-camel stretching forth her arms (A^aDobaAEahaA, S, K, i. e. A^aEoDaAdahaA, S) in going along: (S, K:) or lifting her foot towards her arm in going along: so accord. to an explanation by As of the former of the two following pls.: (TA:) the pl. is DawaAbiEu (Lth, As, TA) and Dub~aEN. (TA.) And A horse that runs vehemently; (O, K, TA;) like DaAbiHN, of which the pl. is DawaAbiHu: (TA:) or that runs much: (Lth, O, TA:) or that bends his hoof towards his arm: (TA:) or that inclines towards (lit. follows) one of his sides, and bends his neck. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

A^aDobaEu *
i. q. A^aEoDabu [q. v.]; formed from the latter by transposition. (TA.)
maDobaEapN * The portion of flesh that is beneath the armpit, in the fore part. (O, K.) -A2- See also DabuEN [of which it is a quasi-pl. n.].
muDobiEapN * : see DabiEapN.
muDab~aEapN * A she-camel whose breast is prominent and whose arms recede. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

HimaArN maDobuwEN *
An ass devoured by the DabuE [or hyena]: (O, K:) or [an ass which may the hyena devour, for] accord. to some it means an imprecation that the DbE may devour him. (TA.)

1 Dabanahu * , aor.
Dabina , inf. n. DabonN, He put him, or it, (i. e. a man, or another thing,) above his Dibon [q. v.]. (TA.) [See also what next follows.]

4 ADbnhu *
He put it in his Dibon, (S, K, TA,) or on his Dibon; (TA;) or he took it beneath his Dibon, i. e. his HiDon [or the part between his armpit and flank]: (A'Obeyd, TA:) and ↓ ADTbnhu signifies the same. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- And He straitened him, or it, (K, TA,) by putting him, or it, beneath his side. (TA.)
8 ADTbnhu * : see 4. ― -b2- Also He took him, or it, with his hand, and raised him, or it, to a little above his navel. (TA.)

DibonN * The part between the armpit and the ka$oH [or flank]; (S, K, TA;) or the HiDon [which generally means as above]; (A'Obeyd, TA;) [or] the part, of the side, between the armpit and the HiDon [which is here evidently used as syn. with ka$oH]: (S:) or the armpit [itself]: so says Ibn-El-Faraj: like DiborN: (TA in art Dbr:) or the armpit and the part next to it: or the uppermost part of the side: or the part beneath the ka$oH [or flank] and beneath the armpit: or the part between the xaASirap [or flank] and the head [or crest] of the hip. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A side of a road: one says, A^axa*a fiY DibonK mina AlT~ariyqi (assumed tropical:) He took a side of the road: pl. A^aDobAnN. (TA.) ― -b3- And huwa fiY Diboni fulaAnK means (assumed tropical:) He is in the quarter, or protection, of such a one; as also ↓ fY Dibonatihi. (TA.) ― -b4- [The pl.] A^aDobaAnN signifies also (tropical:) The narrow places (maDaAyiq) of the jamal [an evident mistranscription for jabal i. e. mountain]. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Places abounding with beasts of prey: (K, TA:) sing. DibonN. (TA.) ― -b6- And AlD~ibonu signifies (assumed tropical:) That [place, or ground,] which renders people impotent, or helpless, to dig it. (K.)

DabanN *
Deficiency, or a falling short. (K, TA.)

makaAnN DabinN *
A narrow place. (S.)
DabonapN * and DubonapN: see what next follows.

DibonapN * and ↓ DabinapN (S, K) and ↓ DabonapN and ↓ DubonapN (K) The household, or family, (S, K, TA,) of a man, (S,) and [his] relations, or servants, or other dependents: (TA:) or the cattle, and household, or family, that are under one's authority, and which he minds, or to which he attends, and the maintenance whereof is incumbent on him. (IAth, TA.) And A travelling-companion, or travellingcompanions, in whom is no profit, or advantage, (K, TA,) being only such as he who travels with him, or them, has the burden of supporting. (TA.) -A2- See also DibonN.
DabinapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
DbAnp * [app. DibaAnapN, like biTaAnapN, which is one of its syns.,] A man's particular, or special, intimates, friends, or associates, and his aiders, or assistants, and kinsfolk. (TA.)
DabanoTFY * : see art. DbT. It is mentioned in the K and by Sgh both here and in art. DbT.

div2.head: Dbw or DbY
div2.entryFree:
1 Dabatohu Aln~aAru * , (S, M, K,) and Al$~amosu, (M,) aor.
1a2u3a , [or
1a2i3a ,] inf. n. DabowN, (S, K,) or DaboYN, (M,) or both, (IKtt, TA,) The fire, (S, M, K,) and the sun, (M,) altered [in colour], and roasted, broiled, or fried, him, or it: (S, K:) or burned, or scorched, him, or it. (M.) -A2- DabaA A_ilayohi He had recourse, or betook himself, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, or covert: (K:) a dial. var. of DabaA^a. (TA.)

4 ADbY *
i. q. A^amosaka: (M, K:) so in the phrase, ADbY Alr~ajulu EalaY maA fiY yadayohi [The man grasped, or kept hold of, that which was in his hands]: a dial. var. of A^aDobaA^a: (Lh, M:) like A^aDab~a. (TA in art. DbA^.) ― -b2- And ADbY Ealyohi He was, or became, at the point of gaining possession of it; (Ks, T, S, K;) namely, a thing. (Ks, S.) ― -b3- And He concealed it, and was silent respecting it. (IKtt, TA. [App. a dial. var. of A^aDobaA^a.]) -A2- And i. q. rafaEa [He raised; &c.]: so in the K: but in the Tekmileh waqaEa [he, or it, fell; &c.]. (TA.) -A3- And i. q. A^aDowaY [but in what sense is not shown]. (K.) -A4- ADbY bihimu Als~afaru The journey failed of fulfilling its promise to them in respect of what they hoped to obtain in it, of gain, and profit, or advantage. (El-Hejeree, M, K. *)

DaAbK *
Ashes. (S, K.)

maDobaApN * , (M, and thus in a copy of the S,) or miDobaApN, (thus in a copy of the S, [and Freytag states it to be thus accord. to IDrd, but accord. to the S to be DabaAwap, which is evidently a mistake,]) or muDobaApN, with damm, (K, and said in the TA to be thus written in copies of the S,) A cake of bread baked in hot ashes: (S, M, K:) thus called by some of the people of El-Yemen: but [ISd says, respecting maDobaApN as thus expl.,] I know not how this is unless the thing be named by the name of the place. (M.)
maDaAbK * [a pl. of which the sing. is most probably miDobFY] Frying-pans: like maDaAbiHu. (AHn, TA in art. DbH.)

1 Daj~a * , aor.
Daji3a , inf. n. DajiyjN (L, Msb, TA) and Daj~N and DajaAjN and DujaAjN, the last on the authority of Lh, (L, TA,) [and the last but one is said in one place in the L and TA to be a subst. from DaAj~ahu,] He cried out, or vociferated: (L:) or he cried out, or vociferated, calling for aid, or succour: (AA:) or he cried out, or vociferated, and raised a clamour, or confused cries or shouts or noises, being frightened at a thing: (Msb:) or DajiyjN signifies the crying out, or vociferating, on the occasion of some disagreeable occurrence, and in difficulty, or distress, and inability to bear what has befallen one, or impatience: (Kitáb el-Ghareebeyn:) or ↓ A^aDaj~uwA, inf. n. A_iDojaAjN, signifies they cried out, or vociferated, and raised a clamour, or confused cries or shouts or noises: and Daj~uwA, aor.
Daji3a , inf. n. DajiyjN, [as meaning they did so] when unable to bear a thing that had befallen them, or impatient, and overcome, (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA,) and frightened. (TA.) And one says also, Daj~a AlbaEiyru, (A, L,) inf. n. DjiyjN, (L,) [The camel uttered a cry, i. e. grumbled,] mina AlHimoli [in consequence of the load]. (A. [See 1 in art. rgw.]) And A_ino Daj~a fazidohu wiqorFA [If he grumble, add to him a load]: a prov. (A.) The poet El-Kanánee uses the phrase faDaj~aD~aj~apF for faDaj~ato Daj~apF; and it is cited by Sb as an ex. of the incorporation of t into D. (O.)
2 Dj~j * , inf. n. taDojiyjN, He went away: or he inclined, or declined. (O, K.) -A2- And He poisoned a bird, or a beast of prey. (O, K.)

3 DAj~hu * , (S, O,) inf. n. muDaAj~apN (S, O, K) and DijaAjN, (S, K,) He acted with him in an evil manner; treated him with enmity, or hostility; (S, O, K, TA;) and contended in altercation with him. (S, * O, * K, * TA.)
4 A^aDoja3a see 1. -A2- [Reiske, as mentioned by Freytag, explains ADj~ also as a trans. verb, meaning “ Fatigavit, molestia affecit. ”]
Daj~apN * , a subst., signifying A crying out, or vociferating: (L:) or a clamour, or confusion of cries or shouts or noises, of a people or party. (S, Msb.)

DajaAjN * a subst. from DaAj~ahu; [as such signifying Evil, or inimical, conduct; and contention:] (S, L, TA:) [and] compulsion. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Also] an inf. n. of 1, sometimes used as an epithet, [meaning That cries out, or vociferates, &c.,] applied to a man: pl. DujujN. (L.)
