[Freytag explains it, from the Deewán of Jereer, as meaning “ Vanus, nefas. ”] -A2- Also i. q. EaAjN [as meaning A kind of bracelet]; (T, O, K, TA;) which is like the siwaAr of a woman. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And A kind of bead (xarazapN), (O, K, TA,) used by women in their attracting [of men]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph.

DijaAjN *
A certain gum which is eaten (O, K, TA) in its moist state: when it has become dry, it is pounded, then formed into lumps, and made potent with potash, and one washed with it the garment, or piece of cloth, which it cleanses like soap. (O, TA.) And The fruit of a certain plant; or a gum; with which women wash their heads: written by IDrd with fet-h [i. e. ↓ DajaAjN], but by AHn with kesr. (TA.) ― -b2- And (as AHn says in one place, O, TA) Any tree with which birds, or beasts of prey, are poisoned. (O, K, TA.)
DajuwjN * A she-camel that cries out when being milked, and is impatient. (S, O, K.)
DajaAjN A^aDaj~u * , and, by poetic license A^aDojaju, [meaning Very evil or inimical conduct &c.,] is a phrase like $iEorN $aAEirN. (TA.)

1 Dajira * , aor.
Dajara , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. DajarN; (S, Mgh, Msb;) and ↓ tDj~r; (A, Mgh, Msb, K;) He was vexed, or disquieted by grief: (S:) or, followed by minohu, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and by bihi, (A, K,) he was vexed, or disquieted by grief, at it, or by reason of it, and by distress of mind, and complained: (Mgh:) or he was grieved at it, or by reason of it, (A, Msb,) and distressed in mind, (A,) or vexed, or disquieted, (Msb,) and complained: (A, Msb:) or he was disgusted (tabar~ama, A, K) at it, or by it, and was vexed, or disquieted, (K,) by grief. (TA.) ― -b2- And Dajira He (a camel) cried, or grumbled, much: (S:) and Dajirato she (a camel) cried, or grumbled, (A, K,) much, (A,) on being milked, (A, K,) being distressed thereby. (A.) In a verse, (of El-Akhtal, TA,) Dajira is contracted into Dajora; like as faxi*N, among nouns, is contracted [into faxo*N]. (S, TA.)

4 ADjrhu *
He caused him to be vexed, or disquieted by grief (S, Mgh) and by distress of mind, and to complain: (Mgh:) or he caused him to grieve, (minohu at it, or by reason of it,) and to be vexed, or disquieted, and to complain: (Msb:) or he caused him to be disgusted, and vexed, or disquieted, (K,) by grief. (TA.)
5 taDaj~ara see 1, first sentence.
DajorN * : see the next paragraph.

DajirN * A man vexed, or disquieted by grief: (S:) or grieved, (A, Msb,) and distressed in mind, (A,) or vexed, or disquieted, (Msb,) and complaining: (A, Msb:) or disgusted, (mutabar~imN, A, K,) and vexed, or disquieted, (K,) by grief: (TA:) and ↓ mutaDaj~irN signifies the same: (A:) and so, but in an intensive manner, ↓ DujarapN: (TA:) and ↓ DajuwrN is also an epithet [in this last, intensive, sense,] applied to a man: (S, Msb:) accord. to Aboo-Bekr, DajirN, signifying straitened, or distressed, in mind, is from the same word in the sense here next following. (TA.) ― -b2- A narrow place; (Aboo-Bekr, K;) as also ↓ DajorN. (K.)

DujorapN *
Grief, and distress of mind, with complaint: (A:) or disgust (tabar~umN, A, K) and vexation, or disquietude, (K,) arising from grief. (TA.) [SM supposes Z to have said that it is syn. with mutaDaj~irN: but this is a mistake.] -A2- Also A certain small bird: (AHát, O, K: *) as though [so called because], by reason of its disquietude, not remaining in one place. (TA.)
DujarapN * : see DajirN.

DajuwrN * : see DajirN. ― -b2- Also A she-camel that cries, or grumbles, (A, K,) much, (A,) on being milked, (A, K,) being distressed thereby. (A.) ― -b3- It is said in a prov., applied to a niggard from whom property is obtained by degrees, notwithstanding his nig-
gardliness, A_in~a AlD~ajuwra qado tuHolabu [Verily the she-camel that grumbles (or that grumbles much) on being milked is sometimes milked]. (A'Obeyd.)
muDojirN * act. part. n. of 4: pl. maDaAjiru and maDaAjiyru. (S, K.)
mutaDaj~irN * : see DajirN.

1 DajaEa * , aor.
DajaEa , inf. n. DajoEN and DujuwEN, [He lay upon his side; or] he laid his side upon the ground; [and simply he lay; and he slept;] as also ↓ AiDoTajaEa, (S, Msb, K, TA,) which is also expl. as syn. with naAma, [which has the second and third of the meanings mentioned above,] and with AisotaloqaY, [which has the third of those meanings,] (TA,) the T being substituted for the t of AiDotajaEa, (Lth, S, Msb,) and ↓ AiD~ajaEa, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ AiloTajaEa, (S, L, K, in the CK [erroneously] AT~ajaEa,) the D in ADTjE being changed into l, which is the letter nearest in sound thereto, because the combination of two such letters as D and T is disliked, (S, L,) the same change occurring in AiloTiraAdN for AiDoTiraAdN, (Az, TA,) though this change is anomalous; (L;) and ↓ A^aDojaEa likewise signifies the same as DajaEa; (Msb;) [and] so does ↓ AnDjE, (K, TA,) as quasi-pass. of the trans. verb ADjE. (TA.) ― -b2- [And accord. to Freytag, it occurs in the Deewán of the Hudhalees as signifying He declined from the way.] ― -b3- DajaEa Aln~ajomu means (tropical:) [The star, or asterism, or the Pleiades,] inclined to setting; as also ↓ Dj~E, (K, TA,) inf. n. taDojyEN. (TA.) And DajaEati Al$~amosu is a dial. var. of ↓ Dj~Et, (TA,) which means (tropical:) The sun approached the setting; (S, K, TA;) like Dar~aEat. (S, TA.) ― -b4- DajaEa fiY A^amorihi (tropical:) He was, or became, weak in his affair; as also ↓ ADjE; and so DajiEa, like fariHa [in measure], on the authority of IKtt. (TA. [See also 2, and 5, and 6.]) And DujiEa fiY raA^oyihi [not a mistranscription for DajiEa, as is shown by its part. n., q. v.,] (tropical:) He was, or became, weak in his judgment, or opinion. (TA.)

2 Daj~aEa see above, in two places. ― -b2- Dj~E fiY AlA^amori, (Mgh, K,) inf. n. taDojiyEN, (S,) (tropical:) He fell short of doing what was requisite, or due, in the affair; (S, Mgh, K, TA;) and was, or became, weak therein. (Mgh.) [See also DajaEa fiY A^amorihi, and see 5, and 6.] ― -b3- Hence, Alt~aDojiyEu fiY Aln~iy~api (assumed tropical:) The wavering, or vacillating, in intention, and not making it to take effect. (Mgh.)

3 DAjEhu * , (S, TA,) inf. n. muDaAjaEapN, He lay upon his side, or simply he lay, or slept, with him. (TA.) And DaAjaEahaA, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Msb,) He lay, or slept, with her, (Msb, TA,) namely, his girl, or young woman, (TA,) in, or on, one bed, (Msb,) or in one innermost garment. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, DAjEhu Alham~u (tropical:) Anxiety clave to him. (TA.)

4 A^aDojaEotuhu * , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iDojaAEN, (TA,) I laid him upon his side; (S, * Msb;) I laid his side upon the ground. (K.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) I lowered it, or depressed it, namely, a thing. (K, TA.) ― -b3- ADjE Alr~umoHu AlT~aEona (tropical:) [app. The spear made the thrusting to be in a downward direction]. (TA.) ― -b4- ADjE juwaAliqahu (assumed tropical:) He emptied his sack, it being full. (O, K.) ― -b5- AlA_iDojaAEu in relation to the vowel-sounds is (tropical:) like AlA_imaAlapu and AlxafoDu. (K, TA. [See arts. myl and xfD.]) -A2- See also 1, in two places.

5 tDj~E fiY AlA^amori * (tropical:) He held back in the affair, (S, K, TA,) and did not undertake it. (S, TA.) [See also 1, and 2, and 6.] ― -b2- And tDj~E Als~aHaAbu (tropical:) The clouds continued raining (A^arab~a) in the place. (S, K, TA.)
6 tDAjE Eano A^amori ka*aA waka*aA * (tropical:) He feigned himself unmindful, or heedless, of such and such an affair. (Z, TA.) [See also 1, and 2, and 5.]
7 A_inoDajaEa see 1, first sentence.

8 AiDoTajaEa * , and its vars. AiD~ajaEa and AiloTajaEa: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- AlAiDoTijaAEu fiY Als~ujuwdi is (tropical:) The not drawing up the body from the ground in prostration [in prayer]; (Mgh, TA;) the contracting oneself, and making the breast to cleave to the ground, therein. (K, TA.) [See also its part. n., below.]

DajoEN * [The species of glasswort, or kali, called] gaAsuwl, for [washing] clothes: n. un. with p: (K:) accord. to IDrd, the gum of a certain plant, or a certain plant [itself], with which clothes are washed: (O:) of the dial. of El-Yemen: (TA:) and, (O, K,) accord. to Ed-Deenawaree, (O,) i. e. AHn, (TA,) a certain plant, (K,) resembling small cucumbers, (O, K, TA,) [or] in shape like asparagus, (TA,) but thicker (O, K, TA) in a great degree, (O, TA,) four-sided in the stalks, (O, K, TA,) and having in it an acidity (O, TA,) and a bitterness (maraArap O) or a taste between sweet and sour (mazaAzap TA): it is crushed (yu$odaxu O) or cut into slices (y$rH TA) and its juice is expressed into milk such as is termed raAy^ib [q. v.], which in consequence becomes pleasant, (O, K, TA,) and somewhat biting to the tongue; and its leaves are put into sour milk, like as is done with the leaves of the mustard: (O, TA:) it is good as an aphrodisiac. (O, K, TA.)

DijoEN * (assumed tropical:) Inclination: (O, K:) so in the phrase DijoEu fulaAnK A_ilaY fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) [The inclination of such a one is towards such a one], (O,) or A_ilaY~a [towards me]. (K.)

DajoEapN *
A single act of lying, upon the side or otherwise, or of sleeping: (IAth, O, * TA:) a sleep. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) Weakness in judgment; (O, K, TA;) as also ↓ DujoEapN. (K.) One says, fiY raA^oyihi DajoEapN (tropical:) In his judgment is weakness. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) Ease; repose; freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; as also ↓ DujoEapN. (TA.)

DujoEapN *
One whom people often lay upon his side [or throw down]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [And app., One who lays others on the side, or prostrates them; as is implied by what here follows.] ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A disease: (K, TA:) because it lays the man upon his bed. (TA.) ― -b4- See also DajoEapN, in two places. ― -b5- And see DujaEapN.

DijoEapN *
A mode, or manner, of lying upon the side [or in any posture], (S, O, Msb, K,) or of sleeping. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Sluggishness, laziness, or indolence. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Also, for *aAtu DijoEapK, (assumed tropical:) A bed. (JM. [See also maDojaEN.]) It is said in a trad. that the DijoEap of the Apostle of God was of skins, (IAth, JM, TA,) stuffed with fibres of the palm-tree: (IAth, TA:) meaning his bed. (JM.)
DajaEapN * a gen. n. (O, K) in the sense of AiDoTijaAEN [i. e. The act of lying upon the side, or in any manner; and of sleeping]. (O.)

DujaEapN * , (S, O, K,) and, accord. to the K, ↓ DujoEapN, but this [as an epithet] has the meaning first assigned to it above, (TA,) and ↓ DujoEiy~apN and ↓ DijoEiy~apN and ↓ DujoEiY~N and ↓ DijoEiY~N, (O, K,) the last two [in the CK, erroneously, DuijoEaY, but] like quEodiY~N and qiEodiY~N, (O,) and ↓ DaAjEN, (K,) [or this last is a simple part. n.,] (tropical:) A man who lies upon his side [or in any manner, or sleeps,] much, or often: (S, O, K, TA:) sluggish, lazy, or indolent: (S and O in explanation of the first, and K in explanation of all:) or who keeps to the house or tent; seldom, or never, going forth; nor rising and speeding to do a generous deed: or impotent and stationary: (K, TA:) [or,] accord. to IB, ↓ DaAjiEN and ↓ DujoEiY~N and ↓ DijoEiY~N signify one who is content with his poverty, and betakes himself to his house or tent. (TA.)
DujoEiY~N * and DijoEiY~N: see each in two places in the next preceding paragraph.
DujoEiy~apN * and DijoEiy~apN: see DujaEapN.

DajuwEN * A water-skin (qirobapN) that makes the drawer of water to lean by reason of its heaviness. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- A wide dalow [or leathern bucket]; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) as also ↓ DaAjiEapN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A cloud (saHaAbapN) slow by reason of the abundance of its water. (IDrd, O, K, TA.) ― -b4- A well (biy^orN) hollowed in the sides, the water having eaten its interior. (AA, O, K. *) ― -b5- A she-camel that pastures aside. (A'Obeyd, O, K.) ― -b6- A wife contrarious to the husband. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K. [See also A^aDojaEu.]) ― -b7- And (tropical:) A man weak in judgment; (IDrd, O, K;) as also ↓ maDojuwEN. (K.)

DajiyEN * [A bedfellow]. DajiyEuka means He who lies, or sleeps, with thee; (S, O, Msb;) i. q. ↓ muDaAjiEuka; (K;) which latter is likewise applied to a female; as also DajiyEapN: and you say,
huwa DajiyEuhaA meaning He is he who lies, or sleeps, with her in one innermost garment; and hiYa DajiyEatuhu She is she who so lies, or sleeps, with him. (TA.) And [hence] one says, biy^osa AlD~ajiyEu AljuwEu (tropical:) [Very evil is the bedfellow, hunger]. (TA.)

DaAjiEN *
Lying upon his side [or in any manner; and sleeping; see its verb]; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ muDoTajiEN (TA) and ↓ muDojiEN. (Msb.) See also DujaEapN, in two places. ― -b2- (tropical:) Stupid, foolish, or unsound in intellect: (IAar, O, K, TA:) because of his impotence, and his cleaving to his place. (TA.) ― -b3- dalowN DaAjiEapN A leathern bucket that is full, (IAar, ISk, O, K,) so that it leans in rising from the well by reason of its heaviness. (ISk, O, K.) See also DajuwEN. ― -b4- And DaAjiEN (tropical:) A star inclining to setting: pl. DawaAjiEu: (O, K, TA:) [or] AlD~awaAjiEu signifies [or signifies also] the fixed stars. (Ham p. 364.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Inclining as in the saying A^araAka DaAjiEFA A_ilaY fulaAnK (tropical:) [I see thee inclining towards such a one]. (O, TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) A place of bending of a valley: pl. DawaAjiEu. (O, K.) ― -b7- Also, applied to a beast, (assumed tropical:) Worthless; in which is no good. (TA.) [But] ― -b8- ganamN DaAjiEapN means Numerous sheep or goats; as also ↓ DaHoEaA='u. (Fr, S, O, K.) ― -b9- And A_ibilN DaAjiEapN and DawaAjiEu (assumed tropical:) Camels keeping to the plants called HamoD; remaining among them. (TA.)

DaAjiEapN * as a subst. i. q. maSab~u waAdK; (AA, T, O, K, TA; [app. meaning The place where the water flows into it, of a valley; for] Az adds, in the T, as though it were a raHabap, [see raHabapu AlwaAdiY in art. rHb,] then, afterwards, it takes a straight direction, and becomes a valley (waAdK): pl. DawaAjiEu. (TA.) ― -b2- DawaAjiEu [which is like wise pl. of DaAjiEN] also signifies [Hills such as are called] hiDaAb [pl. of haDobapN]; (S, O, K;) and is said to have no sing. [in this sense]: occurring in a verse of En-Nábighah Edh-Dhubyánee: (S:) but ISk says that, in this instance, it is the name of a certain place. (O.)

A^aDojaEu Alv~anaAyaA * (tropical:) Having the central incisors inclining; (O, K, TA;) applied to a man: (O:) pl. DujoEN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^aDojaEu signifies also Contrarious to his wife. (O, K. [See also DajuwEN.]) ― -b3- For a meaning of its fem., DajoEaA='u, see DaAjiEN, last sentence but one.

maDojaEN *
A place in which, or on which, one lies upon his side [or in any manner, or sleeps]; (O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ muDoTajaEN: (O, K:) [a bed; and the like:] pl. maDaAjiEu: (Msb, TA:) which means sometimes places of sleep, or of passing the night: (Bd in iv. 38:) and beds; or other things spread upon the ground to lie upon. (Jel ibid., and Bd in xxxii. 16.) ― -b2- [Hence] the pl. is used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Wives, or women: so in the saying, huwa Tay~ibu AlmaDaAjiEi i. e. (assumed tropical:) He has well-born wives or women; like kariymu AlmafaAri$i. (TA.) ― -b3- And maDaAjiEu Algayovi means (tropical:) The places of falling of rain. (O, K, TA.) One says, baAtati Alr~iyaADu maDaAjiEa lilogayovi (tropical:) [The meadows were during the night places of the falling of rain]. (A, TA.)
muDojiEN * : see DaAjiEN, first sentence.
maDojuwEN * : see DajuwEN, last sentence. muDaAjiEN: see DajiyEN
muDoTajaEN * : see maDojaEN. ― -b2- It is also used as an inf. n. (Har p. 664.)

muDoTajaEN * : see DaAjiEN, first sentence. ― -b2- [It is said that] Sal~aY muDoTajiEFA means (tropical:) He prayed lying upon his right side, [or app., inclining towards that side,] facing the Kibleh. (TA. [But see 8.])

1 Dajima * , (MA, K,) aor.
Dajama , (K,) inf. n. DajamN, (MA, K, *) It was, or became, distorted, or crooked; said of the mouth; (MA, K;) and in like manner one says of the side of the mouth; and of the lip; and of the chin; and of the neck: (K:) and likewise, (tropical:) of a well: and (tropical:) of a wound. (K, TA.) [See DajamN below.]

6 tDAjm * [He was, or became, distorted, or crooked, in the mouth: (see its part. n., below:) and so, accord. to Golius, ↓ ADjm~ and ↓ ADjAm~. ― -b2- And] (tropical:) i. q. Aixotalafa: (S, K, TA:) so in the saying, taDaAjama AlA^amoru bayonahumo (tropical:) [The affair, or case, was, or became, complicated, intricate, or confused, so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference, between them]. (S, TA.) And hence the saying, AlA^asomaA='u taDaAjamu [for tataDaAjamu] i. e. taxotalifu [meaning (tropical:) Names are dissimilar, diverse, or various]. (TA.)
9 A_iDojam~a and 11: see the next preceding paragraph.

DajamN * inf. n. of Dajima [q. v.]: (MA, K: *) [as a simple subst.,] Distortion, or crookedness, (S, K,) [in an absolute sense; and particularly,] in the mouth; and in the side of the mouth; and in the lip; and in the chin; and in the neck: (K:) and in the nose; (Lth, TA;) its inclining towards one side (Lth, S, TA) of the face: (S, TA:) and in one of the shoulders: (S, TA:) and, accord. to the M, in the bill [for xT in the TA (an obvious mistranscription) I read xaTom] of the male ostrich: and sometimes in the mouth together with the nose: (TA:) and in like manner (tropical:) in a well: and (tropical:) in a wound. (K, TA.)

DujomapN *
A certain small creeping thing (duwayob~apN) of foul odour, (K, TA,) that stings, or bites. (TA.)

A^aDojamu *
Having the quality termed DajamN, expl. above: (K:) [or, particularly,] having the nose inclining towards one side of the face: (S:) [fem. DajomaA='u: and pl. DujomN.] And [hence] qaliybN A^aDojamu (assumed tropical:) A well having a crookedness in the wall that surrounds its interior: or that is not dug in a straight, or an even, direction: pl. qulubN DujomN. (TA.) El-'Ajjáj has applied the phrase qulubN DujomN to (tropical:) Wide wounds; as likened to the wells thus termed. (TA.) ― -b2- And [the pl.] DujomN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Men who eat much. (IAar, TA.)

mutaDaAjimN *
Distorted, or crooked, in the mouth, (S, K.)

R. Q. 1 DaHoDaHa * , [inf. n. DaHoDaHapN, which see below,] said of the saraAb [or mirage], It was, or became, in a state of commotion; or moved to and fro; as also ↓ taDaHoDaHa. (S, K.) ― -b2- And, (K, TA,) said of an affair, (TA,) It was, or became, manifest, evident, or apparent. (K, * TA.)

R. Q. 2
see the preceding paragraph.

DiH~N * The sun: (S, O, K:) and (K) the light of the sun, (Lth, A, O, K,) when it has possession of the ground: (Lth, O, TA:) or the light of the sun upon the surface of the ground; sunshine; contr. of Zil~N: (AHeyth, T, O, TA:) accord. to AHeyth, originally wiDoHN, the w being rejected and a H added to the radical H; but correctly, it is originally DiHoYN, from DHyt Al$ms [app. a mistranscription for DaHiytu lil$~amosi]: (TA; as from the T:) also land, or ground, that lies open and exposed (K, TA) to the sun: (TA:) and what is shone upon, or smitten, by the sun: (K, TA:) it has no pl. in any of these senses. (ElFihree, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yaqoEudan~a A^aHadukumo bayona AlD~iH~i waAlZ~il~i faA_in~ahu maqoEadu Al$~ayoTaAni (S, A) (tropical:) [None of you shall sit between the sunshine and the shade, for it is the sitting-place of the devil]; meaning half of him in the sun and half of him in the shade. (TA.) And one says, jaA='a fulaAnN biAlD~iH~i waAlr~iyHi (tropical:) Such a one came with, or brought, that upon which the sun had risen, and that upon which the wind had blown; (S, K, TA;) meaning, abundance, or much; (S, A;) or much property, or many cattle: (TA:) [F asserts that] one should not say bAlD~iyHi, (K,) i. e. biAlD~iyHi waAlr~iyHi: (TA:) this the vulgar say, but [J affirms that] it is nought: (S:) several, however, assert that AlD~iyH is correct: (MF:) [and the author of the K, who disallows it in this art., authorizes it in art. DyH, q. v.:] Kr, also, is related to have said that AlDiyHu signifies “ the sun ” and “ its light; ” and is said to signify “ what is exposed to the sun: ” and a poet says,
waAl$~amosu fiY All~uj~api *aAti AlD~iyHi
[And the sun in the abyss of sunlight]: Aboo-Mis-hal, moreover, mentions, in his “ Nawádir, ” the saying, AusotuEomila fulaAnN EalaY AlD~iyHi waAlr~iyHi [meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one was employed as manager of much property]. (TA.) maAta Eani AlD~iH~i waAlr~iyHi, occurring in a trad., is rendered agreeably with the explanation of the saying in a trad. mentioned above, and means (tropical:) He died leaving much property. (TA.) And it is said of the Prophet, in a trad., yakuwnu fiY AlD~iH~i waAlr~iyHi He will be exposed to the heat of the sun and the blowing of the winds; meaning, accord. to Hr, (assumed tropical:) he will be attended by, or in the midst of, numerous horsemen and military forces. (TA.)
DaHoDaHN * : see DaHoDaHapN: -A2- and DaHoDaAHN.
DuHoDuHN * : see what next follows.
DaHoDaHapN * and ↓ DaHoDaHN and ↓ DuHoDuHN The running of the saraAb [or mirage, along the surface of the ground, like water: see R. Q. 1]. (K.)

DaHoDaAHN *
Shallow water; (S, A, TA;) and hence metaphorically applied in a trad. to (tropical:) a shallow part of hell-fire: (TA:) or water little in quantity; as also ↓ DaHoDaHN: or water reaching to the ankles: or reaching to the middle of the skin: or in which there is no being drowned: (K:) or water little in quantity, in a pool left by a torrent, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- And Many, or much; in the dial. of Hudheyl; (AA, O, K;) not known to others: (TA: [see also DaHolN:]) accord. to As, it is applied to sheep or goats, and to camels, as meaning many, or numerous: and also as meaning scattered, or dispersed, over the surface of the land, but, notwithstanding, few. (TA.)

1 DaHika * , (S, MA, O, Msb, K, &c.,) and some say DiHikotu, with kesr to the D, (TA, as from the K, [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K,]) to agree with the vowel of the H because the latter is a faucial letter, and this is a correct dial. var. of which similar instances are mentioned, and DaHaka also is said to be a well known dial. var. of DaHika, (TA,) aor.
DaHaka , (S. O,) inf. n. DaHikN and DiHokN (S, MA, O, Msb, K, KL) and DaHokN, (S, MA, O, K, KL,) the first of which is the superior form, (IDrd, O,) [the second and third being contractions thereof,] and DiHikN, (S, O, K, KL,) and if you said DaHakN it would be agreeable with analogy, (Az, TA,) He laughed; (MA, KL, PS, TK;) contr. of bakaY: (TK:) [see also 6:] AlD~aHiku is well known, as meaning the expanding of the face, and displaying of the teeth, by reason of happiness, joy, or gladness; and Alt~abas~umu is the beginning thereof: thus in the Towsheeh and other works: (MF, TA:) and in like manner in the Mufradát [of Er-Rághib]; in which it is added that it is also used as meaning simply the being happy, joyful, or glad: and sometimes as meaning simply the wondering [at a thing]; and this is the meaning intended by him who says that it is peculiar to man: (TA:) [i. e.] DaHika, said of a man, signifies also he wondered; syn. Eajiba; (O, K, TA;) with mino preposed to the object of wonder: (TA:) or he was frightened; or he feared. (K, TA.) You say, DaHika minohu and bihi, both meaning the same, (S, O, Msb,) i. e. He laughed at him; derided him; or ridiculed him: or he wondered at him. (Msb.) And DaHika A_ilayohi [He behaved laughingly, or cheerfully, towards him]. (IDrd and K in art. b$ [See ba$~a lahu.]) ― -b2- Said of an ape, He uttered a cry or cries: (K:) or one says of the ape when he utters a cry or cries, yaDoHaku, (S, TA,) meaning he displays his teeth, or grins. (TA.) ― -b3- And DaHika Als~aHaAbu (tropical:) The clouds lightened. (S, O, K, TA.) Hence the usage of the verb in a trad. cited voce taHad~ava. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And DaHika Algadiyru i. e. (tropical:) [The pool of water left by a torrent] glistened by reason of its fulness. (TA.) ― -b5- [And DaHika vagoruhu (assumed tropical:) His front teeth, or his teeth, glistened by reason of his laughing; meaning he laughed so as to show his front teeth, or his teeth.] ― -b6- And DaHika Alz~ahoru (tropical:) The flowers [looked gay, or] were as though they were laughing. (TA.) And DaHikati AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The earth, or land, put forth its plants, or herbage, and its flowers. (TA.) And DaHikati Alr~iyaADu Eani AlA^azohaAri (tropical:) The meadows, or gardens, displayed the flowers. (TA.) ― -b7- And DaHikati Aln~axolapu (tropical:) The palm-tree put forth [or disclosed] its DaHok; as also ↓ A^aDoHakat; (TA;) [i. e.] the spathe of the palm-tree, (Skr, O, TA,) that covered the TaloE [or spadix], (O,) burst open. (Skr, O, TA.) And DaHika AlT~aloEu (tropical:) The TlE [here app. meaning the spathe of the palm-tree] split, or clave, open; and so tabas~ama. (TA.) ― -b8- And, as some assert, (ISd, TA,) DaHikato signifies also (tropical:) She menstruated; said of a hare; (ISd, Z, O, Msb, TA;) accord. to some, from the DaH~aAk [meaning the interior] of the TaloEap [of the palm-tree] when it bursts open; (ISd, TA;) and hence, (K, TA,) said also in this sense of a woman, (O, Msb, K, TA,) accord. to Mujáhid, (O, TA,) and some others, (TA,) in the Kur xi. 74, (O, K, TA,) where some read faDaHakato, which is said to be a well-known dial. var.; (TA;) and likewise, accord. to some, said in this sense of the hyena, (O, TA,) when she sees blood, or as IAar says, when she eats the flesh of men and drinks their blood: (TA:) [it is commonly asserted by the Arabs that] the hare menstruates like women: (Kzw:) but with respect to this meaning as assigned to the verb in the Kur xi. 74, Fr says that he had not heard it from any person deserving of confidence; (O, TA; *) and Zj says that it is nought: both say that the meaning there is, she laughed by reason of happiness: (TA:) and some say that there is an inversion in this case, what is meant being faba$~aronaAhaA biA_isoH`qa faDaHikato: (Fr, O, TA:) or the meaning is, she wondered; so says I'Ab; and so Er-Rághib, who adds that it is confirmed by her saying, “ shall I bring forth a child when I am an old woman, and this my husband is an old man? verily this is indeed a wonderful thing: ” and that faHaADato which is inserted by some of the expositors after faDaHikato is not an explanation of this expression, as some of them have imagined it to be, but is the mention of [a fact which was] a sign that the announcement was not that of an event improbable: or the meaning is, she was frightened; so says Fr.: (TA:) and with respect to the meaning of this verb when said of the hyena, mentioned above, it is rejected by AHát and others: (TA:) IDrd says, on the authority of AHát, respecting the following verse of TaäbbataSharrà,
taDoHaku AlD~aboEu liqatolaY hu*ayolK
wataraY Al*~iy^oba lahaA yasotahil~u
that the meaning is (assumed tropical:) The hyena displays her teeth, or grins, on account of the slain [of Hudheyl], when she sees them, like as they say of the ass when he plucks out the [plant called] Sil~iyaAnap; (O, TA;) or, as others say, (assumed tropical:) the hyena snarls, displaying her teeth; and sees the wolf raising his voice in calling the [other] wolves to them, i. e. to the slain: (O, TA:*) Abu-l-' Abbás says that the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) the hyena displays her teeth, because the wolf contends with her over the slain: and some say that the poet means, (assumed tropical:) the hyena rejoices because of the slain. (TA.) ― -b9- One says also, DaHikati Als~amurapu, meaning (assumed tropical:) The smrp [or gum-acacia-tree] flowed with its gum: from DHkt meaning “ she menstruated. ” (Bd in xi. 74.)

3 muDaAHakapN * [inf. n. of DAHkhu] signifies [The contending, or vying, in laughing, with another; or the laughing with another; or] the laughing together. (KL.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, Aln~aworu yuDaAHiku Al$~amosa (assumed tropical:) [The flowers vie in brightness with the sun]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A_in~a raA^oyaka layuDaAHiku Almu$okilaAti (tropical:) [Verily thy judgment makes sport with ambiguities]; said to him to whom confused and dubious things are apparent and known. (TA.)

4 ADHkhu * , (S, O, K,) inf. n. A_iDoHaAkN, (KL,) said of God, (S, O,) or of a man, (K,) He made him, or caused him, to laugh. (S, * O, * K, * KL, PS.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ADHk AlD~abuEa, said of blood, (TA,) or of the sword, (O, TA,) (assumed tropical:) [It made the hyena to display her teeth; or to snarl, displaying her teeth: or to rejoice: (see 1, latter part:) but explained as meaning] (tropical:) it made the hyena to menstruate. (TA.) ― -b3- And ADHk AlHawoDa (tropical:) He filled the wateringtrough so that it overflowed: (O, TA:) its glistening being likened to laughing. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, near the middle of the paragraph.
5 taDaH~aka see the next paragraph.

6 tDAHk * and ↓ tDH~k [are both mentioned in the K and TA as though syn. with each other and with DaHika: and accord. to the KL, the former signifies He laughed: but accord. to the TK, the latter signifies he manifested laughing: or] the former is syn. with ↓ AstDHk [app. as meaning he affected to laugh, or laughing: or, more exactly, agreeably with analogy, like the contr. tabaAkaY and AisotabokaY, the former signifies thus; and the latter, he desired to laugh]. (S.) ― -b2- And you say also, humo yataDaAHakuwna [meaning They laugh together, one with another]. (K.)
10 A_isotaDoHaka see the next preceding paragraph.

DaHokN * [originally an inf. n., a contraction of DaHikN,] The appearance, or appearing, of the central incisors [or of the front teeth] by reason of happiness, joy, or gladness. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) Wonder. (K, TA.) -A2- [As an epithet,] A man whose teeth are white. (As, O, TA.) -A3- [And as a subst., properly so termed,]
White front teeth. (As, O, K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Honey: (K:) or white honey; (Ibn-Es-Seed, TA;) likened to the front teeth because of its intense whiteness: (AA, O, TA:) or honey in its comb; syn. $ahodN. (K.) ― -b3- And, (O, K,) some say, (O,) (assumed tropical:) Fresh butter. (O, K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Snow. (O, K.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Blossoms, or flowers, or white blossoms or flowers; syn. naworN: (O, and so in copies of the K:) or light; syn. nuwrN. (So in a copy of the K.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The TaloE [or spadix] of the palm-tree when its envelope bursts open from it; (S, * O, * K;) in the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab: (O:) accord. to Th, what is in the interior of the TaloEap [here meaning spathe of the palm-tree]: as AA says, the waliyEap, or waliyE [thus differently written in two different places in the TA,] of the TaloE [or spathe of the palm-tree], which is eaten; as also ↓ DaH~aAkN. (TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) The middle of a road; (K, TA;) and so, accord. to the K, ↓ DaH~aAkN; but, correctly, this should have been there mentioned as syn. with DaHokN in the sense next preceding. (TA.)

DaHokapN *
A single act of DaHik [or laughing; i. e. a laugh]. (S, O.) -A2- [The pl.] DaHokaAtN signifies (tropical:) The best of everything: and DaHokaAtu Alquluwbi, the best of possessions, or wealth, and of children: so says Aboo-Sa'eed. (TA.)

DuHokapN * A thing, (Lth, TA,) or a man, (S, O. TA,) that is laughed at, or ridiculed; i. e. yuDoHaku minohu: (S, O, K, TA:) an epithet importing more discommendation than DuHakapN. (K.) ― -b2- See also maDoHakN.

DuHakapN * , (S, O, Msb, K,) an epithet importing discommendation, (K,) and ↓ DuHuk~apN, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) and ↓ DaH~aAkN, (Msb, K,) an epithet importing commendation, (TA, [but the contr. is implied, or rather plainly indicated, in the K,]) and ↓ DaHuwkN, (K,) and ↓ miDoHaAkN, (S, O, K,) which last is [also] applied to a woman, (S, O,) One who laughs much (kaviyru AlD~aHiki). (S, O, Msb, K.)
DuHuk~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

DaHuwkN * : see DuHakapN. ― -b2- [Also] A man cheerful in countenance. (O.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A wide road: (S, O:) or (tropical:) a distinct, an apparent, or a conspicuous, road; as also ↓ DaH~aAkN: pl. of the former (in this sense, TA) DuHokN. (K, TA.)
DaH~aAkN * : see DuHakapN: ― -b2- and see DaHokN, last two sentences: ― -b3- and DaHuwkN.

DaAHikN *
Laughing; [&c.;] (KL;) act. part. n. of DaHika. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also applied to clouds (saHaAb), meaning (tropical:) Appearing, or extending sideways, in the horizon, and lightening. (S, O, TA.) ― -b3- [And to the tooth (Als~in~, used as a gen. n.): thus in the phrase DaAHika Als~in~i, meaning (assumed tropical:) Laughingly, so as to display the teeth.] ― -b4- See also DaAHikapN. ― -b5- Also, [or perhaps HajarN DaAHikN,] (tropical:) Very white stone appearing in a mountain (IDrd, O, TA.) of any colour, as though laughing. (IDrd, O, TA.) ― -b6- One says also raA^oYN DaAHikN, meaning (tropical:) Judgment that is plain, or perspicuous, (TA,) not confused or dubious. (O, TA.) ― -b7- And, [using DAHk as a gen. n.,] maA A^akovara DaAHika naxolikumo (tropical:) [How numerous are the bursting spathes of your palm-trees!]. (TA.) ― -b8- [And an instance of DaAHikN applied to a woman, without p, meaning (assumed tropical:) Menstruating, is cited by Bd, in xi. 74.]

DaAHikapN * , (S, O, K,) or ↓ DaAHikN, (Msb,) or both, (Mgh,) (tropical:) The tooth next behind the naAb [or canine tooth]; (Mgh, Msb;) [i. e. the anterior bicuspid;] any one of the four teeth that are between the A^anoyaAb and the A^aDoraAs: (S, O, K:) or any one of the teeth that are in front of the A^aDoraAs that appear on the occasion of laughing: (K:) pl. DawaAHiku. (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K.) A^awDaHuwA biDaAHikapK (O, TA,) a phrase occurring in a trad., (O,) means (assumed tropical:) They smiled. (TA.)

A^uDoHuwkapN * [A laughable thing;] a thing at which one laughs: (O, K, TA:) and ↓ maDoHakapN signifies [in like manner a cause of laughter;] a thing at which one laughs, or which one ridicules: pl. of the former A^aDaAHiyku. (TA.) [See also muDoHikaAtN.]

[
maDoHakN * lit. A place of laughing: the front teeth; because they appear in laughing; like mabosimN: pl. maDaAHiku.] One says, badato maDaAHikuhu and ↓ DuHokatuhu and [in like manner] mabaAsimuhu (assumed tropical:) [His front teeth appeared, by his laughing]. (TA.)
maDoHakapN * : see A^uDoHuwkapN.
muDoHikaAtN * [pl. of muDoHikapN] i. q. nawaAdiru [as meaning Extraordinary things or sayings, particularly such as cause laughter: see also A^uDoHuwkapN]. (TA.)
miDoHaAkN * : see DuHakapN.

1 DaHala * , (O, K,) aor.
DaHala , (K,) said of water, It was, or became, shallow, (O, K, TA,) and little in quantity. (TA.) And said of a pool of water left by a torrent, Its water became little in quantity. (K.)
4 maA A^aDoHala xayoraka * means maA A^aqal~ahu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) How little, or scanty, is thy goodness, or bounty, or beneficence!]. (TA.)

Q. Q. 4 AiDomaHal~a * , (S, O, K,) mentioned in the K in a separate art., its author, and some others, holding the m to be radical, but most of the leading authorities on inflection hold it, with J [and Sgh and Fei], to be augmentative; (TA;) and AimoDaHal~a, (S, O, Msb, K,) of the dial. of the Kilá- bees, mentioned by AZ, formed by transposition of the m; (S, O, TA;) and AimoDaHan~a, (K,) formed by substitution, mentioned by Yaakoob; (TA;) It (a thing, S, O) went away; (S, O, Msb, K;) and came to nought. (Msb.) ― -b2- And said of clouds (saHaAb), They became removed, or cleared off. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b3- And i. q. AinoHal~a [It became untied, or undone, &c.]. (K.)

DaHolN *
A small quantity of water, (S, M, O, K,) upon the ground, (M, K,) shallow, (M,) not deep; (K;) i. q. DaHoDaAHN; (S, O;) or the latter has a more general meaning, applying to little or much: (TA:) accord. to some, such that the bottom of it appears: (MF, TA:) or a small quantity of water in a source, or fountain, and in a well, and in a hot spring, and the like; or in a pool left by a torrent, and the like: or water little in quantity; or near in place: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aDoHaAlN and [of mult.] DuHuwlN and DiHaAlN. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, O,) A^ataAnu AlD~aHoli (S, O, K) i. e. A mass of rock of which part is covered by the water and part is protruding; (O;) expl. [more fully and variously] in art. Atn; (K;) so called because the water does not cover it by reason of its paucity. (S, O.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] one says, A_in~a xayoraka laDaHolN i. e. [(assumed tropical:) Verily thy goodness, or bounty, or beneficence, is] little. (TA.)

gadiyrN DaAHilN *
A pool, left by a torrent, the water of which has become shallow and has then gone away. (Sh, TA.)

maDoHalN * The place of a DaHol: (M, TA:) or a place in which is little water: (O, K:) the mirage (saraAb) is likened thereto: (TA:) pl. maDaAHilu; (O, TA;) to which Ru-beh, (O,) or El-'Ajjáj, (TA,) likens clouds. (O, * TA.)

div2.head: DHw and DHY
div2.entryFree:
1 DaHaA AlT~ariyqu * , (S, K,) aor. yaDoHuw, (S,) inf. n. DaHowN, (S, and so in the CK,) or DuHuw~N, (so in other copies of the K and in the TA,) like Euluw~N, thus accord. to ISd and IKtt, (TA,) and DuHiY~N, (TA as from the K, [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K,]) The road appeared, or became apparent, (S, K,) to a person: so says AZ: (S:) [and so, app., signifies DaHiYa, aor. yaDoHaY; for] As says, yusotaHab~u mina Alfarasi A^ano yaDoHaY EijaAnuhu i. e. [It is approved as a quality of the horse] that his EjAn [q. v., a word variously expl.,] appear. (S, TA.) ― -b2- DaHiyati All~yolapu The night was, or became, cloudless. (TA.) ― -b3- DaHiYa Alfarasa The horse was, or became, white. (TA.) ― -b4- Zil~uhu DaHaA (tropical:) He died: (K, TA:) it [properly] means his shade, or shadow, became sun: and when a man's shade, or shadow, becomes sun, he himself becomes nought. (IAmb, TA.) ― -b5- And DaHaA and DaHiYa, aor. of each yaDoHaY, inf. n. DaHowN, (K, TA,) or, accord. to the M, DuHuw~N, (TA,) and DuHiY~N, He, or it, was smitten by the sun; or the sun came, or fell, upon him, or it: (K, TA:) or DaHiYa, aor. yaDoHaY, inf. n. DaHFA; and DaHaA, aor. yaDoHuw, inf. n. DaHowN and DuHuw~N, he, or it, was smitten by the heat of the sun. (Ham p. 625.) Hence, in the Kur [xx. 117], laA taZomaA^u fiyhaA walaA taDoHaY [Thou shalt not thirst. therein nor shalt thou be smitten by the sun]; i. e., thou shalt be preserved from the heat of the sun. (TA.) ― -b6- And DaHaA, inf. n. DaHowN and DuHuw~N
and DuHiY~N, He went forth to the sunshine; (K;) as also lil$~amosi ↓ AstDHY; (TA;) [and app. ↓ tDH~Y also; see Har p. 296, where, for Alnzwl, in Alnzwl ll$ms as an explanation of Alt~aDaH~iY, I think we should read Alburuwzu:] or DaHiytu lil$~amosi, inf. n. DaHaA='N; and DaHayotu also; aor. of each A^aDoHaY; I went forth to the sunshine. (S.) A^aDoHi [the imperative of ↓ A^aDoHaY] occurs in a trad., accord. to the relaters thereof: but As says that it is [correctly] AiDoHa, with kesr to the A and fet-h to the H; from DaHiytu; being a command to go forth to the sunshine. (S.) ― -b7- And DaHiYa, (S, K,) inf. n. DaHFY [or DaHFA], He (a man, S) sweated. (S, K.)

2 DaH~ayonaAhumo * is like Sab~aHonaAhumo [i. e. it signifies We came to them in the time of the morning called AlD~uHaY]: (TA:) and ↓ DAHAhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. muDaAHaApN, is similar to gaAdaAhu and raAwaHahu, meaning, (TA,) He came to him in the time called AlD~uHaY. (K, TA.) ― -b2- DH~Y Alganama He pastured the sheep, or goats, in the time called AlD~uHaY; (S, K, TA;) and in like manner, AlA_ibila the camels. (TA.) And DaH~ayotu AlA_ibila Eani Alwirodi I pastured the camels with the [morning-pasture called] ↓ DaHaA=', so that they might come to the water having satisfied themselves with food: and in like manner, Ea$~ayotuhaA Eanohu “ I pastured them with the [evening-pasture called] Ea$aA=', ” &c. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] DaH~ayotuhu, inf. n. taDoHiyapN, I fed him in the time called AlD~uHaY: (K, TA:) or I fed him with the [morning-meal called] gadaA=', at any time [of the morning]; but more commonly known as meaning, in the time called AlD~uHaY: and the verb primarily relates to camels [and sheep or goats]: or DH~Y qawomahu means he fed his people, or party, with the [morning-meal called] gadaA='; or he invited them [thereto, i. e.] to his DaHaA='. (TA.) ― -b4- IAth says, when the Arabs, in their journeying, or migrating, passed by a piece of land in which was herbage, one of them said, A^alaA DaH~uwA ruwayodFA, meaning [Now] be ye gentle with the camels ↓ Hat~aY nataDaH~aY i. e. in order that we may obtain of this herbage; then Alt~aDoHiyapu was applied to mean the being gentle in order that the camels may reach the place of alighting [app. in the morning] having satisfied themselves with food: and then ↓ taDaH~aY was said of anyone as meaning he ate in the time called [AlD~uHaY or] AlD~aHaA='. (TA.) One says, DaH~ayotu Eani Al$~aYo'i (assumed tropical:) I was gentle, or I acted gently, with the thing. (S.) And DH~Y Eani AlA^amori (tropical:) He acted gently, or deliberately, in the affair: and so Ea$~aY Eanohu. (A, TA.) And DaH~i ruwayodFA, (S, A, TA,) a prov., (A, TA,) meaning (tropical:) Hasten thou not; (S, TA;) from taDoHiyapu AlA_ibili Eani Alwirodi: [see the third sentence of this paragraph:] or meaning be thou patient a little while: (TA:) or the meaning is, slaughter thou, or sacrifice thou, [deliberately, leisurely, or] without haste: (Meyd:) [for] ― -b5- DH~Y, inf. n. taDoHyapN, signifies [also] He slaughtered, or sacrificed, the [victim termed] A^uDoHiy~ap, in the time called AlD~uHaY: and hence, by reason of frequency of usage, he did so in any time of what are termed A^ay~aAmu Alt~a$oriyqi: (Msb:) and DH~Y bi$aApK, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or bikabo$K A^awo gayorihi, (Mgh,) he slaughtered, or sacrificed, a sheep or goat, (S, Msb, K,) or a ram or other [victim], (Mgh,) in the time called AlD~uHaY (Mgh, K) of the day called yawomu AlA^aDoHaY; and afterwards said of him who has done so [at any time, even] in the last part of the [said] day. (Mgh.) -A2- See also 4. -A3- And see 5.

3 DAHt Albiladu *
The countries, or lands, became exposed to the sun, and their herbage consequently dried up. (TA.) -A2- DAHAhu: see 2, first sentence.

4 ADHY *
He (a man, TA) entered upon the time of morning called AlD~uHaY, (K, * TA,) or the time called AlD~aHowap, (TA,) [or the time called AlD~aHaA=', for] you say, A^aqamotu biAlmakaAni Hat~aY A^aDoHayotu, from AlD~aHaA='u [and therefore meaning I remained in the place until I entered upon the time called AlD~aHaA='], like as you say A^aSobaHotu from AlS~abaAHu. (S, TA.) Hence the saying of 'Omar, A^aDoHuwA liSalaApi AlD~uHaY, (S,) or biSalaApi AlD~uHaY, (TA,) i. e. Perform ye the prayer of the time called AlDHY at its [proper] time: do not delay it until the time called AlD~aHaA=' has become advanced: (TA:) or do not perform that prayer when the time called AlD~uHaY has become advanced. (S.) ― -b2- And you say, ADHY fulaAnN yafoEalu ka*aA, (S, M, K,) like as you say Zal~a yfEl k*A; (S;) meaning Such a one became occupied, or engaged, in the time called AlD~uHaY in doing such a thing: (M, K, TA:) or did such a thing in the first part of the day, (IKtt, TA.) ― -b3- [This phrase often means also Such a one became occupied, or engaged, in doing such a thing; betook, set, or applied, himself to doing such a thing; set about, or commenced, doing such a thing; or began to do such a thing; like A^aSobaHa and Zal~a &c. And, like these verbs, ADHY followed by an aor., or by a part. n. in the accus. case, often requires to be rendered simply He, or it, became: see an ex. in a verse cited voce dafiy^N.] ― -b4- ADHY also signifies He performed the supererogatory act of prayer (Aln~aAfilap) in the time called AlD~uHaY. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 1, last sentence but one. ― -b6- One says also, ADHY Eani AlA^amori, meaning (tropical:) He withdrew himself far from the affair. (TA. [See also another meaning of this phrase in what follows.]) And AlqaTA yuDoHiY Eani AlmaA='i (tropical:) The birds called qTA go far from water. (TA.) -A2- ADHY Al$~aYo'a He made apparent, showed, or revealed, the thing. (K, TA.) And Eani AlA^amori ↓ DH~Y He made the affair, or case, apparent, or manifest: and [so ADHY Eanohu, for] one says, A^aDoHi liY Eano A^amorika, with fet-h to the ', meaning Make manifest to me thy affair, or case: so in the M. (TA.) ― -b2- laA A^aDoHaY A@ll~`hu lanaA Zil~aka is a deprecatory phrase [lit. May God not cause thy shadow to become sun to us: meaning (assumed tropical:) may God not deprive us of thee by death: (see DaHaA Zil~uhu:) or it may be similar in meaning to the phrase here following]. (TA.) laA tuDoHinaA Eano Zil~ika [lit. Make us not to go forth into the sun from thy shadow] means (assumed tropical:) withdraw not from us the shadow of thy compassion: the verb being made trans. by means of En because the phrase implies the meaning of laA tuxorijonaA minohu: and Zl~ being here used metaphorically. (Har p. 4.)

5 taDH~Y * : see 1, latter half. ― -b2- And see 2, in two places. It [generally] means He ate in the time of morning called AlD~uHaY: (K:) or he ate the [morning-meal called] gadaA='; syn. tagad~aY: (S, TA:) and ↓ DH~Y also has the former [or the latter] meaning. (ISd, TA.)
10 A_isota1o2a3a see 1, latter half.
DaHowN * : see the next paragraph.

DuHFY * , also written DuHFA, held by some to be of the measure fuEalN, and by others to be [originally DuHowFY i. e.] of the measure fuEolFY, of the former measure accord. to Mbr, and of the latter accord. to Th, (MF, TA,) [The early part of the forenoon, after sunrise: accord. to some, when the sun is yet low: accord. to others, when the sun is somewhat high:] i. q. ↓ DaHowapN, accord. to most authorities: (MF, TA, and so in one place in the K:) or this latter signifies the period of the day after sunrise: (S:) or this signifies the advanced state of the day (AirotifaAEu Aln~ahaAri [which is said by the doctors of the law in the present day to mean when the sun has risen the measure of a rumoH, q. v., or more]); as also ↓ DaHowN and ↓ DaHiy~apN: (K:) and the DuHaY is after the DaHowap (S, K) a little, (K,) when the sun shines brightly: (S:) or from sunrise to the time when the day is advanced and very white: thus in the M: (TA:) or it is the spreading of the sun [upon the earth], and the extending of the day: and the time [thereof] is thus named: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or DuHFY is pl. of ↓ DaHowapN, like as qurFY is of qaroyapN; and its sing. is like ↓ DaHaA='N, which means the extending of the day, and is of the masc. gender, as though a name of the time [thereof]: then DuHFY became used as a sing., and the time was thus called: (Msb:) it is fem. and masc.: (S, K: *) he who makes it fem. holds it to be pl. of ↓ DaHowapN; and he who makes it masc. holds it to be [a sing.] noun of the measure fuEalN, like SuradN and nugarN: (S:) its dim. is ↓DuHaY~N, without p; (Fr, Msb, K;) for they disapproved the affixing the p lest it should be confounded with the dim. of DaHowapN. (Fr, Msb.) Using it as an adv. noun, you say, laqiytuhu DuHaY, when you mean [I met him] in the DHY of this day; without tenween. (S, TA.) See also DaHowapN. [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 162-167, respecting the prayer that is performed in the time thus called,
i. e. the prayer termed SalaApu AlD~uHaY, mentioned above, voce A^aDoHaY.] ― -b2- Also The sun: (M, Msb, K:) because of its appearing in the time thus called. (M, TA.) One says, AirotafaEati AlD~aHaY, meaning The sun became high. (Msb.) ― -b3- And DuHaY Al$~amosi The light of the sun: thus is expl. xci. 1. of the Kur. (TA.) ― -b4- maA likalaAmihi DuHFY means (assumed tropical:) His speech, or language, has no perspicuity: thus in the M and K: but in the A, ↓ A^ano$adaniY $aEorFA layosa fiyhi HalaAwapN walaA DaHaA='N i. e. [He recited to me poetry] in which was no [sweetness nor] plainness of meaning. (TA.)

DaHowapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. You say, A^atayotuka DaHowapF, meaning [I came to thee] in a [time called] ↓ DuHFY [or rather DaHowap], (K, * TA,) with tenween, unless you mean of this day [in which case you say DaHowapN, without tenween, like as you say in the latter case DuHaY]. (TA.)
DaHoyaA * and DaHoyaA='u fems. of A^aDoHaY [q. v.].

DaHoyaAnN * , which should by rule be DaHowaAnN, Anything exposing itself, or being exposed, to the sun. (IJ, TA.) qul~apN DaHoyaAnapN means [A mountain-top] exposed to the sun: (S, K:) occurring in a saying of Taäbbata-sharrà. (S.) And EaSFA DaHoyaAnapN A staff, or stick, growing in the sun so as to be matured thereby, and extremely hard. (TA.) ― -b2- See also A^aDoHaY. ― -b3- Also A man who eats in the time called AlD~uHaY: fem. with p. (K.)

DaHaA='N * , with medd, (S, Hr, Msb, TA,) and fet-h, (Hr, Msb, TA, [erroneously written in copies of the K with damm,]) The period [of the forenoon] next after that called AlD~uHaY; i. e. when the day is at the highest: (S:) or the period near midday: (K:) or the period of the day when the sun has risen to the fourth part of the sky: (TA:) see also DuHFY, in two places. ― -b2- And hence, The [morning-meal called] gadaA='; because it is eaten in the time thus called. (S, TA.) [And also applied to Pasture eaten in that time:] see 2, third sentence.
DuHaY~N * dim. of DuHFY, q. v. (Fr, Msb, K.)
DaHiy~apN * : see DuHFY: -A2- and see also A^uDoHiy~apN.

DaAHK * [part. n. of 1, Appearing, &c.] ― -b2- You say makaAnN DAHK An outer, exterior, or exposed, place: (S:) and A^aroDN DaAHiyapN Land not surrounded by a wall. (TA in art. HwT.) [And particularly A place exposed to the sun.] ― -b3- [Hence,] mafaAzapN DaAHiyapu AlZ~il~i [A desert, or waterless desert,] having no shade or shadow; and DaAHiyapu AlZ~ilaAli [having no shades or shadows]. (TA.) And $ajarapN DaAHiyapN biAlZ~il~i [if not a mistake for DaAHiyapu AlZ~il~i] A tree having no shade. (Har p. 4.] ― -b4- And badaA biDaAHiY raA^osihi [He appeared with, or he showed,] the side of his head. (TA.) [See also the next paragraph.]

DaAHiyapN *
An outer, exterior, or exposed, side or region or tract of anything: [pl. DawaAHK: whence] one says, humo yanoziluwna AlD~awaAHiYa [They alight, or abide, in the exterior tracts]. (S.) [Hence also,] DawaAHiY Alr~uwmi The exterior districts of the Greeks. (K.) And AlD~aAHiyapu mina AlbaEoli What are in the open country, of the palm-trees that imbibe with their roots, without being watered: opposed to AlD~aAminapu mina Aln~axoli: (AO, S in this art. and in art. Dmn, q. v.:) and AlD~awaAHiY mina Aln~axoli what are outside of the town-wall, of the palm-trees: thus used, AlDwAHY is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (TA.) And DawaAHiY qurayo$K Those [of Kureysh] who abide outside of Mekkeh. (TA.) And huwa mino A^aholi AlD~aAHiyapi He is of the people of the desert. (TA.) AlD~awaAHiY also signifies The parts, of a man, that stand out, or are exposed, (K, TA,) to the sun, (TA,) such as the shoulder-blades, and the shoulders: (K, TA:) pl. of DaAHiyapN. (TA.) And The sides of a watering-trough. (K.) And The heavens. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] faEalahu DaAHiyapF He did it openly. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- DaAHiyapu AlmaAli means The cattle, (K,) or sheep or goats, (TA,) that drink in the time of morning called DuHFY. (K, TA.)

A^aDoHaY * , applied to a horse, i. q. A^a$ohabu [Of a colour in which whiteness predominates over blackness; &c.]: fem. DaHoyaA='u: (S, K:) or AlD~aHoyaA='u was, (K,) or was also, (S, and so afterwards in the K,) the name of a certain mare, belonging to 'Amr Ibn-'Ámir (S, K) Ibn-Rabee'ah. (S.) ― -b2- And layolapN DaHoyaA='u, (S, K,) and DaHoyaA with the short A, both mentioned by ISd, (TA,) and ↓ A_iDoHiyaAnapN, (S, K,) and ↓ A_iDoHiyapN accord. to the K, but [SM says] I have not found any mention of this last, [meaning except in the K,] and probably the right word is ↓ A_iDHiyaAnN, as in the books of strange words together with A_iDoHiyaAnapN, and accord. to the “ Irtisháf ed-Darab ” of AHei one says [also] ↓ A^aDoHiyaAnN with fet-h, (TA,) A bright night, (S, K, TA,) in which are no clouds: (S, TA:) and in like manner, ↓ yawomN A_iDoHiyaAnN, in the K, erroneously, DaHoyaApN, a bright day, in which are no clouds, as in the M; or bright with the brightness of the DuHaY, accord. to Er-Rághib; or [simply] bright, and so ↓ DaHoyaAnN, which is likewise applied in this sense to a moon, as also ↓ A_iDoHiyaAnN, and to a lamp, or its lighted wick. (TA.) ― -b3- And AimoraA^apN DaHoyaA='u A woman whose hair of her EaAnap will not grow forth; (K, TA;) as though her EAnp, being bare of hair, had no shade upon it. (TA.) -A2- maA A^adoriY A^aY~u AlD~aHoyaA='i huwa is a saying mentioned by Az in art. ThY as meaning I know not what one of mankind, or of the people, he is. (TA.) -A3- A^aDoHFY [a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is A^aDoHaApN]: see A^uDoHiy~apN. Hence, yawomu AlA^aDoHaY [The day of the victims; which is the tenth of Dhu-l- Hijjeh]; (S, Mgh, K, * TA;) so says Yaakoob; (TA;) or Eiydu AlA^aDoHaY [the festival of the victims]: (Msb:) and by AlA^aDoHaY when it is made masc. is meant that day. (Fr, S, Msb.)
A_iDoHiyapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A_iDoHiyaAnN * and A^aDoHiyaAnN, and the former with p: see A^aDoHaY, in five places. ― -b2- AlA_iDoHiyaAnu is also the name of A certain plant, (K, TA,) resembling the A^uqoHuwaAn [or chamomile] in appearance. (TA.)

A^uDoHiy~apN * , (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the measure A^ufoEuwlapN [as though originally A^uDoHuwyapN], (Msb,) and A_iDoHiy~apN, (As, S, Msb, K,) pl. [of each] A^aDAHiY~u; and ↓ DaHiy~apN, of which the pl. is DaHaAyaA; and A^aDoHaApN, of which the pl. is ↓ A^aDoHFY, (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K, [in copies of the K and in my copy of the Mgh written A^aDoHaY, but it is properly speaking a coll. gen. n. of which A^aDoHaApN is the n. un., and is therefore with tenween,]) like A^aroTaApN and A^aroTFY; (As, S, Mgh, Msb; *) A sheep or goat (S, K, KL) &c. [i. e. meaning also a camel and a bull or cow] (KL) that is slaughtered, or sacrificed, (S, K, KL,) in the time called AlD~uHaY, (K,) on the day called yawomu AlA^aDoHaY [the day of the victims, which is the tenth of Dhu-l-Hijjeh]. (S, K, * KL.)

A^aroDN maDoHaApN *
A land from which the sun is hardly, or never, absent; (K, TA;) i. e. an exposed land. (TA.)
muDoTaHK * and ↓ mutaDaH~K and ↓ musotaDoHK A man entering upon the time of morning called AlD~uHaY. (K, * TA.)
mutaDaH~K * : see what next precedes.
musotaDoHK * : see what next precedes.

1 Daxuma * , [aor.
Daxuma ,] (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. DixamN, (S, Msb, TA,) accord. to the copies of the K DaxomN, but this is wrong, (TA,) and DaxaAmapN, (S, Msb, K,) It, or he, was, or became, large, big, bulky, (S, * Msb, K,) or thick: (S:) or large in body, portly, or corpulent, and fleshy. (K.)
4 ADxm lahu * (Ibn-'Abbád and K * voce A^adolafa) [i. q. A^agolaZa lahu] (assumed tropical:) He spoke to him in a rough, harsh, coarse, rude, uncivil, or ungentle, manner. (TK in art. dlf.)

DaxomN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ DaxamN (K) and ↓ DuxaAmN (S, K) and ↓ A^aDoxamu, (K,) which last is also with teshdeed of the final letter, (S, K,) i. e. ↓ A^Doxam~u, in poetry, (S, TA,) for there is no word [properly] of the measure A^afoEal~u, and IJ mentions ↓ A_iDoxam~N, [evidently in the same sense,] like A_irodab~N [in measure], (TA,) Large, big, bulky, (S, * Msb, K,) or thick; (S;) applied to a thing (Msb, K) of any kind: (K:) or large in body, portly, or corpulent, and fleshy: (K:) pl. DxaAmN; (S, Msb;) like sihaAmN pl. of sahomN: (Msb:) fem. DaxomapN, (S, Msb,) applied to a woman; (Msb;) pl. DaxomaAtN, with the x quiescent, (S, Msb,) because it is an epithet. (S.)
See also miDoxamN. ― -b2- It was said to a man, A_in~a laka laxayorN [app. meaning “ Verily thou hast wealth ”]; and he replied, A^ajalo xayorN Daxomu AlEunuqi [app., (tropical:) Yea, large wealth]; which is tropical. (TA.) And one says, lahu suwdadN DaxomN (assumed tropical:) [He has great lordship or dignity], and $arafN DaxomN [great nobility], and $aA^onN aDaxomN [great importance or rank]. (TA.) ― -b3- DaxomN applied to a road means (tropical:) Wide. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And applied to water, (tropical:) Heavy. (K, TA.)
DaxamN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
Dixam~apN * , applied to a woman, (tropical:) Very wide, or wide and fat, (EariyDapN A^ariyDapN,) and soft, or tender. (K, TA.)
DuxaAmN * : see DaxomN.
A^aDoxamu * : see DaxomN. ― -b2- One says [also], h`*aA A^aDoxamu minohu [This is larger, bigger, &c., than it, or he]. (S.)
A^aDoxam~u * and A_iDoxam~N: see DaxomN.

A^uDoxuwmapN *
A woman's EiZaAmap [or thing resembling a pillow], (S, K, TA,) with which she makes herself [to appear] large behind her waist [or posteriors]. (TA.)

miDoxamN * , as an epithet applied to a chief, or lord, (tropical:) Noble, and portly, or corpulent; (K, TA;) as also ↓ DaxomN. (TA.) ― -b2- And, applied to a man, (TA,) (tropical:) Vehement in dashing himself against another; and in striking, or beating. (K, TA.)

1 Dad~ahu * , (AZ, K,) first pers. Dadadotuhu, [aor.
Dadu3a ,] inf. n. Dad~N, He overcame him: (AZ, L:) and also, (AZ, L,) or Dad~ahu fiY AlxuSuwmapi, (K,) He overcame him in litigation, altercation, or contention. (AZ, L, K.) ― -b2- And Dad~ahu Eanohu He averted him; turned him, or sent him, away, or back; or caused him to return, or go back, or revert; from it: (L, K:) i. e., a thing, or an affair: (L:) and prevented, or hindered, him from doing it; (K;) by gentle means: (L, K:) as also Sad~ahu: heard by Aboo-Turáb from Záïdeh. (L.) -A2- Dad~a Alqirobapi, (S, K,) aor.
Dadu3a , (S,) inf. n. Dad~N, (AA, S,) He filled the water-skin. (S, K.)

3 DAd~hu * , (inf. n. muDaAd~apN, Msb,) He, or it, was, or became, contrary, opposed, or repugnant, to him, or it; (AHeyth, S, * L, K;) said with respect to two men when one desires what is long, and the other, what is short; or one, darkness, and the other, light; or one, to pursue one course, and the other, to pursue another: (AHeyth, L:) or he, or it, was, or became, separated from him, or it, by contrariety, opposition, or repugnance: (Msb:) [or, accord. to the explanation of mutaDaAd~aAni in the Msb, it was, or became inconsistent with it.]

4 ADd~ *
He (a man, S) was, or became, angry. (S, K.) It is not, as some assert it to be, a quasi-pass. [of Dad~ahu], like as A^akab~a is of kab~ahu. (TA.)

6 taDaAoda3a [tDAd~A They two were, or became, contrary, opposed, or repugnant, each to the other: or, accord. to the explanation of mutaDaAd~aAni in the Msb, they two were, or became, inconsistent, each with the other.]

Did~N * (S, L, Msb, K) and ↓ DadiydN (S, L, K) and ↓ DadiydapN (Th, M) The contrary, or opposite, (AA, IAar, S, * M, Msb, K,) of a thing: (AA, Msb:) or Did~u $aYo'K signifies that which is repugnant to a thing, so that it would overcome it; as black is to white, and death to life: (Lth, L:) [or, accord. to the explanation of mutaDaAd~aAni in the Msb, that which is inconsistent with a thing:] pl. of the first A^aDadaAdN. (S, Msb, &c.) One says also, huwa Did~uka and ↓ Dadiyduka He is contrary, or opposed, or repugnant, to thee; as when thou desirest what is long, and he, what is short; or thou, darkness, and he, light; or thou, to pursue one course, and he, to pursue another. (AHeyth, L.) And Did~N is sometimes a pl., (K,) or sometimes denotes a collective body; (Akh, S, L;) as in the phrase yakuwnuwna Ealayohimo Did~FA, (S, L, K,) in the Kur [xix. 85], (S, L,) meaning They shall be adversaries, or enemies, to them: ('Ikrimeh, Jel:) or helpers against them. (Fr, Jel.) One says also, Alqawomu EalaY~a Did~N waAHidN, meaning The people are assembled together against me in contention, or altercation, with me. (L.) ― -b2- Did~N in lexicology signifies A kind of mu$otarak [or homonym]; being a word that has two contrary meanings; as jawonN, which means both “ black ” and “ white; ” and jalalN, which means both “ great ” and “ small ” pl. as above. (Mz, 26th nwE.) [Did~N is itself a word of this kind, as is shown by what here follows.] ― -b3- Also, (AA, Th, S, L, Msb, K,) and ↓ DadiydN, (S, L, K,) The like, or equal, (AA, Th, S, L, Msb, K,) of a thing. (AA, Msb.) Thus they have two contrary meanings. (K.) One says, laA Did~a lahu and lahu ↓ laA Dadiyda There is no like, or equal, to him, or it. (S, L.) And laqiYa Alqawomu A^aDodaAdahumo The people, or party, found, or met, their equals, or fellows. (L.)
DadadN * : see DaAd~N.
DadiydN * : see Dad~N, in four places.
DadiydapN * : see Did~N, first sentence.
DaAd~N * , or ↓ DaAdidN and ↓ DadadN One who fills vessels for people when they seek, or demand, water: pl. DudadN, [which is anomalous,] on the authority of AA. (L.)
DaAdidN * : see what next precedes.

humaA mutaDaAd~aAni *
They two are contrary, opposed, or repugnant, each to the other: (S, * L, K:) or they two are inconsistent; or such as cannot be, or exist, together; as night and day. (Msb.)

1 Dar~ahu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) and Dar~a bihi, (K,) aor.
Daru3a , (Msb,) inf. n. Dar~N; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ DAr~hu, [which see also below,] (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. muDaAr~apN (Msb, K) and DiraArN; (A, Msb, K;) and ↓ ADr~hu, (K,) or bihi ↓ ADr~, (Msb,) or both, inf. n. A_iDoraArN; (TA;) He, or it, harmed, injured, hurt, marred, mischiefed, or damaged, him, or it; contr. of nafaEahu; (S, A, K;) did to him, or it, an act that was evil, or disliked, or hated. (Msb.) ― -b2- Dar~ahu A_ilayohi: see 8. ― -b3- laA yaDur~aka Ealayohi jamalN (tropical:) No camel will be more sufficient for thee than he; syn. laA yaziyduka: and laA yaDur~uka Ealayohi rajulN (tropical:) [No man will be more sufficient for thee than he; or] thou wilt not find a man who will be more sufficient for thee than he; i. e. laA tajidu rajulFA yaziyduka EalaY maA Einoda h`*aA Alr~ajuli mina AlkifaAyapi: (ISk, S:) and maA yaDur~uka EalaY AlD~ab~i SayodN (tropical:) No animal that is hunted is more sufficient for thee than the Dab~; and so maA yaDiyruka: and maA taDur~uka EalayohaA jaAriyapN (tropical:) No girl, or young woman, is more sufficient for thee than she; syn. maA taziyduka: (A:) and maA yaDur~uka Ealayohi $ayoy^FA (tropical:) He, or it, is not at all more sufficient for thee than he, or it; syn. maA yaziyduka. (IAar, TA.) -A2- Dar~a, [sec. pers. app. Darurota, and aor. yaDur~u,] inf. n. DaraArapN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, blind: part. n. DariyrN [q. v.]. (MA.)

3 DAr~hu * , inf. n. muDaAr~apN and DaraArN, He harmed him, injured him, or hurt him, in return, or in requital: whence the saying in a trad., lA Darara walaA DiraAra fiY AlA_isolaAmi There shall be no harming, injuring, or hurting, of one man by another, in the first instance, nor in return, or requital, in El-Islám: (Mgh, TA: *) DiraArN is syn. with muDaAr~apN: (S:) or, accord. to some, it is syn. with DararN; and in the phrase in a trad. mentioned above, is added as a corroborative. (TA.) See also 1. muDaAr~apN in the case of a testament is the not executing it; or the violating it in part; or the bequeathing to any unfit person or persons; and the like; contrary to the sun~ap. (TA.) ― -b2- He disagreed with, or differed from, him; dissented from him; was contrary, opposed, or repugnant, to him; or he acted contrarily, contrariously, adversely, or in opposition, to him; syn. xAlafahu. (K.) And hence, accord. to some, the saying in a trad., (O, K,) relating to the seeing God on the day of resurrection, (O,) laA tuDaAr~uwna fiY ruw^oyatihi, (O, K,) i. e. Ye will not differ, one from another, nor dispute together, respecting the truth of the seeing Him; (Zj, O, * TA;) because of his manifest appearance: (Zj, TA:) or the meaning is, laA tuDaAm~uwna, (S, K,) and thus some relate it, (TA,) meaning ye will not draw yourselves together, (K, TA,) and straiten one another; one saying to another “ Show me Him, ” like as people do in looking at the new moon, but each will by himself have the sight of Him: (TA:) or, as some say, it is ↓ laA taDaAr~uwna [originally tataDaAr~uwna], meaning laA taDaAm~uwna, [which is the same in signification as laA tuDaAm~uwna], i. e. with fet-h to the t: (TA, and so in one of my
copies of the S:) and some say, lA tuDaAruwna, from AlD~ayoru; (Mgh, TA;) [i. e. ye will not be hurt;] meaning ye will not hurt one another: (M in art. Dyr:) and some, laA tuDaAmuwn, from AlD~ayomu. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b3- See also 4; and the phrase tazaw~aja EalaY muDaAr~apK, voce Dir~N.

4 ADr~hu * and ADr~bihi : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- ADr~hu EalaY AlA^amori He compelled him against his will to do the thing. (Sgh, K.) [See also 8.] -A2- ADr~, intrans., (tropical:) It (anything) approached so near as to harm, injure, or hurt; (TA;) or so near as to straighten, or incommode. (L.) You say, ADr~ bihi, meaning (tropical:) It approached very near to him, so as to annoy him: (TA, from a trad.:) or (tropical:) he drew very near to him: (S, A:) or (tropical:) he clave, or stuck, to him. (A.) And ADr~ biAlT~ariyq (tropical:) He approached the road, but was not upon it. (TA.) And banuw fulaAnK yuDir~u AlT~ariyqu (tropical:) The sons of such a one are one the travelled track. (A.) And ADr~ Als~ayolu mina AlHaAy^iTi (assumed tropical:) The torrent drew near to the wall: and Als~aHaAbu A_ilaY AlA^aroDi the clouds to the earth. (K.) ― -b2- ADr~ Ealayohi (tropical:) He importuned him; plied him; plied him hard; pressed him; pressed him hard; was urgent with him; persecuted him, or harassed him. (A.) ― -b3- ADr~ Alfarasu EalaY faA^osi All~ijaAmi (tropical:) The horse champed the fA^s [q. v.] of the bit; (A 'Obeyd, S, A;) and so ADz~. (S.) ― -b4- ADr~ fulaAnN EalaY Als~ayori Al$~adiydi (assumed tropical:) Such a one bore patiently hard journeying. (TA.) -A3- Also, (Msb,) inf. n. A_iDoraArN, (S,) He took to himself a wife while having another wife: (As, S, Msb, TA:) [and so, app., ↓ DAr~: (see Dir~N:)] or he gave [a woman] in marriage to a man having at the time another wife. (TA.) -A4- ADr~ yaEoduw (S, K, * TA) signifies He hastened (S, K, TA) somewhat in running, accord. to A 'Obeyd; (S, TA;) but Et-Toosee says that this is a mistake, and that it is correctly ASr~. (TA.)

5 tDr~r *
He was [harmed, injured, or hurt; or] afflicted, grieved, or sick: and he experienced straitness, pressure, or inconvenience. (KL.)
6 laA taDaAr~uwna * [originally tataDaAr~uwna]: see 3.

8 ADTr~hu A_ilaY ka*aA *
It, (a thing, or an affair, TA,) or he, [a man, or God,] necessitated, constrained, compelled, forced, or drove, him to have recourse to, or to do, such a thing; or impelled, or drove, him, against his will, to it, or to do it; (Msb, K;) so that he had no means of avoiding it; as also A_ilayohi ↓ Dar~ahu: (Msb:) it made him to want, or be in need of, such a thing: (K, TA:) from DararN signifying “ narrowness, ” or “ straitness. ” (TA.) [See also 4. Hence the phrase, laA^aDoTar~an~aka A_ilaY A^aSolika, expl. in art. ASl. See also the Kur ii. 120, and xxxi. 23.] ― -b2- AuDoTur~a A_ilaY ka*aA He was, or became, necessitated, constrained, compelled, forced, or driven, to have recourse to, or to do, such a thing; or was impelled, or driven, against his will, to it, or to do it: (S, K:) he wanted, or was or became in need of, such a thing. (K.)
Dar~N * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

Dur~N *
Harm, injury, hurt, mischief, or damage; contr. of nafoEN; as also ↓ Dar~N, (A, K,) or this is an inf. n., (S, Msb, K,) and the former is a simple subst.; (ADk, Msb, K;) and ↓ DararN [which is now the most common]: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) or an evil state or condition; (ADk, T, S, L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ DararN and ↓ taDir~apN and ↓ taDur~apN; (K; for the right reading in the K is wAlD~araru suwo'u AlHaAli, as in the L, &c.; not wAlDrr wsw' AlHAl; TA; [but in some of the copies of the K, and in the TA, this signification is assigned to Dar~N instead of Dur~N; and in the latter, its pl. is said to be A^aDur~N;]) and poverty; and bodily affliction: but the contr. of nafoEN is termed ↓ Dar~N, with fet-h: (ADk, T, Msb, TA: *) [see also Dar~apN and DararN and Dar~aA='u and DaruwrapN and DaAruwraA='u, all of which have similar meanings:] and disease; (A, Msb;) thus in the Kur xxi. 83: (Msb:) or leanness: (S, A, TA:) the state, or condition, of him who is termed Dariyr [q. v.]. (TA.) -A2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

Dar~N * The taking a wife in addition to another wife; (S;) a subst. from Dar~apN. (K.) You say, nukiHati AlmaroA^apu EalaY Dir~K The woman was taken to wife in addition to a former wife. (S.) And, accord. to Aboo-'Abd-Allah Et-Tuwál, tazaw~ajotu AlmaroA^apa EalaY Dir~K and ↓ Dur~K [I took the woman to wife in addition to another wife]. (S.) And tazaw~aja EalaY Dir~K and ↓ Dur~K i. e. ↓ muDaAr~apK, meaning He married so as to have two or three wives together. (K.) And Kr mentions the phrase, tazaw~ajotu AlmaroA^apa EalaY Dir~K kun~a lahaA [I took to wife the woman in addition to others who were her fellow-wives]: and if it be so, Dir~ is an inf. n. [used in this instance as an epithet, and therefore applicable to a pl. number as well as to a single person], formed by the rejection of the augmentative letter [in its verb, i. e. A^aDar~a], or it is a pl. that has no sing. (TA.) -A2- One says also rajulN Dir~u A^aDoraArK (K, TA) i. e. A man [who is] a strong one of strong ones; like as one says Sil~u A^aSolaAlK and Dil~u A^aDolaAlK: (TA:) or very cunning (daAhiyapN) in his judgment, or opinion. (K, TA.)

Dar~apN * [Necessity, or need;] a subst. from 8: (K, TA:) hardness, distressfulness, or afflictiveness, of state or condition: and annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt. (Sgh, K.) See also [Dur~N, and] DararN, and Dar~aA='u, and DaruwrapN. -A2- A woman's husband's wife; her fellow-wife: (S, Msb, K:) an appellation disliked by the Muslim; jaArapN being used in preference to it; accord. to a trad.: (TA:) pl. DaraAy^iru (Msb, K) and Dar~aAtN; (Msb;) the former extr. [with respect to rule]; (TA;) the latter regular. (Msb.) [See also Eal~apN.] ― -b2- Hence, sing. of DaraAy^iru signifying (tropical:) Discordant things or affairs; likened to fellow-wives, who will not agree. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence also, app.,] AlD~ar~ataAni is a term applied to (assumed tropical:) The two stones of a mill. (S, M.) -A3- The flesh of the DaroE [or udder]: (S:) or the udder (DrE) altogether, (K, TA,) except the A^aTobaA=' [or teats], when containing milk, but not otherwise: (TA:) or the base of the DrE, which is never, or scarcely ever, without milk in it: (TA:) or the base of the vadoY [or breast]: and i. q. xilofN [q. v.]. (K.) One says Dar~apN $akoraY, meaning A full Dr~p: (S in this art.:) or a Dr~p having much milk. (S in art. $kr.) ― -b2- Dar~apu AlA_ibohaAmi The portion of flesh that is beneath the thumb, which is what corresponds to the A^aloyah in the hand: (S:) or AlD~ar~apu signifies the portion of the palm of the hand extending from beneath the little finger to the wrist: (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) or the inner side of the hand, (K, TA,) over against the little finger, corresponding to the Alyp in the hand: (TA:) or the portion of flesh beneath the thumb: (K:) or the root thereof [i. e. of the thumb]: (TA:) and that part of the flesh of the sole of the foot upon which one treads, next the great toe. (K.) [See A^aloyapN.] ― -b3- The pl. of Dar~apN (in all the senses expl. above, TA) is DaraAy^iru, (K, TA,) which [as said above] is extr. (TA.) ― -b4- And AlD~ar~ataAni signifies The buttocks, on each side of the bone thereof: (K:) or the two flabby portions of flesh, on each side. (M, TA.) -A4- Also Much property, (S,) or many cattle, (S, * TA,) exclusive of money: (TA:) or property, or cattle, (mAl,) upon which one relies [for his maintenance], but belonging to another, or others, (K, TA,) of his relations: (TA:) and a detached number of cattle, of camels, and of sheep or goats. (K, TA.)
Dur~apN * : see Dar~aA='u.

DararN * : see Dur~N, in two places. ― -b2- Also Defect, deficiency, detriment, or loss, (Msb, K,) and so ↓ Dar~apN and ↓ DaraArapN, (TA,) that happens to a thing, (K,) or to articles of property. (Msb.) You say, daxala Ealayohi DararN fiY maAlihi [Defect, deficiency, detriment, or loss, came upon him in his property, or cattle]. (TA.) And huwa fiY Darari xayorK [He is in a state of defective, or little, prosperity]. (TA.) See also Dar~aA='u. ― -b3- Also Narrowness, or straitness. (A 'Obeyd, S, K.) You say makaAnN *uw DararK A narrow place. (A 'Obeyd, S.) And laA Darara Ealayoka and ↓ lA DaAruwrapa and ↓ lA taDir~apa [app. No straitness shall befall thee: or no evil: or no adversity: or no want]. (S.) ― -b4- And Narrow. (K.) You say makaAnN DararN A narrow place. (TA.) And maA='N DararN Water in a narrow place. (IAar.) ― -b5- And The brink, or edge, of a cave, or cavern. (AA, O, K.) One says, laA tamo$i EalaY h`*aA AlD~arari [Walk not thou on this brink, or edge, of a cave]. (AA, O.)

DariyrN *
i. q. muDaAr~apN [i. e. Injurious conduct, either in the first instance or in return or requital: &c.: see 3]: (S, A, K:) a subst. in this sense: (TA:) but it is mostly used in the sense here next following. (S, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Jealousy. (S, A, K.) One says, mA A^a$ad~a Dariyrahu EalayohaA (tropical:) How great is his jealousy on her account! (S, A.) And A_in~ahu la*uw DariyrK EalaY A@moraA^atihi (tropical:) Verily he is jealous on account of his wife. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Spirit (nafosN), and
remains of stoutness of body (baqiy~apu jisomK): (S, K:) or, as some say, remains of spirit (baqiy~apu nafosK). (TA.) One says naAqapN *aAtu DariyrK A she-camel strong in spirit, slow in becoming fatigued: (S, TA:) also expl. as meaning that injures the [other] camels by the vehemence of her pace, or the hardness of her journeying. (TA.) And baAqK DariyruhaA, referring to camels, is expl. by As as meaning Whose strength is lasting. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Patience, (S, K,) and endurance. (S.) One says, A_in~ahu la*uw DariyrK Verily he has patient endurance of evil: (TA:) and A_in~ahu la*uw DariyrK EalaY Al$~ar~i waAl$~idapi Verily he has patient endurance of evil and hardship; (As, S, * TA;) a phrase used in relation to a man and to a beast. (TA.) -A2- Also [an epithet] signifying Anything intermixed, or mingled, with Dur~ [i. e. harm, injury, &c.]; and so ↓ maDoruwrN. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Blind; (S, K;) [a more respectful epithet than A^aEomaY]; pl. A^aDir~aA='u: (K:) (assumed tropical:) harmed by the loss of an eye, or by a constant and severe disease: (Msb:) (tropical:) diseased: (A, K:) and (assumed tropical:) lean, or emaciated: (K:) affected with a malady of long continuance; or crippled, or deprived of the power to move or to stand or to walk, by disease, or by a protracted disease: (TA:) fem. with p: (A, K:) and pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b3- And Persevering, and strong. (TA.) [Thus having contr. meanings.] ― -b4- And Very patient (AA, S, K) in endurance of everything; applied to a beast, (AA, S,) and also to a man. (TA.) -A3- Also The brink of a valley; (S, K;) the side thereof: one says, nazala fulaAnN EalaY A^aHadi DariyraY AlwaAdiY, meaning [Such a one alighted] upon one of the two sides of the valley: (S:) pl. A^aDir~apN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Freytag has explained it also, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees, as meaning The last part of a journey.]
DaraAy^iru * Persons in want, needy, or poor. (S.) ― -b2- Also pl. of Dar~apN, [q. v.,] (Msb, K, TA,) in various senses. (TA.)
DaraArapN * : see DararN: and Dar~aA='u, in two places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Blindness. (S, K, TA.) [See 1, last sentence, where it is mentioned as an inf. n.]

DaruwrapN *
Necessity, necessitude, need, or want; (Lth, S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ DaAruwrapN (S, K) and ↓ DaAruwrN and ↓ DaAruwraA='u and ↓ Dar~apN: (K, TA:) pl. DaruwraAtN. (TA.) You say, HamalaniY AlD~aruwrapu EalaY ka*aA waka*aA [Necessity urged me to do such and such things]. (Lth.) And ↓ rajulN *uw DaAruwrapi and DaruwrapK A man in want. (S.) [And hence fiY AlD~aruwrapi as meaning In the case of necessity in poetry or verse: and DaruwrapF by necessity; meaning by poetic license. See also Daruwriy~apN.] ― -b2- And Difficulty, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, fatigue, or weariness. (Msb.) [See also Dur~N, and Dar~apN, and Dar~aA='u.]

DaruwriY~N * [Necessary knowledge]; as opposed to AikotisaAbiY~N, [natural, bestowed by nature, instinctive, or] such as the creature has by [divine] appointment; and, as opposed to AisotidolaAliY~N, [intuitive, immediate, axiomatic, or] such as originates without thought, or reflection, and intellectual examination of an evidence or a proof. (Kull.) [See also badiyhiY~N.] ― -b2- [Daruwriy~apN as an epithet applied to a proposition means Qualified by the expression biAlD~aruwrapi (by necessity). ― -b3- And the pl. Daruwriy~aAtN means Necessary, or indispensable, things.]

[
Daruwriy~apN *
Necessity. (See also DaruwrapN.) ― -b2- As fem. of the epithet DaruwriY~N, see this latter word.]

Dar~aA='u *
A hurtful state or condition; (IAth;) contr. of sar~aA='u: (IAth, Msb:) or hardship, distress, or straitness of condition [or of the means of subsistence, or of the conveniences of life]; (AHeyth;) i. q. $id~apN; (S, A, K;) as also baA^osaA='u, like which it is a fem. n. without a mase.; and accord. to Fr, A^aDur~N and A^abow^usN may be used as pls. of these two ns.: (S:) or, accord. to Az, (assumed tropical:) that [evil] which relates to the person; as disease: whereas bA^sA=' is that which relates to property; as poverty: (Bd in ii. 172:) or detriment, or loss, with respect to property and with respect to persons; (A, K;) as also ↓ Dar~apN, or ↓ Dur~apN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) and ↓ DaraArapN: (K:) and [hence] poverty: and punishment: and drought, or barrenness; or vehement, or intense, drought; (TA: [see also DaAruwraA='u:]) and (assumed tropical:) disease of long continuance; or such as cripples, or deprives of the power to move or to stand or to walk; (A, K;) as also ↓ DararN, as used in the Kur iv. 97: or, accord. to Ibn-'Arafeh, the latter there means (assumed tropical:) a hurtful malady that cuts one off from serving in war against unbelievers and the like; as also ↓ DaraArapN; relating to sight, &c. (TA.) -A2- [Also, accord. to Freytag, Tangled trees, in a valley: but the word having this meaning is correctly DaraA='N, belonging to art. Drw and DrY, q. v. And be explains it also as meaning a bare, or an open, place; and the contr. i. e. a place covered with trees; referring to the “ Kitáb el-Addád. ”]
Dar~aArN * [That harms, injures, hurts, &c., much]. (TA in art. xlw.)

DaAr~N * [act. part. n. of 1; Harming, injuring, hurting, &c.; or that harms, &c.; noxious, injurious, &c.]. Aln~aAfiEu AlD~aAr~u, an appellation of God, means He who benefiteth and who harmeth whomsoever He will, of his creatures. (TA.)
DaAruwrN * : see DaruwrapN.
DaAruwrapN * : see DararN; and DaruwrapN, in two places.

DaAruwraA='u *
Drought: and hardship, distress, or adversity. (K.) See also DaruwrapN. [And see Dur~N, and Dar~aA='u.]

[
SifapN A@DoTiraAriy~apN *
i. q. SifapN xiloqiy~apN i. e. A natural quality; opposed to A@xotiyaAriy~apN.]
taDir~apN * and taDur~apN: see Dur~N: and for the former see also DararN.

muDir~N *
Approaching (K, TA) to a thing: and approaching so near as to harm, injure, or hurt. (TA.) saHaAbN muDir~N means Clouds approaching the earth. (S, A.) -A2- Also A man having two wives, (S, K, *) or having [several] wives at the same time. (Msb.) And a woman having a fellow-wife, (TA,) or having fellow-wives; (S, Msb;) having a fellow-wife, or two fellow-wives; as also muDir~apN. (K.) -A3- And A man having a Dar~ap [q. v.] of cattle: (TA:) or who has a Dar~ap of cattle that return to him in the afternoon, or evening, from the place of pasture. (S, TA.)

maDar~apN *
A cause, or means, of harm, injury, hurt, mischief, or damage; contr. of manofaEapN: (S, TA:) [and simply] harm, injury, hurt, &c.; syn. DararN: pl. maDaAr~u. (Msb.)

miDoraArN * A woman, and a she-camel, and a mare, that takes fright, and runs away, and goes at random, (tanid~u watarokabu $idoqahaA,) by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (IAar, K.)
