DaforN, (S, A, &c.,) He plaited, braided, or interwove, (S, A, Mgh, K,) hair, (S, Mgh, K,) &c., (S,) or the like, (TA,) or a [lock of hair, such as is called] *uw^aAbap, and a [girth of thongs such as is called] nisoE, (A,) in a wide form; (S, Mgh;) as also ↓ Df~r, inf. n. taDofiyrN: (S, TA:) he made hair into DafaAy^ir, [pl. of DafiyrapN,] each Dafiyrap consisting of three or more distinct portions. (Msb.) ― -b2- He twisted a rope or cord. (K.) ― -b3- Dafarato $aEarahaA, (S, TA,) aor.
Dafira , (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) said of a woman, (S, TA.) She gathered together her hair. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- And Dafara, from the same verb in the first of the senses expl. above, (tropical:) He made, or constructed, a [dam of the kind called] Dafiyrap. (IAar, TA.) ― -b5- DaforN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The building with stones without [the cement called] kilos and without clay. (K, * TA.) You say, Dafara AlHijaArapa Hawola bayotihi (assumed tropical:) [He built the stones around his house, or tent, without mortar or clay]. (TA.) ― -b6- Dafara AlbaEiyra AlElafa, (A,) inf. n. DaforN, (K,) (tropical:) He put the fodder into the mouth of the camel, (A, K, *) against his will. (A.) And Dafara Alfarasa lijaAmahu, (A,) or Dafara Ald~aAb~apa, aor.
Dafira , inf. n. DaforN, (TA,) (tropical:) He put the bit into the mouth of the horse, (A,) or of the beast. (TA.) -A2- Also Dafara, aor.
Dafira , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. DaforN, (S, Msb,) He ran; syn. EadaA and saEaY: (S, Msb, K:) or he hastened, or went quickly: or he bounded, or sprang: (TA:) he leaped (As, K) in his running. (As, TA.)
2 Daf~ara see the preceding paragraph, first sentence.

3 DAfrhu *
He aided him. (A, Msb.) [See also 6.]

6 tDAfrwA *
They leagued together, and aided one another, (Ibn-Buzurj, S, * A, * Msb, * K, *) EalaY AlA^amori to do the thing, (S, A, * K,) and EalaY fulaAnK against such a one. (Ibn-Buzurj.)

7 AnDfr AlHabolaAni *
The two ropes became twisted together. (S.)

DaforN *
A camel's girth, of plaited [goats'] hair; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ DafaArN: (K:) the girth of a camel's saddle: (S:) a wide girth of a camel's saddle; as also ↓ DafiyrapN: pl. [of mult.] (of the first, TA) DufuwrN (K, TA) and [of pauc.] A^aDofaArN; (TA;) and (of the second, TA) DufurN. (K, TA.) ― -b2- See also DafiyrapN, in three places. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A great quantity of sand that has become collected together: or a quantity of sand that has become accumulated, part upon part; (K;) and (K) so ↓ DafirapN: (S, K:) pl. [of the former] DufuwrN; (K;) and [coll. gen. n.] of the latter ↓ DafirN: (S:) or a long, broad, Hiqof [generally expl. as meaning a winding tract] of sand; by some pronounced ↓ DafarN: (Lth, TA:) [or] a Hiqof of sand is termed ↓ DafiyrapN. (S.)
DafarN * : see the last preceding sentence.

DafirN * and [its n. un.] DafirapN: see DaforN. -A2- kinaAnapN DafirapN [in the TA Dfyrp, evidently a mistranscription,] i. q. mumotaliy^apN [i. e. A full quiver]. (S, O. [Freytag writes kinAnpu DafirapN, and explains it as meaning “ Gens Cinanah impleta est: ” but in my copies of the S and in the O, it is kinaAnapN.])
DafaArN * : see DaforN, first sentence.

DafiyrN *
A rope of [goats'] hair, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) twisted: of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The shore, or side, of the sea or of a great river; (O, K, * TA;;) as also ↓ DafiyrapN. (TA.)

DafayrapN * (As, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ DaforN, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) the latter an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly so termed], (Mgh,) A single lock of hair: (M, Msb, K:) and (Msb) a [lock of hair such as is termed] *uw^aAbap, (Mgh, Msb,) or jamiyrap and gadiyrap, of a woman: (As, TA:) or a plaited, braided, or interwoven, *w^Abp: (A, TA;) or [a plait of hair] consisting of three, or more, distinct portions: (Msb:) or i. q. EaqiySapN [q. v.]: one says lahaA DafiyrataAni, and ↓ DaforaAni, meaning EaqiySataAni: (Yaakoob, S:) or the DafiyrataAni pertain to a man, not to a woman; [though such is not the case accord. to modern usage;] and gadaAy^ir, [pl. of gadiyrapN,] to women; and these are maDofuwrap [i. e. plaited]: (AZ, TA:) the pl. of DafiyrapN is DafaAy^iru (A, Msb) and DufurN; (Msb;) and the pl. of ↓ DaforN is DufuwrN. (A.) ― -b2- See also DaforN, in two places. ― -b3- DafiyrapN also signifies (tropical:) A dam, (IAar, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) extending in an oblong form upon the ground, having in it wood and stones. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A plain, or soft, tract of land, oblong, producing herbage or the like, extending [to the distance of the journey of] a day, or two days. (TA.) ― -b5- See also DafiyrN.

AlD~aAfiru fiY AlHaj~i *
He who twists, or plaits, (yaEoqiSu,) his hair during the performance of the pilgrimage. (TA.)

1 DafaA * , aor. yaDofuw, (S, Msb,) inf. n. DafowN (S, Msb, K) and Dafuw~N, (Msb,) It (a thing, S, and a garment, S, Msb) was, or became, complete, full, ample, or without deficiency. (S, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- And It was, or became, much in quantity; (S, K, * TA;) said of property, or property consisting in cattle, (S, TA,) and of hair, and of wool. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, Dafato Ealayohi Aln~iEomapu, i. q. raf~ato [i. e. Wealth became abundantly bestowed upon him]. (M in art. rf.) And DafaA AlEayo$u, meaning Ait~asaEa [i. e. The means of subsistence became ample]. (Msb.) ― -b3- And DafaA AlHawoDu, (TA,) inf. n. DafowN, (K, TA,) The watering-trough overflowed (K, * TA) by reason of its fulness. (TA.) -A2- DafiYa He (a man) became poor: mentioned by Az in art. Dyq. (TA.)

DafFA *
A side: and DafawaAhu his, or its, two sides. (K.) [Daf~apN and Dif~apN, also, have a similar meaning.]
DafowN * [an inf. n. of 1, q. v.: and as a simple subst.,] Wealth, or prosperity, and ampleness [of circumstances]. (TA.) [See also what next follows.]

Dafowapu AlEayo$i *
An easy and a plentiful state, or condition, of life. (K, TA.) One says, fulaAnN fiY DafowapK mino Eayo$ihi [Such a one is in an easy and a plentiful state, or condition, in respect of his means of subsistence]. (S.)

vawobN DaAfK *
A garment that is complete, full, ample, or without deficiency. (S, Msb, K. *) And farasN DaAfiY Als~abiyb A horse full, or ample, in the sbyb [or hair of the forelock or of the mane or of the tail]. (TA.) And rajulN DaAfiY Alr~aA^osi A man having much hair of the head. (S.) And diym~pN DaAfyapN A lasting, or continuous, or continuous and still, rain, in consequence of which the land becomes abundant with herbage. (TA.) And huwa DaAfiY AlfaDoli (tropical:) [He is abundant in excellence]. (TA.)

1 Dalalotu * , (S, Mgh, * O, Msb, * K,) third pers. Dal~a, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
Dali3a , (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. DalaAlN and DalaAlapN; (S, * O, * Msb;) and Dalilotu, (S, Mgh, * O, Msb, * K,) third pers. as above; (Mgh;) the former of the dial. of Nejd, and the more chaste; the latter of the dial. of the people of El-'Áliyeh, (S, Msb, TA,) and of El- Hijáz, and Kr has mentioned Dililotu for Dalilotu as heard from the tribe of Temeem; (TA;) I erred, strayed, or went astray; (Mgh, Msb;) deviated from the right way or course, or from that which was right; missed, or lost, the right way; or lost my way; DalaAlN and DalaAlapN signifying the contr. of ra$aAdN, (S, O, TA,) and hudFY. (K, TA.) [See DalaAlN below.] Hence, in the Kur [xxxiv. 49], qulo A_ino Dalalotu fiA_in~amaA A^aDil~u EalaY nafosiY [Say thou, If I err, I shall err only against myself, i. e., to my own hurt]. (O, Msb. [See also x. 108 and xvii. 16 of the Kur.]) One says also, Dal~a DalaAluhu [app. His error became error indeed; a phrase similar to jad~a jid~uhu, q. v.: or his erring passed away; see 4, latter part]. (TA.) And Dal~a Eani AlqaSodi He deviated from the right way or course. (TA.) And the verb is trans. as well as intrans.: you say, Dal~a AlT~ariyqa, and Dal~a Eanohu, aor.
Dali3a and
Dala3a , (Mgh, Msb,) inf. ns. as above, meaning He erred, strayed, or went astray, from the road, or way; (Msb;) he did not find the way to the road: (Mgh, Msb:) and of anything stationary, if you miss the place thereof, you say Dalalotuhu and Dalilotuhu: (Az, Msb:) or you say, Dalilotu AlT~ariyqa, (K,) or Dalilotu Almasojida, and Ald~aAra, (ISk, S, O,) [I missed, or lost, the right way to the road, or the mosque, and the house,] when you know not the place thereof: (ISk, S, O:) and in like manner, anything stationary, to which one does not find the way: (ISk, S, O, K:) and AA says the like: but that one says of a thing that falls from his hand, and a thing that quits its place, ↓ A^aDolalotuhu, (IB, TA,) which means I lost it, and knew not its place; meaning, for instance, a horse, or she-camel, or the like: (Az, Msb:) [thus] one says, A^aDolalotu biEiyriY [I lost my camel, and knew not his place,] (AA, ISk, S, IB, O) when his shank has been tied up to his arm and one does not find the way to him, and when he has been left loose and has gone away whither one knows not: (AA, IB, TA:) but Yoo differs from others respecting this case; for, accord. to him, one says, ADl~ fulaAnN baEiyrahu and also Dal~ahu, in the same sense; (O, TA;) and the like is said in the K: (TA:) and it is also said in the Bári' that when you seek an animal and miss its place and find not the way to it, it is regarded as in the category of stationary things, and therefore you say Dalilotuhu. (Msb.) ― -b2- Dal~a signifies also He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (Ibn-Es-Seed, TA.) ― -b3- Also, aor.
Dali3a (S, O, K) and
Dala3a , (K,) the pret. being like zal~a and mal~a, (TA,) inf. n. DalaAl, It (a thing, S, O, TA) became lost; [as though it went astray;] it perished, came to nought, or passed away. (S, O, K, TA.) Thus in the phrase Dal~a Ean~iY ka*aA Such a thing became lost from me. (Mgh.) One says to him from whom pieces of money have dropped, qado Dal~ato Eanoka [They have become lost from thee]. (TA.) And to him who has done a deed from which no profit has resulted, you say, qad Dal~a saEoyuka (tropical:) [Thy labour has been lost]: the like occurs in the Kur xviii. 104, meaning DaAEa. (TA, in two places.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He (a man, TA) died, and became dust and bones. (K, TA.) In this sense the verb is used in the Kur xxxii. 9: but some there read, in the place of DalalonaA, SalilonaA [q. v.], with S: (TA:) or the verb in that instance has the meaning here next following. (S.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) He, or it, (a man, S, TA, or a camel, Msb, and a thing, TA,) was, or became, unperceived or imperceptible, unapparent, latent, hidden or concealed, or absent, (S, Msb, K, TA.) Hence the phrase, Dal~a AlmaA='u fiY All~abani (tropical:) [The water became unperceived, or concealed, in the milk]. (TA.) One says of a road to which he has not been able to find the way, Dal~a Ean~iY
[It has become hidden from me]. (K, TA.) And hence also the saying of a man, as is related in a trad., (S, O, TA,) after his having charged his sons by saying to them, “ When I die, burn ye me; and when I shall have become ashes, pound me; then scatter me in the water: ” (O, TA:) laEal~iY A^aDil~u A@ll~`h (S, O, TA) i. e. (assumed tropical:) May-be, I shall be unperceived by God, or concealed from Him: (S:) or may-be, I shall be hidden, or absent, from God's punishment: (O, TA:) or, as El-'Otbee says, may-be, I shall escape God, and my place will be hidden from Him. (TA.) And Dal~a said of one forgetting means (assumed tropical:) His memory became absent from him. (O, Msb, TA.) A^ano taDil~a A_iHodaAhumaA, or A_ino taDil~a, in the Kur [ii. 282], accord. to different readers, (TA,) in which instance A^ano and A_ino are syn., (Mughnee, [see A^ano, in p. 106, cols. 1 and 2,]) means If one of them twain [referring to women] be absent from her memory: or if the memory of one of them twain be absent from her: [or if one of them twain err in her memory:] or, accord. to Zj, the meaning of the verb in this case is that which next follows. (TA.) ― -b6- Dalilotu Al$~aYo'a also signifies (assumed tropical:) I forgot the thing: whence one says of a woman, Dal~ato A^ay~aAma HayoDihaA (assumed tropical:) [She forgot the days of her menstruation]; and so ↓ A^aDal~atohaA: (Mgh:) or Dal~a fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) He was made, or caused, to forget such a one. (K. [In the CK, Aunosiyohi is erroneously put for A^unosiyahu.]) It is said that laA yaDil~u rab~iY, in the Kur xx. 54, means (assumed tropical:) My Lord will not be unmindful: or nothing will escape Him. (TA.) ― -b7- And one says, Dal~aniY fulaAnN, (Msb, K,) or Dal~aniY fulaAnN falamo A^aqodaro Ealayohi, (O,) meaning Such a one went away from me, (O, Msb, K,) and I was unable to compass him [or to find him]: so in the Bári'. (Msb.) -A2- Dul~a, as a verb of wonder: see Dul~N.

2 Dlalhu * , (S, MA, O, K,) inf. n. taDoliylN and taDolaAlN, (K,) He, or it, made, or caused, him to pursue a course that led to error, or deviation from the right way: (K: [see also 4:]) he, or it, led him astray; seduced him: (MA:) [or] he attributed, or imputed, to him error, or deviation from the right way. (S, MA, O.) Dul~ila saEoyuhumo, a phrase used by a poet, means Error, or deviation from the right way, was attributed to their labour; because they did not reach their goal. (Ham p. 771.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, Dal~ilo maAlaka Send forth, or set free, thy cattle to pasture, or to pasture where they please, by themselves. (O.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph.

4 ADl~hu * , inf. n. A_iDolaAlN, He, or it, made him, or caused him, to err, stray, or go astray; to deviate from the right way or course, or from that which was right; to miss, or lose, the right way; or to lose his way. (Az, TA.) [See also 2, first sentence.] AlA_iDolaAlu is of two sorts: one of these is the consequence of erring, or straying; either as in the case in which one says A^aDolalotu AlbaEiyra (expl. above, see 1, former half); or the decreeing that one shall err, or stray, &c., because he has done so already, and this is sometimes the case when the A_iDolaAl of a man is attributed to God: the other sort is the embellishing [or commending] to a man that which is false, or wrong, or vain, in order that he may err, or stray, &c.: and God's A_iDolaAl of a man is of two sorts; one of which has been expl. above; the other is God's so constituting man that when he observes [and pursues] a certain course, or way, [of acting or the like], whether it be such as is commended or such as is discommended, he habituates himself to it, and esteems it pleasant, and keeps to it, and finds it difficult to turn from it, wherefore it is said that custom is a second nature. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- Also He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to perish, or become lost; syn. A^aholakahu, (S, TA,) and A^aDaAEahu, (El-Fárábee, S, O, Msb,) or Day~aEahu; (TA;) [ADAEhu and Dy~Ehu signifying the same; and so ADl~hu and ↓ Dll~`hu; whence,] A^alamo yajoEalo kayodahumo fiY taDoliylK, in the Kur cv. 2, means [Did He not make their plot to be such as ended] in a causing to perish, or become lost, (fiY taDoyiyEK,) and in annulment? (Ksh, Bd.) A^aDal~a A^aEomaAlahumo, in the Kur [xlvii. 1 and 9, which may be rendered (assumed tropical:) He will cause their works to be lost, or to be of no effect], means, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, He will not recompense them for their good works; the phrase being similar to the saying qado Dal~a saEoyuka [expl. above]. (TA.) And A^aDal~a A@ll~`hu DalaAlaka (assumed tropical:) [May God make thine erring to be no more, or to come to an end,] is expl. by ISk as meaning may thine erring pass away from thee, so that thou shalt not err; and he adds that the saying mal~a malaAluka means *ahaba Eanoka Hat~aY laA tamal~a. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) He buried, and hid, or concealed, him, or it. (K, TA.) You say, A^uDil~a Almay~itu (tropical:) The dead was buried. (S, O.) The phrase A^aDal~ato bihi A^um~uhu, meaning (tropical:) His mother buried him, in a verse cited by IAar, is extr., or anomalous. (TA.) ― -b4- And He found him to be erring, straying, going astray; deviating from the right way or course, or from that which was right; missing, or losing, the right way; losing his way; not rightly directed, or not finding the way to the truth: like as one says A^aHomadahu, and A^aboxalahu. (TA.) ― -b5- And you say, A^aDal~aniY ka*aA, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a thing was, or became, beyond my power, or compass. (IAar, Msb, TA.) ― -b6- See also 1, near the end.

5 tZl~l *
It went away: so in the saying, tDl~l AlmaA='u mino taHoti AlHajari [The water went away from beneath the stone]. (O, TA.)

6 tDAl~ *
He feigned himself to be erring, straying, going astray; deviating from the right way or course, or from that which was right; missing, or losing, the right way; or losing his way. (O, TA.)

10 AstDl~ DalaAluhu *
His erring demanded that he should err [the more], so that he did err [the more: like as erring is said to be a cause of one's being made to err: see 4: and see also Dal~a DalaAluhu, near the beginning of the art.]: so in the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
raA=haA Alfuw^aAdu faA@sotaDal~a DalaAluhu
[The heart beheld her, and his erring demanded that he should err &c.]. (Skr, S, TA.)
Dal~N * : see DalaAlN.

Dul~N * : see DalaAlN. ― -b2- [Also, app. as meaning A lost state; a state of perishing, coming to nought, or passing away;] a subst. from Dal~a signifying DaAEa and halaka. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And hence [its usage, in the manner of a proper name, in] the saying, huwa Dul~u bonu Dul~K, (S,) which means, (S, O, K,) as also ↓ huwa Dil~u bonu Dil~K, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) He is the unknown, the son of the unknown; (S, Z, O, K;) and in like manner, bonu Alt~alaAli ↓ AlD~alaAlu; (S, O;) and qul~u bonu qul~K: (TA:) or he is one in whom is no good: (K:) or he is one who persists in error. (M, K.) ― -b4- [Hence also, perhaps, it is said that] yaA Dul~a maA tajoriY bihi AlEaSaA [in the CK Dal~a] means yaA faqodahu and yaA talafahu [i. e., app., O the loss, or O the coming to nought, of that by reason of which the mare El-'Asà is running!]: (K, TA:) a prov.; said by Kaseer Ibn-Saad to Jedheemeh El-Abrash, when he went with him to Ez-Zebbà; for when they were within her province, he repented, and Kaseer said to him, “ Mount this my horse, and escape upon him, for his dust will not be cloven [by the pursuer, ” i. e. he will not be overtaken]: (TA: [but the mare is thus made a male:]) or it was said by 'Amr Ibn-'Adee, when he saw El-'Asà, the mare of Jedheemeh, with Kaseer upon her: qawomu is suppressed after yA; and ↓ Dul~a is of the forms [of verbs] denoting wonder, originally Dalula, with damm, like Hub~a in the phrase Hub~a bifulaAnK, originally Habuba; and the meaning of the prov. is, O people, what a case of perdition is that by reason of which El-'Asà is running! i. e., the death of Jedheemeh. (Meyd.) ― -b5- Dul~N bitaDolaAlK [in CK Dal~N] means A vain, or futile, thing: (S, O, K:) [or a vain, misleading thing; taDolaAlN being an inf. n. of Dal~ala:] 'Amr Ibn-Shás El-Asadee says,
ta*ak~arotu layolaY laAta Hiyna A@dikaArihaA
waqado HuniYa AlA^aDolaAEu Dul~N bitaDolaAli
[I remembered Leylà when it was not a time for remembering her, the ribs having become bent by the bending of the back with age: it was a vain, misleading thing]. (S, O.) ― -b6- Dul~u A^aDolaAlK: see Dil~apN.
huwa Dil~u bonu Dil~K * : see Dul~N. ― -b2- Dil~u A^aDolaAlK: see Dil~apN.

Dal~apN *
Confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see the right course: (K:) [or error: for] one says, faEala *`lika Dal~apF He did that in error (fiY DalaAlapK): and *ahaba Dal~apF He went away not knowing whither he went: (TA:) and fulaAnN yaluwmuniY Dal~apF Such a one blames me wrongly: (S, O:) [or, behind my back, or in my absence: for] Dal~apN signifies
also speech respecting a person behind his back, or in his absence; relating to good and to evil. (M, K, TA.) -A2- [Freytag explains it as signifying also One in whom is no good, on the authority of Meyd.]

Dul~apN *
Skill in guiding, or directing aright, in journeying. (Fr, K, * TA.)

Dil~apN * : see DalaAlN. ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa A@bonuhu liDil~apK (tropical:) He is his son unlawfully begotten, or not trueborn. (AZ, A, K, TA.) ― -b3- *ahaba damuhu Dil~apF (tropical:) His blood went unrevenged, or without retaliation. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And huwa tiboEu Dil~apK, (Th, O, K, TA,) with kesr to the t and to the D, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, tabaEu,] and tiboEN Dil~apN, (K, TA,) thus related by IAar, (TA,) but the former only accord. to Th, (TA in art. tbE,) (assumed tropical:) He is a follower of women: (TA in that art.:) or he is one in whom is no good, and with whom is no good: (IAar, Th, TA:) or he is a very cunning man (daAhiyapN), one in whom is no good; (IAar, O, K, TA;) and so tiboEu Sil~apK, (O, L, TA,) as some relate it; (L, TA;) and in like manner, A^aDolaAlK ↓ Dil~u, (Lh, O, K, TA,) and A^aDolaAlK ↓ Dul~u, (K, TA,) and Sil~u A^aSolaAlK, [q. v.,] which is with kesr only, (K, TA,) a phrase similar to Dir~u A^aDoraArK. (TA in art. Dr.)
DalalN * : see DalaAlN. ― -b2- Also Water (O, K) running (K) beneath a rock, which the sun does not reach: (O, K:) one says maA='N DalalN: (O:) or running among trees. (K.) [See also DalalN.]

DalaAlN * [an inf. n. of 1: used as a simple subst.,] Error; contr. of ra$aAdN, (S, O, TA,) and of hudFY; (K, TA;) as also ↓ DalaAlapN, (S, O, K,) and ↓ Dal~N, and ↓ Dul~N, and ↓ Dil~apN, and ↓ DalalN, and ↓ DaloDalapN, (K,) and ↓ DulaDilapN, (O, TA,) and ↓ A^uDoluwlapN, (K,) of which last the pl. is A^aDaAliylu, (Lth, O, TA,) as in the saying tamaAdaY fiY A^aDaAliyli AlhawaY [He persevered in the errors of love], (TA,) or A^aDaAliylu, as some say, has no sing., or its sing. is supposed, or has been heard, and is A^uDoluwlapN or A^uDoluwlN or A_iDoliylN or some other form: (MF, TA:) the primary signification of AlD~alaAlu is the going away from the right course, or direction: (Ham p. 357:) or it signifies, accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál, the loss, or missing, of that which brings, or conducts, to the object sought: or, as some say, the pursuing a way that will not bring, or conduct, to that object: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the deviating from the right way: and it is said to be any deviation from that which is right, intentional or unintentional, little or much; because the right and approved way is very difficult; wherefore it may be used of him who commits any mistake whatever, and is imputed to prophets and to unbelievers, though between the DlAl of the former and that of the latter is a wide difference: and in another point of view, it is of two sorts; one is in the speculative departments of knowledge, as in acquaintance with the unity of God, and with the prophetic function or office, and the like, indicated in the Kur iv. 135; or it is in the practical departments of knowledge, as in acquaintance with the ordinances of the law, that is, religious services. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A state of perdition: so in the Kur liv. 24: (S, O:) [and in like manner ↓ DalaAlapN; for] DalaAlapu AlEamali signifies The annulled and lost state of work. (TA.) ― -b3- And Absence, or a state of concealment. (Msb. [This is there said to be the primary signification.]) ― -b4- huwa AlD~alaAlu bonu Alt~alaAli see expl. voce Dul~N.
DaluwlN * : see DaAl~N.

DalaAlapN * : see DalaAlN, in the beginning, and near the end, of the paragraph. One says, hiYa AlD~alaAlapu waAlt~alaAlapu; (S, O;) in which the latter noun is an imitative sequent. (S and K in art. tl.)

Dil~iylN * A man (S, O) who errs, strays, goes astray, or deviates from the right way or course, much, or often: (S, O, K:) or (tropical:) who errs, &c., much, or often, in religion: (TA:) and ↓ muDal~alN, (S, TA,) which in some of the copies of the S is written thus and also muDal~il, (TA,) signifies the same; (S, TA;) or one who is not disposed, or directed, to good; in the K, Al~*Y lA yuwaf~iY bixayorK, [or yuwfiY bxyr, as in the CK,] but correctly Al~*Y lA yuwaf~aqu lixayorK; or, as some say, a committer of errors, and of false, wrong, or vain, actions: and Dil~iylN is also expl. as signifying one who will not desist from error. (TA.) Imra-el-Keys was called Almaliku AlD~il~iylu [The much-erring king], (S, O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AlD~aliylu,]) and ↓ Almlk AlmuDal~alu. (K.)

DaAl~N *
Erring, straying, or going astray; deviating from the right way or course, or from that which is right; missing, or losing, the right way; or losing his way; (S, * Msb, TA;) and ↓ DaluwlN is syn. therewith; (K;) [or rather with Dil~iylN, accord. to a general rule:] pl. of the former Dul~aAlN, [of which see an ex. in a verse cited voce risolN,] and DuAl~uwna: [in the Kur i. last verse,] some read walaA A@lD~aA^al~iyna, to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters. (TA.) You say DaAl~N taAl~N; (S, O;) in which the latter epithet is an imitative sequent. (S and K in art. tl.) ― -b2- [Also Becoming lost; &c. ― -b3- And Forgetting. It is said that] waA^anaA mina A@lD~aAl~iyna [in the Kur xxvi. 19] means (assumed tropical:) I being of those that forgot. (K, TA.) And AimraA^apN DaAl~apN means (assumed tropical:) A woman forgetting the days of her menstruation. (Mgh.)

DaAl~apN * an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, (IAth, TA,) A stray; i. e. a beast that has strayed: (S, O, TA:) or a camel remaining in a place where it is lost, without an owner (K, TA) that is known: (TA:) or a lost animal (IAth, Msb, TA) or other thing, whatever it be: (IAth, TA:) applied to the male and to the female, (S, O, Msb, K,) and to two and to a pl. number: (TA;) and it has for its pl. DawaAl~u, (Msb, TA,) like dawaAb~u pl. of daAb~apN. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., DaAl~apu Almuw^omini Haraqu Aln~aAri [expl. in art. Hrq]. (TA.) And one says, AlHikomapu DaAl~apu Almuw^omini (assumed tropical:) [Wisdom is the object of persevering quest of the believer]; meaning that the believer ceases not to seek wisdom like as a man seeks his stray. (TA.)

DalaDilN * and ↓ DalaDilapN, (As, S,) as though contracted from DalaADilN [and DalaADilapN], (S,) or A^aroDN ↓ DalaDilapN and DalaDilN [in the CK DalaDalapN and SalaDalN] and ↓ DulaDilapN and ↓ DulaDilN (K) and ↓ DulaADilN (Lh, K) and DuloDulapN, (IDrd, K,) Rugged land or ground. (As, S, K.) And makaAnN DalaDilN, originally DalaADiylu, A hard, stony place. (Fr, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (so in the K,) i. e. (TA) DalaDilN and ↓ DalaDilapN, accord. to As, (O, TA,) or ↓ DulaDilapN, (S, O, TA,) [said to be] the only instance of its kind among reduplicate words, (S, O, TA, [in which last the same assertion is quoted from the T, app. in relation to the last, or last but one, of these words,]) and, as in the Jm, ↓ DuloDulapN, (O, TA,) A stone, (As, S, O,) or stones, (K,) such as a man can lift from the ground and carry: (As, S, O, K:) or, accord. to the T, DlDlp [thus in the TA, app. ↓ DalaDilapN or ↓ DulaDilapN,] signifies any stone such as a man can lift from the ground and carry, or above that, smooth, found in the interiors of valleys. (TA.)
DulaDilN * : see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- Also, (IAar, O, TA,) in the K, erroneously, SulaDilapN, (TA.) and ↓ DulaADilN, A skilful guide of the way. (IAar, O, K, TA.)
DaloZalapN * : see DalaAlN.

DuloDulapN * : see DalaDilN, in two places. ― -b2- DalaADilu AlmaA='i, (O, K,) and SalaASiluhu, (O,) [said in the O, in this art., to be pls. of which the sings. are DulaDilapN and SulaSilapN, but the sings. are correctly DuloDulapN and SuloSulapN, (see the latter of these two in its proper art.,)] The remains of water: (O, K:) so says Lh. (O.)
DalaDilapN * : see DalaDilN, in four places.
DulaDilapN * : see DalaAlN: ― -b2- and maDal~apN: ― -b3- and DalaDilN, in three places.
DulaADilN * : see DalaDilN: -A2- and DulaDilN.
A^uDoluwlapN * : see DalaAlN.

waqaEa fiY waAdiY tuDul~ila * , (Ks, S, O, K, *) like tuxuy~iba and tuhul~ika, all imperfectly decl., (S, O,) and tuDal~ila, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) and taDal~ila, with two fet-hahs, and tiDil~ili, with two kesrehs, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, TA,) meaning AlbaATil [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He fell into that which was vain, unreal, nought, futile, or the like, and consequently, into disappointment]: (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to the A, waqaEuwA fY wAdY tDl~l means (tropical:) They perished. (TA.)

TariyqN muDil~N *
A road that causes to go astray, or to deviate from the right course. (TA.) And, accord. to As, muDil~N signifies A land (A^aroDN) in which one loses his way. (TA. [See also the next paragraph.]) [Hence,] fitonapN muDil~apN means [A trial, or sedition, or discord, &c.,] that causes men to go astray, or to deviate from that which is right. (TA.) And [hence also,] AlmuDil~u means The saraAb [or mirage]. (TA.)

maDal~apN * a subst. like majobanapN and maboxalapN [i. e., as such, signifying A cause of erring, straying, going astray, or deviating from the right way or course or from that which is right, &c.]: (TA:) [and used in the manner of an epithet:] one says A^aroDN maDal~apN A land that causes one to err, &c.: (TA:) or, as also ↓ maDil~apN, (S, O, Msb, K, TA, [in the CK miDal~apN,]) and ↓ DulaDilapN, (O, K,) a land in which one errs, or strays, from the [right] way; (S, O, Msb, K; *) in which one does not find the right way: and xaroqN mDl~pN [A desert, or farextending desert, &c., in which one errs, &c.]: it is used alike as masc. and fem. and pl.: but one says also A^araDuwna mDl~AtN. (TA.)
maDil~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
muDal~alN * : see Dil~iylN, in two places.

mutaDaAl~N * [part. n. of 6, q. v.]. One says, A_in~aka tahodiY AlD~aAl~a walaA tahodiY AlmutaDaAl~a [Verily thou wilt direct aright the erring, &c., but thou wilt not direct aright him who feigns himself to be erring, &c.]. (S, O.)

1 DalaEa * , aor.
DalaEa , (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. DaloEN, (S, O, Msb,) It, or (assumed tropical:) he, inclined, or declined: (S, O, K:) it, or (assumed tropical:) he, declined, or deviated, from that which was right, or true: (S, O, Msb, K:) (assumed tropical:) he acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (S, * O, * K.) You say, DalaEa Eanohu (tropical:) He deviated, or turned away, from him, or it; or he did so, acting wrongfully, &c.: and DalaEa Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) he acted wrongfully, &c., against him. (TA.) And DaloEuka maEa fulaAnK (S, O, Msb, * K *) (assumed tropical:) Thy inclining, (S, O, Msb, K,) and thy love, or desire, (S, O,) is with such a one [i. e. in unison with that of such a one]. (S, O, Msb, * K: * in the Msb and K, maEahu is put in the place of maEa fulaAnK.) And laA tanoqu$i Al$~awokapa biAl$~awokapi faA_in~a DaloEahaA maEahaA, (S, O, K,) or bimivolihaA [in the place of bAl$wkp], (Meyd,) [lit. Extract not thou the thorn by means of the thorn, or by means of the like of it, for its inclination is with it,] meaning, demand not aid, in the case of thy want, of him who is more benevolent to the person from whom the object of want is sought than he is to thee: (Meyd:) a prov.: (S, Meyd, O:) applied to the man who contends in an altercation with another, and says, “ Appoint thou between me and thee such a one; ” pointing to a man who loves what he [i. e. the opponent of the speaker] loves: (S, O, K:) the author of the K adds, it is said that it should by rule be DalaEaka, for they say DaliEa maEa fulaAnK, like fariHa, [as though meaning he inclined with such a one,] but they have contracted it; which is wonderful, in consideration with his having mentioned shortly before, DalaEa, like manaEa, as signifying maAla. (TA.) One says also, xaASamotu fulaAnFA fakaAna DaloEuka EalaY~a i. e. (assumed tropical:) [I contended in an altercation with such a one and] thy inclining [was against me]. (S, O.) ― -b2- DaliEa, aor.
DalaEa , (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. DalaEN, (Mgh, Msb,) means It (a sword, K, or a thing, Msb) was, or became, crooked, or curved: (Mgh, Msb, K:) and ↓ tDl~E may mean the same: (Ham p. 80:) a poet says, (namely, Mohammad Ibn-'Abd-Allah El-Azdee, TA,)
waqado yaHomilu Als~ayofa Almujar~aba rab~uhu
EalaY DalaEK fiY matonihi wahowa qaATiEu
[And verily, or sometimes, or often, its owner bears the tried sword, notwithstanding crookedness in its broad side, it being sharp]: (S, O:) and (K) DalaEN signifies the being crooked, or curved, by nature; (S, O, K;) as also DaloEN; whence the saying, laA^uqiyman~a DalaEaka and DaloEaka [I will assuredly straighten thy natural crookedness]: (K:) thus in the copies of the K; but this is a mistake, occasioned by the author's seeing in the T and M laA^uqiyman~a DalaEaka and SalaEaka meaning Eawajaka, and his imagining both these nouns to be with D and to differ in the manner stated above: (TA:) you say, DaliEa, aor.
DalaEa , inf. n. DalaEN i. e. he, or it, was, or became, crooked, or curved, by nature: (S, O:) or DalaEN in the camel is like gamozN in horses or the like, [meaning the limping, or halting, or having a slight lameness, in the hind leg,] and the verb is DaliEa; and the epithet [or part. n.] is ↓ DaliEN: (K:) or this is rather the explanation of DaloEN, with Z; (TA;) [or as Mtr says,] DaloE as meaning what resembles EarajN [or natural lameness] is correctly ZaloE: (Mgh:) but when it (i. e. the crookedness, TA) is not natural, one says, DalaEa, like manaEa, (K, TA,) [but this seems rather to relate to the meaning of “ limping, ” agreeably with what I have cited above from the Mgh,] and the inf. n. is DaloEN: (TA:) and the epithet [or part. n.] is ↓ DaAliEN. (K.) -A2- DaluEa, [aor.
DaluEa ,] inf. n. DalaAEapN, He (a man, S, O, Msb, [and app. also a horse and the like, see its part. n. DaliyEN,]) was, or became, strong, or powerful; (S, O, Msb, K;) and strong, hard, or firm, in the A^aDolaAE [or ribs]. (S, O, K. [The latter is said in Har p. 6 to be the primary meaning; and the former, metaphorical.]) -A3- DalaEa as syn. with taDal~aEa: see the latter. -A4- DalaEa fulaAnFA He struck such a one upon his DilaE [or rib]. (K.)

2 Dal~aEa see 4, in two places. ― -b2- taDoliyEu AlA^aEomaAli is said by some to mean (assumed tropical:) The making deeds to deviate from the right, or direct, way or course: and by some to mean (assumed tropical:) the making them heavy, or burdensome. (Har p. 77.) ― -b3- taDoliyEu Alv~awobi signifies The figuring the garment, or piece of cloth, with the form of A^aDolaAE [or ribs]. (S, O, K.) [See also the pass. part. n., below.]

4 ADlEhu * , (K,) inf. n. A_iDolaAEN, (S, O,) It, or he, made it, or (assumed tropical:) him, to incline, or decline; (S, O, K;) [and so ↓ Dl~Ehu; for] AlA_iDolaAEu and Alt~aDoliyEu signify AlA_imaAlapu. (Har p. 77.) ― -b2- [And It, or he, made it, or him, to be crooked, or curved; and so ↓ Dl~Ehu; for] AlA_iDolaAEu and Alt~aDoliyEu signify also Alt~aEowiyju. (Har ubi suprà.) ― -b3- [Hence,] one says also, A^aDolaEatohu AlxuTuwbu, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Affairs, or great or grievous affairs,] burdened him [as though making him to incline, or curving him]. (TA.) -A2- See also 8.

5 tDl~E * : see 1, in the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Also,] (S, O, K,) and ↓ DalaEa, like manaEa, (K,) said of a man, (S, O,) He became filled, (S, O, K,) or what was between his A^aDolaAE [or ribs] became filled, (TA,) with food, (S, O, K,) or drink: (S, O:) or with drink so that the water reached his A^aDolaAE, (K, TA,) and they became swollen out in consequence thereof: (TA in explanation of the former verb:) and the former verb is also expl. as meaning he drank much, so that his side and his ribs became stretched. (TA.) And tDl~E mina AlT~aEaAmi He became filled with the food; as though it filled his ribs. (Msb.)

8 AlAiDoTilaAEu * is from AlD~alaAEapu [inf. n. of DaluEa] meaning “ the being strong, or powerful; ” (ISk, S, O, and Har p. 391;) AlAiDoTilaAEu biAl$~aYo'i signifying The raising the thing upon one's back, and rising with it, and having strength, or power, sufficient for it. (Har ibid.) And you say, ADTlE biHamolihi, meaning He had strength, or power, to bear it, or carry it. (Mgh, and Har p. 645.) [See also the part. n., below.] And biAlA^amori ↓ A^aDolaEa (assumed tropical:) He had strength, or power, sufficient for the affair; as though his ribs had strength to bear it. (Msb.)
DaloEN * : see DilaEN, first sentence.
DiloEN * : see DilaEN, first and last sentences.

DalaEN * The weight, or burden, of debt, that bends the bearer thereof. (IAth, O, K.) And Strength, or power; (As, S, O, Msb, K;) a subst. in this sense, from DaluEa; (Msb;) and the bearing, or endurance of that which is heavy, or burdensome. (As, S, O, K.) ― -b2- Also inf. n. of DaliEa [q. v.]. (Mgh, Msb, K.)

DaliEN *
Crooked, or curved, by nature. (S, O, TA.) And applied to a spear as meaning Crooked, or curved; not straightened: (TA:) or, so applied, inclining, or bending: (Ham p. 80:) and ↓ DaliyEN and ↓ DaAliEN, so applied,
[likewise] mean crooked, or curved. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph.

DilaEN * and ↓ DiloEN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the former of the dial. of El-Hijáz and the latter of the dial. of Temeem, (Msb, TA,) and ↓ DaloEN, which is the only form, or almost the only one, that is used by the vulgar, is said by MF to be mentioned by some one or more of the commentators, but not known in the lexicons, (TA;) [A rib;] a certain appertenance of an animal, (Msb,) well known; (K;) the curved thing of the side; (TA;) a single bone of the bones of the side: (Mgh, Msb:) of the fem. gender, (Msb, K, TA,) accord. to common repute; or, as some say, masc.; or, accord. to some, whose opinion in this case is preferred by Ibn-Málik and others, of both genders: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] DuluwEN and [of pauc.] A^aDolaAEN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and A^aDoluEN, (O, Msb, K,) and A^aDaAliEu also is a pl. of DilaEN, or, as some say, of [its pl.] A^aDoluEN. (TA.) DilaEu Alxalofi [and Alxilofi] is [The rib] in the lowest part of the side [of a man, i. e. the lowest rib; and the hindmost rib in a beast]: (TA:) and signifies also A burn in the part behind what is thus termed. (O, K, TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A piece of stick or wood; syn. EuwdN; [erroneously supposed by Golius and Freytag to mean here the musical instrument thus called;] (IAar, O, K;) so in a saying of the Prophet to a woman, respecting a blood-stain on a garment, Hut~iyhi biDilaEK (assumed tropical:) [Scrape thou it off with a piece of stick]: (IAar, O:) or (assumed tropical:) such as is wide and curved; as being likened to the DilaE (O, K) of an animal. (K.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) An oblong piece of a melon; (O, * K, TA;) as being likened to the DilaE [properly thus called]. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) A trap for birds; because of its gibbous shape: so in the saying, naSaba DilaEFA lilT~ayori [He set up a trap for the birds]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- And The base, or lower part, of a raceme of a palm-tree. (TA in art. Ehn.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) A line that is made on the ground, after which another line is made, and then the space between these two is sown. (TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) A small mountain apart from others: (S, O, K:) or a small mountain, such as is not long: (TA:) or a low and narrow mountain, (Aboo-Nasr, S, O, K, TA,) long and extended: or, accord. to As, a small mountain, extending lengthwise upon the earth, not high. (TA.) And [the pl.] DuluwEN signifies (tropical:) Curved tracts of ground: or tracks (TaraAy^iq) of a [piece of stony ground such as is termed] Har~ap. (O, K, TA.) ― -b8- Also (assumed tropical:) An island in the sea; pl. A^aDolaAEN: or, as some say, it is the name of a particular island. (TA.) ― -b9- [In geometry, (assumed tropical:) A side of a rectilinear triangle or square or polygon. ― -b10- And (assumed tropical:) A square root; called in arithmetic ja*orN: see $aYo'N, near the end of the paragraph.] ― -b11- One says also, humo EalaY~a DilaEN jaAy^irapN, (S, A, O, K, in the last of which, between hm and ElY~ is inserted ka*aA,) and ↓ DiloEN is allowable, (S, TA,) meaning (tropical:) They are assembled against me with hostility: (A, TA:) the origin of which is the saying of AZ, one says, humo EalaY~N A_ilobN waAHidN [or A^alobN waAHidN] and SadoEN waAHidN and DilaEN waAHidN, meaning as above. (TA.)

DilaEapN *
A certain small fish, green (xaDoraA='), short in the bone. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

DaliyEN * : see DaliEN: ― -b2- and see also maDoluwEN, in three places. ― -b3- Also, applied to a man, (S, O, Msb,) Strong, or powerful; (S, O, Msb, K;) and strong, hard, or firm, in the A^aDolaAE [or ribs]: (S, O, K:) or, as some say, long in the A^aDolaAE, great in make, bulky; applied to any animal, even to a jinnee: (TA:) pl. DuloEN, (K,) or app., DuluEN [of which the former may be a contraction]. (TA.) And, applied to a horse, Complete, or perfect, in make or formation, large in the middle, thick in the [bones called] A^alowaAH, having many sinews: (ISk, S, O, K:) or, so applied, thick in the A^alowaAH; strong, hard, or firm, in the sinews: (Msb:) or, as some say, long in the ribs (AlA^aDolaAE), wide in the sides, large in the breast. (TA.) And DaliyEu Alfami A man large in the mouth: (Kt, O, K:) or wide therein: (A 'Obeyd, O, K:) expl. in the former sense, and in the latter, as applied to the Prophet; (O, TA;) width of the mouth, (Kt, O, K, TA,) and largeness thereof, (TA,) being commended by the Arabs, and smallness thereof being discommended by them; (Kt, O, K, TA;) whereas the Persians, or foreigners, (AlEajam,) commend smallness thereof: (TA:) or having large teeth, closely and regularly set together; (Sh, O, K;) and thus also expl., by Sh, as applied to the Prophet: (O, TA:) and DaliyEu Alv~FnaAyaA a man whose central incisors are thick. (TA.)

DaAliEN *
Inclining, or declining: (TA: [like ZiAliEN:]) declining, or deviating, from that which is right, or true: acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (S, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- See also DaliEN. ― -b3- And see 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph.
DawolaEN * (tropical:) Inclining with love or desire. (IAar, O, K, TA.)

A^aDolaEu * , applied to a man, [and accord. to the CK to a beast (daAb~ap) also,] Whose tooth is like the DilaE [or rib]; (Lth, O, K;) fem. DaloEaA='u [perhaps applied to the tooth, but more probably, I think, to a woman]; (TA;) and pl. DuloEN. (K.) ― -b2- Also, (O, [but accord. to the K “ or, ”]) Strong, thick, (O, K, TA,) large in make. (TA.) ― -b3- And Stronger, or more powerful. (O, * TA.)

muDoliEN * A load heavily burdening, or overburdening, (S, IAth, O, K, TA,) to the A^aDolaAE [or ribs]; (TA;) as though leaning, or bearing, upon the A^aDolaAE: (IAth, TA:) or a heavy load, which one is unable to bear; as also ↓ muDal~iEN. (Har p. 77.) [See also muZoliEN.] And, daAhiyapN muDoliEapN (tropical:) A calamity that heavily burdens, or overburdens, and breaks, the A^aDolaAE [or ribs]. (TA.) ― -b2- And daAb~apN muDoliEN A beast whose A^aDolaAE [or ribs] have not strength sufficient for the load. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, L, K.) ― -b3- See also muDoTaliEN.

muDal~aEN * A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with stripes, like thongs, or straps, (O, K, TA,) these being of A_iboriysam, or of qaz~, [i. e. silk, or raw silk,] wide, like A^aDolaAE [or ribs]: (TA:) or [simply] figured: (Lh, TA:) or variously woven, and thin: (TA:) or partly woven and partly left unwoven. (ISh, Az, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And qub~apN muDal~aEapN [A ribbed dome or cupola; i. e.] having the form of A^aDolaAE. (TA.)
muDal~iEN * : see muDoliEN.

maDoluwEN *
Having the DilaE [or rib] broken. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ― -b2- And qawosN maDoluwEapN A bow in the wood of which are a bending (EaTofN) and an evenness (taqaw~umN, as in the O and K, or taqowiymN, as in the L), [app. towards each extremity,] the rest of it (saAy^iruhaA) being similar to its kabid [which means its middle part, or part where it is grasped with the hand, or part against which the arrow goes, &c., for it is variously explained]; (O, K, TA;) so accord. to As, (O, TA,) and AHn; (TA;) as also ↓ DaliyEN, (O, K, TA,) and ↓ DaliyEapN; for which last, maDoluwEapN is erroneously repeated in the K; [app. from its author finding it said in the O that such a bow is termed DaliyEN and maDoluwEapN; and in the TK, muDawolaEapN is substituted for it:] ↓ qawosN DaliyEapN is also expl. as meaning a thick bow. (TA.)

muDoTaliEN * is from AlD~alaAEapu [inf. n. of DaluEa]: so in the saying, fulaAnN muDoTaliEN bih`*aA AlA^amori i. e. Such a one is possessed of strength, or power, sufficient for this affair: so says ISk: and he adds that one should not say muT~aliEN: Aboo-Nasr Ahmad Ibn- Hátim says, one says huwa muDoTaliEN bih`*aA AlA^amori and muT~aliEN lh [also]; AlAiDoTilaAEu being from AlD~alaAEapu meaning Alquw~apu; and AlAiT~ilaAEu being from AlEuluw~u, from the saying AiT~alaEotu Alv~aniy~apa meaning EalawotuhaA [I ascended upon the mountain, or mountain-road, termed vaniy~ap]; i. e. he is one who has ascendancy with respect to this affair, who is master of it: (S, O, TA:) Lth expressly allows muT~aliEN for muDoTaliEN by the incorporation of the D into the [letter that is originally] t, so that the two together become T with teshdeed. (TA.) And lih`*aA AlA^amori ↓ huwa muDoliEN means the same as muDoTaliEN as first expl. above, i. e. He is possessed of strength, or power, sufficient for this affair. (O, K. [In both, in this instance, lih`*aA, not bih`*aA.]) In the phrase A_i*aA kaAna muDoTaliEFA EalaY Haq~ihi [If he be possessed of power, or ability, to obtain his right, or due], it seems that mDTlEA is made trans. by means of ElY because made to imply the meaning of qaAdirFA or muqotadirFA. (Mgh.) ↓ musotaDoliEN,
likewise, signifies Having strength, or power. (TA.)
musotaDoliEN * : see what next precedes.

1 Dam~ahu * , [aor.
Damu3a ,] inf. n. Dam~N, He drew it, put it, brought it, or gathered it, together; collected it; or contracted it. (Msb.) You say, Dam~a $ayoy^FA A_ilaY $aYo'N, (S, MA, K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, He drew, put, or brought, together [and joined or adjoined] a thing to a thing. (MA, K.) And Damamotuhu A_ilaY SadoriY [I drew him, or pressed him, to my bosom;] I embraced him. (TA.) And Dam~a Alqawomu, [A^anofusahumo being app. understood, or perhaps it is correctly Dum~a,] The people, or party, collected themselves together, or became collected. (TA.) And Aall~ahum~a A@Domumo na$ariY (assumed tropical:) O God, compose what is discomposed, or disorganized, [lit. bring together what is scattered,] of my affairs. (K * and TA in art. n$r.) And Dum~a janaAHaka Eani Aln~aAsi (assumed tropical:) [Contract thy side from men;] meaning be thou gentle, courteous, easy to deal with, or compliant, to men. (TA.) And Dum~ato Ealayohi AlA^anaAmilu The ends of the fingers were drawn together upon it. (Ham p. 21. [See also a similar phrase in what follows, with the verb in the act. form, virtually meaning the same.]) ― -b2- [Also He compacted it: and he compressed it. ― -b3- And He, or it, comprised it; or enclosed it: and he grasped it: as also Dam~a Ealayohi, in both of these senses.] You say, Dam~ato Ealayohi AlA^anaAmilu The ends of the fingers grasped it. (Ham p. 21. [See a similar phrase above.]) And Dam~a EalaY AlmaAli He took [or grasped] all the property. (TA.) And Dam~a mino maAlihi He took of his property. (TA.) ― -b4- [Dam~a AlHarofa, aor. and inf. n. as above, a conventional phrase in lexicology and grammar, He pronounced the letter with the vowel-sound termed Dam~: and he marked the letter with the sign of that vowel-sound.]

3 DAm~hu * , (S, MA, K, TA,) inf. n. muDaAm~apN, (TA,) He became, or drew, near, or close, to him; he became conjoined with him; (MA;) i. q. A_ilayohi ↓ AnDm~; (S, * MA, K; *) and ↓ tDAm~. (K.) And DaAmamotu Alr~ajula I continued conjoined with the man occupied in one affair. (TA.) And DAm~ Al$~aYo'u A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i The thing became [adjoined to the thing, or] conjoined with the thing. (TA.) See also 6.
4 A^aDomamotuhu kitaAbFA A_ilaY A^axiY * [app. I made him, or it, to be accompanied by, or I made it to comprise, a letter to my brother]. (TA.)

5 taDam~amotuhu *
I took it, or devoured it, altogether. (TA in art. Eb.) [See also R. Q. 1.]

6 taDaAm~uwA *
They became, or drew, near, or close, together, or one to another; or became conjoined, one with another. (S, MA, TA. [See also 8.]) Hence the saying in a trad., laA taDaAm~uwna fiY ruw^oyatihi [originally tataDaAm~uwna]; but some relate it otherwise, saying ↓ lA tuDaAm~uwna; and some, lA tuDaAmuwna, from AlD~ayomu; (TA in this art.;) and some, lA tuDaAr~uwna; and some, lA tuDaAruwna, from AlD~ayoru. (TA in art. Dr: for explanations, see 3 in that art.) See also 3 above. [Hence,] tDAm~ fiY sujuwdihi wajuluwsihi [He drew himself together in his prostration and his sitting, in prayer]. (S, * and K in art. Hfz.)

7 AnDm~ *
It was, or became, drawn, put, brought, or gathered, together; collected; or contracted. (Msb.) AnDm~ A_ilayohi is syn. with DaAm~ahu, q. v. (S, * MA, K. *) [And it signifies also He adjoined himself, got him or got himself, betook him or betook himself, repaired, or resorted, to him, or it. And AnDm~ Ealayohi It became drawn together upon it. AnDm~ AlY ka*aA is expl. in the TA as meaning AinoTawaY: but I think that AlY is evidently a mistranscription for EalaY; and that the meaning therefore is, It infolded such a thing, or enclosed it, like ADTm~ Elyh, q. v.]

8 ADTm~ Al$~aYo'a *
He drew, brought, or gathered, the thing to himself: (K:) the T is substituted for t because of the D. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, in a trad., ADTm~ baEoDuhumo A_ilaY baEoDK [They drew near, or close, one to another]. (TA. [See also 6.]) And, in another trad., ADTm~ Ealayohi Aln~aAsu The people, or men, pushed, pressed, crowded, or thronged, together upon him. (TA.) ― -b3- And ADTm~ Ealayohi It comprised it, or enclosed it. (K.) You say, AiDoTam~ato Ealayohi AlD~uluwEu The ribs comprised it, or enclosed it. (S. [See also 7.])

R. Q. 1 DamoDama EalaY AlmaAli *
He took all the property; (K;) as though he drew it, or gathered it, (Dam~ahu,) to himself. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- And DamoDama He (a man, TA) encouraged his heat; or became courageous in heart. (K, accord. to different copies.) ― -b3- And, said of a lion, He [roared, or] uttered a cry: (K, TA:) inf. n. DamoDamapN. (TA.)
Dam~N * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Msb, &c.) ― -b2- [As a conventional term of lexicology and grammar, A certain vowel-sound, well known.]

AlD~im~u * and ↓ AlD~imaAmu Severe calamity or misfortune; (K, TA;) accord. to Lth: (TA:) but app. mistranscriptions, and correctly with S [i. e. AlS~im~u and, by implication, AlS~imaAmu, but the latter is app. only SamaAmi, without the art., like qaTaAmi]; (K, TA;) so says Az. (TA.)

Dam~apN * [inf. n. un. of 1 (q. v.): and as such signifying] An embracing. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A number of horses assembled from every quarter for a race: (K, TA:) thus called because so assembled. (TA.) ― -b3- [And, as a conventional term in lexicology and grammar, The sign of the vowel-sound termed Dam~.]
DumaAmN * : see what next follows.

DimaAmN * , (S, KL,) with kesr; (S;) or ↓ DumaAmN, like guraAbN; (K;) [the former app. the right, being agreeable with analogy, like ribaATN and wivaAqN and A_isaArN and EiqaAlN &c.;] A thing, (S, K,) or thread, string, cord, or the like, (KL,) by means of which one thing is drawn, and joined, or adjoined, to another thing. (S, K, KL.) One says, Alt~aqowaY DimaAmu Alxayori kul~ihi [Piety is that which draws and attaches to its possessor every good thing]. (TA.) -A2- See also AlD~im~u, above.

DamuwmN *
Any valley along which one goes between two long hills of the kind termed A^akamap: or any valley flowing [with water] between two long hills of that kind: (so accord. to different copies of the K:) [the former explanation is app. the right; for] AHn says, when one goes along a valley between two long hills of the kind termed A^akamap, that places is termed AlD~amuwm. (TA.)
DamiymN * [i. q. ↓ maDomuwmN]. One says, A^arosalotu fulaAnFA wajaEalotu Damiymahu fulaAnFA [I sent such a one, and made such a one his adjunct]. (TA.)

DimaAmapN * : see A_iDomaAmapN. ― -b2- DimaAmataA AlmuSoHafi means The two sides [or boards] of the book, that embrace it between them. (T and M and TA voce daf~apN.) And in like manner, DimaAmataA Als~aroji and Alr~aHol [The two boards of the horse's saddle and of the camel's saddle, that embrace it between them]. (M ibid.)
Dam~aAmN * One who collects together the seed-produce. (TA.)
DaAm~N * act. part. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (TA.)

DaAm~apN * [a subst. from DaAm~N, rendered such by the affix p]. You say, nahaDa fulaAnN liloqitaAli wahuwa DaAm~apu qawomihi [Such a one rose and sped to fight, or to the fight, he being the musterer of his people, or party]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A want, or an object of want, that brings one and causes him to have recourse [to a thing]. (Meyd, in explanation of a prov. cited voce DaAy^imN, in art. Dym, q. v.)

DamoDamN * A lion that grasps everything; as also ↓ DumaADimN. (S.) [See also DamoDaAmN: and see what here follows.] ― -b2- Also, (S,) Angry; (S, K;) applied to a man: (S:) and, as also ↓ DumaADimN and ↓ SumaDimN, an angry lion: (K, TA:) or simply a lion: (TA:) and bold, or daring; (K, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b3- And Big, bulky, or corpulent: (K, TA:) but it is mentioned by IAar as with the unpointed S. (TA.)
DumaDimN * : see DamoDamN. ― -b2- Also Niggardly in the utmost degree. (IAar, TA.) [See also DumaADimN.]
DimoDimapN * : see zimozimapN and SimoSimapN.
DamoDaAmN * One who takes, or gets, everything within his grasp; (K, TA;) drawing it to him self. (TA.) [See also DamoDamN.]

DumaADimN * : see DamoDamN, in two places. ― -b2- Also
One who eats much; who has an inordinate appetite for food; who appropriates to himself exclusively of others: or who eats much, and does not become satiated. (TA.) ― -b3- And A niggardly man. (TA.) [See also DumaDimN.]

A_iDomaAmapN *
A bundle, (HuzomapN, Msb,) or number put, or joined, together, (TA,) i. q. A_iDobaArapN, (S, TA,) of books or writings; (S, Msb, TA;) as also ↓ DimaAmapN: (TA:) pl. of the former A^aDaAmiymu. (S.) You say, jaA='a fulaAnN biA_iDomaAmapK mino kutubK [Such a one brought a bundle of books or writings]. (S.) ― -b2- And A company, or collection, (S, K, TA,) of men, or people, not of one stock, but of different tribes mixed together; [and of horses;] as though collected and joined, one to another: pl. as above. (TA.) One says, farasN sab~aAqu AlA^aDaAmiymi i. e. [A horse that often outstrips] the collections (S, K) of horses. (K.) ― -b3- And its pl. A^aDaAmiymu signifies also Stones: (TA:) or collections of stones: (Mgh in art. SqE:) occurring in a trad. respecting the stoning of an adulterer. (Mgh, TA.)

maDam~N *
A place of assembling of military forces. (TA.)
maDomuwmN * pass. part. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (TA.) See also DamiymN.
munoDam~N * [part. n. of 7, q. v. ― -b2- Hence,] Lean; or slender and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly; as though one part thereof were drawn and adjoined to another. (TA.)
Q. 4 A_iDomaHal~a accord. to some, but Q. Q. accord. to most. AiDomaHal~a: see art. DHl.

Q. 4 AiDomaHan~a *
i. q. AiDomaHal~a [q. v. in art. DHl]; formed from the latter by substitution [of n for l: mentioned by Yaakoob. (TA: and mentioned in the K in art. DmHl.)
1 DamVxa see the next paragraph.

2 Dm~xhu biAlT~iybi * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. taDomiyxN; (S, A, K;) and ↓ Damaxahu, (ISd, TA,) aor.
Damuxa , (TK,) inf. n. DamoxN; (ISd, K;) He daubed, or smeared, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) him, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) or his body, (L, K,) with perfume, or some odoriferous or fragrant substance, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) copiously, (L,) so that it seemed to drip. (L, K.) It is said in a trad., kaAna yuDam~ixu raA^osahu biAlT~iybi He [Mohammad] used to daub, or smear, his head copiously with perfume. (L.)

5 tDm~x biAlT~iybi * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ AnDmx, and ↓ AiDoTamaxa, (K,) and ↓ AiD~amaxa, (L,) He daubed or smeared himself, or he became daubed or smeared, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) copiously, (L,) with perfume, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) so that it seemed to drip. (L, K.)
7 A_inoDamaxa see what next precedes.
8 AiDoTamaxa * , and its var. AiD~amaxa: see 5.
DimoxapN * A fat woman or she-camel. (K.) ― -b2- And Fresh ripe dates (ruTab [so in copies of the K, accord. to the TA raTob, app. a mistranscription,]) from which something drips.

1 Damada AljuroHa * , (S, A, L, K,) aor.
Damuda (S, L, K) and
Damida , (K,) inf. n. DamodN; (S, L;) and ↓ Dm~dhu, (A, K,) inf. n. taDomiydN; (TA;) He bound the wound (and in like manner one says of other things, L) with a DimaAd or DimaAdap i. e. a bandage, or fillet, (S, A, L, K,) or kerchief. (A.) This is the primary signification. (L.) And Damada raA^osahu, (L,) or biDimaAdK ↓ Dm~dhu, (Lth,) He wound a piece of rag round his head, after anointing it, or wetting it with water: (Lth, L:) and ↓ Dm~d raA^osahu, inf. n. taDomiydN, He bound his head with a fillet, or bandage, (S, A,) or a kerchief, (A,) or a piece of cloth, not a turban. (S.) And Damada AljuroHa, inf. n. DamodN, also signifies He applied a remedy [or dressing] to the wound, without bandaging it. (L.) And Eayonayohi biAlS~abiri ↓ Dm~d He applied aloes to his eyes. (L, from a trad.) And Damadaha biAlz~aEofaraAni waAlS~abiri He smeared him, or it, over, [or poulticed him, or it,] with saffron and aloes. (Az, L.) ― -b2- And AuDomudo Ealayoka viyaAbaka Bind thou upon thee thy garments, (Ibn-Málik, A,) and EimaAmataka [thy turban]. (A.) And A^ujido Damoda h`*aA AlEidoli Make thou good the binding of this half-load. (L.) ― -b3- And Damadahu (assumed tropical:) He struck him, or hit him, on his head with a staff or stick: (S, K:) sometimes used in this sense: (S:) or he cut, or wounded, (A, L,) him (L,) or it, i. e. his head, (A,) in the place of the turban, with a sword; syn. Eam~amahu. (A, L.) ― -b4- DamodN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The treating with gentleness, or blandishment; soothing, coaxing, wheedling, or cajoling; or striving, endeavouring, or desiring, to do so. (S, L, K,) ― -b5- And Damadato, (A, L,) aor
Damida and
Damuda , (L,) inf. n. DamodN (AA, S, L, K) and DimaAdN, (Fr, A, L,) (tropical:) She (a woman) took to herself two friends, (S, A, L, K,) or secret friends, or amorous associates, (A,) together: (S, A, L, K:) or she took another man beside her husband (AA, A, L) as her friend, or secret friend, or amorous associate; (A;) or two other men: (AA, L;) or she associated as a friend with two or three men in a time of drought, in order that she might eat with one and then with another so as to satiate herself. (Fr.) And Damadatohu, aor, as above, (assumed tropical:) She (a woman having a husband or a friend [or lover]) took him (another man) as her friend [or lover]. (L.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
turiydiyna kayomaA taDomidiyniY waxaAlidFA
wahalo yujomaEu Als~ayofaAni wayoHaki fiY gimodi
(assumed tropical:) [Thou desirest to take me as thy lover together with Khálid: but can the two swords (mercy on thee) be combined in one scabbard?]. (S, L.) And one says, DamadaAhaA (assumed tropical:) They both associated as friends [or lovers] with her, or made love to her. (L.) -A2- Damida, aor.
Damada , It dried; (Hr, L, K;) said of blood upon the throat of a slaughtered sheep or goat. (Hr, L.) -A3- Also, inf. n. DamadN, He acted wrongfully, or injuriously, or unjustly. (L.) ― -b2- And Damida Ealayohi, aor.
Damada , inf. n. DamadN, He bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him: (S, L, K: *) or held fast rancour, &c., against him in his heart. (L.) And He was angry with him: or vehemently enraged against him and angry with him: or he was enraged against him; i. e. one over whom he had power to vent his rage. (L.)
2 Dam~ada see the preceding paragraph, in four places.
4 A^aDomadahumo * (tropical:) He collected them together. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And ADmd AlEarofaju The [plant called] Erfj contained its xuwSap [q. v.] lying hidden within it, not yet appearing. (S, K. *)

5 tDm~d *
It (a wound) was bound with a bandage or fillet [or kerchief (see 1)]. (K.) It (a man's head) was bound with a bandage or fillet [or kerchief] or with a piece of cloth, not a turban. (S.) ― -b2- [And tDm~d bihi He used it, or applied it, as a poultice or the like.]

DamodN *
Such as is fresh, or moist, of herbage or trees: and such as is dry thereof: (S, * L, K: *) thus having two contr. meanings: (K:) or fresh and dry herbage mixed together: and herbage of which every twig, or shoot, has put forth its leaves. (L.) DamodN mina Ald~ami means Such as is dry of blood; dry blood. (L.) ― -b2- Also The better, or best, and the worse, or worst, of sheep or goats: (S, L, K:) or the young, and the old: or such as are in a sound, or good, state, and such as are in an unsound, or a bad, state: or the slender, and the large. (L.) A man says to his creditor, A^aqoDiyka mino Damodi h`*ihi Alganami [I will pay thee with some of the better, or best, or of the worse, or worst, &c., of these sheep or goats]. (S.)
DimodN * (assumed tropical:) A friend; or a true, or sincere, friend; or a special, or particular, friend. (K.)

DamadN *
A remainder, that is due to one, of a fine for blood, or of any other debt. (S, K.) One says, lanaA Einoda fulaAnK DamadN A remainder of a fine for blood, or of another debt, is owed to us by such a one. (S.)

EabodN DamadapN *
A bulky, thick, slave. (El-Hejeree, TA.)

DimaAdN *
A bandage, or fillet, (S, A, K,) or a kerchief, (A,) that is bound upon a wound; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ DimaAdapN: (S, K:) and a piece of rag that is wound round the head, after anointing it, or wetting it with water: (Lth, L:) and sometimes put upon the head on account of a headache: pl. DamaAy^idu. (L.) ― -b2- Also A remedy [or dressing, such as a poultice and the like,] that is applied to a wound. (Ibn-Háni.)

DimaAdapN * : see DimaAdN. ― -b2- A^anaA EalaY DimaAdapK mina AlA^amori
means I have become on the point, or verge, of the affair, or event. (S.)

DaAmidN *
i. q. laAzimN [Cleaving, clinging, holding fast, &c.]. (AHn.)

miDomadapN * [A sort of yoke;] a piece of wood which is put upon the necks of the two bulls [in ploughing], having at each extremity a perforation, and between the two perforations, in its upper side, a notch [app. for the tying of the beam of the plough thereto so that it may not shift from the middle], each of the perforations having a string put into it with the two ends thereof coming forth beneath the mDmdp, and each end of the string having a [short] staff, or stick, tied to it; the neck of the bull being put between the two staves, or sticks. (TA.)

1 Damara * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
Damura ; (S, Msb, K;) and Damura; (S, Msb, K;) inf. n. DumuwrN, of the former, and DumorN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the former also, (A, Mgh,) or of the latter, (Msb,) [also written DumurN, (see an ex., voce nahaArN,)] He (a horse, [&c.,] S, A, &c.) was, or became, lean, or light of flesh: (S:) or slender, and lean: (Msb:) or lean, and lank in the belly: (A, K:) or lank in the belly by reason of leanness: (Mgh:) and ↓ ADTmr signifies the same. (S, K.) [See also 5 and 8.] ― -b2- Also, inf. n. DumuwrN, He became lean and weak. (TA.) ― -b3- Damura AlEinabu (assumed tropical:) The grapes became withered, so as to be neither fresh grapes nor raisins. (Sgh.) ― -b4- Damarati AlHinoTapu (assumed tropical:) The wheat, being parched over the fire, became contracted and small. (Mgh.)

2 Dm~rhu * , inf. n. taDomiyrN, He made him (a horse) lean, or light of flesh; [&c.;] as also ↓ ADmrhu. (S.) ― -b2- He prepared him (i. e. a horse) for racing, [or for a military expedition, (see muDam~irN,)] by feeding him with food barely sufficient to sustain him, after he had become fat; as also ↓ ADmrhu. (Msb:) he fed him with food barely sufficient to sustain him, after he had become fat; as also ↓ ADmrhu: (K:) or he fed him with fodder so that he became fat, and then reduced him to food barely sufficient to sustain him; which is done during forty days: (S:) or he saddled him, and put on him a housing, in order that he might sweat under it, and so lose his flabbiness, and become firm in flesh; and then mounted upon him a light boy or young man, to make him run, but not to make him go so quick a pace as that which is termed Eanaq; by the doing of which, one becomes in no fear of his losing his breath in running, and a quick run does not cut him short: this (says AM) is what I have seen the Arabs practise; and they term it taDomiyrN, and also ↓ miDomaArN. (T, L.) ― -b3- Also He, or it, weakened, and subdued, and diminished, him: and the same signification is assigned to it [tropically] when the objective complement is a word denoting a sensation or passion. (TA.) ― -b4- Alt~aDomiyru also signifies The plaiting well, and the anointing well, the lock of hair termed Damiyrap. (TA.)

4 A^aDomara see 2, in three places. -A2- ADmrhu signifies also He determined, or resolved, upon it, fiY Damiyrihi in his heart, or mind. (Msb.) ― -b2- He conceived it in his heart, or mind. (MA, KL.) ― -b3- He concealed it, syn. A^asar~ahu, (A,) or A^axofaAhu, (K,) fiY qalobihi in his heart, (A,) or fY nafosihi in his mind. (S.) ― -b4- [And hence, He suppressed it, (namely a word or the like,) meaning it to be understood. ― -b5- And hence also ADmr meaning He made use of a pronoun.] ― -b6- And ADmr Sarofa AlHarofi [He suppressed the vowel of the final letter;] he made the movent [final] letter quiescent. (TA.) ― -b7- And A^aDomaratuhu AlbilaAdu (tropical:) The lands, or countries, hid him, by his having travelled far: (A:) and ADmrth AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) the earth hid him, either by reason of travel, or by death. (K, TA.) -A3- ADmr is also syn. with AisotaqoSaY [q. v.]. (O, K.) [Accord. to the TK, one says ADmr Al$~aYo'a meaning AstqSAhu.]

5 tDm~r wajohuhu *
His face became shrivelled, or contracted, by emaciation. (Sgh, L, K.)

7 AnDmr *
It (a branch, or twig,) became dried up. (TA.)
8 ADTmr * : see 1. ― -b2- Also He, (a horse,) after having been fed until he had become fat, was reduced to food barely sufficient to sustain him. (TA.) [See 2.]

DamorN * : see DaAmirN, in two places. ― -b2- Hence, in the opinion of ISd, as he says in the M, it is also applied to a horse as meaning daqiyqu AlHajaAjayoni [i. e. Thin in the bones surrounding, or projecting over, the cavities of the eyes: in the TA, AlhjAjyn, an obvious mistranscription; and in the TK, AlHjAjtyn, which is also wrong]: on the authority of Kr: in the copies of the K, AlHaAjibayoni. (TA.) ― -b3- And Narrow; (O, K;) applied to a place. (O.) ― -b4- And i. q. ↓ DamiyrN [app. in the first of the senses assigned to the latter below]. (O, K: in the CK Dim~iyr.) See also. muDomarN.

DamoraAnN * (S, O, K) and ↓ DumoraAnN (TA) A certain plant, (S, O, K,) of the shrub-kind (mino diq~i Al$~ajari): (K:) or of the kind called HamoD: AM says, it is not of the shrub-kind, and has [what are termed] hadab [q. v.] like the hadab of the A^aroTaY: (TA:) AHn says, it resembles the rimov, except that it is yellow (A^aSofaru [app. a mistranscription for A^aSogaru i. e. smaller]), and it has little wood, [and] the small and dry parts of its branches are fed upon [by the camels] (yuHotaTabu): he adds, on the authority of the ancient Arabs of the desert, that it is [of the kind called] HamoD, green, lank, pleasing to the camels: and Aboo-Nasr says that it is of the kind called HamoD. (O.) -A2- See also what next follows.

DumoraAnu * (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K, TA) and ↓ DamoraAn, thus, with fet-h, as said by As on the authority of ISk; each of the names of dogs; (TA;) a name of a male dog; (O, K;) not of a bitch, as J asserts it to be. (K.) -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

DimaArN *
A place, or a valley, that is depressed, concealing him who is journeying in it. (O.) [Accord. to the K, AlD~imaAru is “ A place; ” i. e. the name of a certain place.] ― -b2- maAlN DimaArN Property of which one hopes not for the return: (K:) or absent property of which one hopes not for the return: (A 'Obeyd, Msb, TA:) if not absent, it is not thus called. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b3- dayonN DimaArN A debt of which the payment is not hoped for: (S:) or for the payment of which no period is fixed. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- EaTaA='N DimaArN A gift that is not hoped for. (A.) ― -b5- waEodN DimaArN, (S,) and EidapN DimaArN, (A, K, [mn AlEa*Abi in the CK being a mistranscription for mina AlEidaAti, as in other copies of the K and in the TA, in which latter is added that EidaAt is pl. of EidapN, which is syn. with waEodN,]) A promise of which the fulfilment is not hoped for: (S, A:) or of which the fulfilment is delayed. (K.) ― -b6- DimaArN also signifies Anything of which one is not confident, or sure. (S.) ― -b7- And A debt of which the payment is deferred by the creditor to a future period; or a sale upon credit, in which the payment is deferred to a definite period; or a postponement, or delay, as to the time of the payment of a debt or of the prince of a thing sold &c.; syn. nasiyoy^apN. (Fr, TA.) ― -b8- Also Unseen; not apparent; contr. of EiyaAnN. (K.) A poet says, censuring a certain man,
waEayonuhu kaAlkaAliy^i AlD~imaAri
[And his present gift is a thing not hoped for, like the unseen debt of which the payment is deferred by the creditor:] meaning, his present gift is like the absent that is not hoped for. (TA.) ― -b9- *ahabuwA bimaAliY DimaArFA means They took away my property by gaming. (Fr, TA.) -A2- Also A certain idol, which was worshipped by El-Abbás Ibn-Mirdás. (O, K, TA. [It is implied in the K that it is with the art. Al; but it is not so accord. to the O and TA.])

DamiyrN *
A thing that thou concealest, or conceivest, or determinest upon, (tuDomiruhu,) in thy heart, or mind: (Lth, TA:) a secret; syn. sir~N: (K:) a subst. from A^aDomara fiY nafosihi $ayoy^FA: (S:) pl. DamaAy^iru. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence used as meaning A pronoun; which is also termed ↓ muDomarN, and AisomN muDomarN, lit. a concealed noun, i. e. a noun of which the signification is not shown by itself alone; opposed to muZoharN: pl. of the first as above; and of the second muDomaraAtN.] ― -b3- See also DamorN. ― -b4- And AlD~amiyru signifies The heart [itself]; the mind; the recesses of the mind; the secret thoughts; or the soul; syn. qalobu AlA_inosaAni, and baATinuhu, (Msb,) or daAxilu AlxaATiri: (A, K:) pl. as above, (Msb, K,) the sing. being likened to sariyrapN, of which the pl. is saraAy^iru. (Msb.) [See also muDomarN. And see an ex. in a verse cited in art. syH, 7th conj.] -A2- Also Withered, or shrivelled, grapes, (O, K,) that are neither fresh grapes nor raisins. (O.)

laqiytuhu biAlD~umayori * is a phrase mentioned by Sgh [in
the O] as meaning I met him at sunset: but it is correctly [biAlS~umayori,] with the unpointed S. (TA.)

DamiyrapN *
A lock, or plaited lock, of hair, such as is termed DafiyrapN and gadiyrapN: pl. DamaAy^iru. (As, TA.)

DaAmirN *
Lean, and lank in the belly; [&c.; see 1;] (A, K;) applied to a he-camel, (K,) and to a horse, as also ↓ DamorN, and ↓ muDam~arN, and ↓ muDoTamirN; (A;) and to a she-camel, (S, A, K,) as also DaAmirapN; (S;) [and to a man;] DaAmirN applied to a she-camel being regarded as a possessive epithet [signifying *aAtu DumorK]: (TA:) and ↓ DamorN signifies also lank in the belly, and small and slender in person; applied to a man: (S, A, K:) fem. with p: (A, K:) the pl. of DaAmirN is Dum~arN. (Ham p. 473.) ― -b2- And A horse in a state of preparation for racing, by his having been fed with food barely sufficient to sustain him, after having become fat: and you say xayolN DaAmirapN and DawaAmiru, meaning horses in that state. (Msb.) ― -b3- Applied to grain, it means Thin, or slender: (Mgh:) and to a branch or twig, sapless; dried up; as also ↓ munoDamirN. (K.)

DawomaraAnN * (S, O, Msb, K) and DawomuraAnN (Msb) and ↓ DamoyuraAnN (O, Msb, K) and DayomaraAnN (Msb) A species of the rayaAHiyn [or sweet-smelling plants]: (S, O:) or of the wild rayoHaAn: (K:) or the rayoHaAn faArisiY~: (Msb, K:) Aboo-Nasr says that the DymrAn is the $aAhasofaram [or $aAhisofaram, i. e. basil-royal, or common sweet basil, ocimum basilicum]: AHn says, on the authority of an Arab of the desert, of El-Yemen, that the DymrAn is exactly like the Hawok [which is one of the names now applied to sweet basil], of sweet odour, and is therefore asserted by some to be the $Ahsfrm, but the DymrAn is wild; and he says that some call it DawomaraAn. (O.)
DayomuraAnN * and DayomaraAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muDomarN *
Concealed, (K,) [or conceived,] in the mind. (S.) You say, hawFY muDomarN, meaning Concealed love; as also ↓ DamorN; as though the latter were believed to be an inf. n. [used in the sense of a pass. part. n.] from the unaugmented, for the augmented, verb. (TA.) See also DamiyrN. ― -b2- Also The place of concealment, (K,) [or of conception,] in the mind. (S.) A poet, (S,) ElAhwas Ibn-Mohammad El-Ansáree, (TA,) says,
sataboqaY lahaA fiY muDomari Alqalobi waAlHa$aA
sariyrapu wud~K yawoma tubolaY Als~araAy^iru
[There will remain to her, in the hiding-place of the heart and the bowels, a secret love, (lit. a secret of love,) on the day when secrets shall be revealed]. (S, TA.)
muDam~arN * : see DaAmirN.
muDam~irN * One who prepares his horses, by reducing them to scanty food, (yuDam~iruhaA,) for a military expedition or for racing. (TA.)

miDomaArN *
A training-place in which horses are prepared for racing [or for military service] by being fed with food barely sufficient to sustain them, after they have become fat: (S, * Msb, K: *) [a hippodrome; a place where horses are exercised:] pl. maDaAmiyru. (A.) You say, jaraY fiY AlmiDomaAri [He ran in the hippodrome, or place of exercise]. (A.) And AlginaA='u miDomaAru Al$~iEori (tropical:) [app. meaning Singing is that in which the excellences of poetry are displayed, like as the excellences of a horse are displayed in the hippodrome]. (A.) ― -b2- Also The time, of forty days, during which a horse is reduced to food barely sufficient to sustain him, after his having been fed with fodder so that he has become fat; (S, TA;) the time during which a horse is thus prepared for racing or for an expedition against the enemy: pl. as above. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Aaloyawoma miDomaArN wagadFA A@los~ibaAqu waAls~aAbiqu mano sabaqa A@lojan~apa [To-day is a time for training, and to-morrow is the race, and the winner is he who wins Paradise:] i. e., to-day one is to work, in the present world, for the desire of Paradise; like as a horse is trained for racing. (Sh.) [One of the explanations of AlmDmAr in the K is gaAyapu Alfarasi fiY Als~ibaAqi, or, as in the TA, lils~ibaAqi; app. meaning The goal, or limit, of the horse in racing: but in the TA, these words are made to form part of an explanation which I have given before, i. e., the time during which a horse is prepared for racing, &c.] -A2- See also 2.

luw^oluw^N muDoTamirN *
Contracted pearls: (K:) or pearls having somewhat of contraction in the middle. (S.) ― -b2- See also DaAmirN.
munoDamirN * : see DaAmirN, last sentence.

1 Damina Al$~aYo'a * , (IAar, S, K,) or AlmaAla, (Mgh, Msb,) and Damina bihi, (Msb, K,) aor.
Damana , (K,) inf. n. DamaAnN (IAar, S, Msb, K) and DamonN, (K,) He was, or became, responsible, answerable, accountable, amenable, surety, or guarantee, (S, Mgh, K,) for the thing, (S, K,) or for the property: (Mgh:) or he made himself responsible, &c., for it; syn. Ailotazamahu; (Msb;) and so, in this sense, ↓ tDm~nhu, (S, * K,) quasi-pass. of Dam~anahu: (S, K:) [as though he had it within his grasp, or in his possession; for] the primary signification of AlD~amaAnu is Alt~aHoSiylu: (Msb:) some of the lawyers say that it is from AlD~am~u; but this is a mistake; (Msb, TA;) for the n is radical. (Msb.) And Damina lahu ka*aA He was, or became, responsible, &c., to him for such a thing. (MA.) And Damina AlmaAla minoha He was, or became, responsible, &c., to him for the property [received from him]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also 5, in four places. ― -b3- Daminahu signifies also (assumed tropical:) He learned it; acquired a knowledge of it. (TA.) -A2- And Damina, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Damana , (K,) inf. n. DamanN, (S, Msb, K, *) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, S) had, or was affected with, a malady of long continuance, or such as crippled him; (S, Msb, K;) was afflicted in his body (S, * K, TA) by some trial, or fracture, or other ailment. (S, * TA.) And Daminato yaduhu, inf. n. DamaAnapN, (assumed tropical:) His arm, or hand, was affected with a malady of long continuance, or such as crippled. (Fr, TA.)

2 Dm~nhu Al$~aYo'a * , (S, MA, K,) or AlmaAla, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. taDomiynN, (S,) He made him to be responsible, answerable, accountable, amenable, surety, or guarantee, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K,) for the thing, (S, MA, K,) or for the property. (Mgh, Msb.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce muEab~adN.] ― -b2- Dam~anotu Al$~aYo'a ka*aA I made the thing to comprise, comprehend, or contain, such a thing. (Msb.) Hence, Dam~ana A@ll~`hu A^aSolaAba AlfuHuwli Aln~asola [God has made the loins of the stallions to comprise, in the elemental state, the progeny]. (Msb.) And Dm~nhu AlwiEaA='a He put it (i. e. anything) into the receptacle. (S, K.) And Dm~n Almay~ita Alqabora He deposited the dead body in the grave. (TA.) And Dm~n AlkitaAba ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He made the writing to comprise, or include, such a thing. (MA.) [And Dm~n AlkalaAma ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He made, or held, the sentence, or speech, or phrase, to imply such a thing. And Dm~n Alkalimapa maEonaY ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He made the word to imply or import, such a meaning.] ― -b3- Alt~aDomiynu as a conventional term of those who treat of elegance of speech is (assumed tropical:) The making poetry to comprise a verse [of another poet]: (TA:) or the introducing into poetry a hemistich, or a verse, or two verses, of another poet, to complete the meaning intended, and for the purpose of corroborating the meaning, on the condition of notifying it as borrowed, beforehand, or of its being well known, so that the hearer will not imagine it to be stolen: and if it is a hemistich, or less than that, it is termed rafowN. (Har p. 267.) And as a conventional term of those who treat of versification, (assumed tropical:) The making a verse to be not complete otherwise than with what follows it. (TA.)

5 taDam~ana see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- tDm~n Al$~aYo'u ka*aA The thing comprised, comprehended, or contained, such a thing. (Msb.) Hence, taDam~anato A^aSolaAbu AlfuHuwli Aln~asola and ↓ Daminatohu [The loins of the stallions comprised, in the elemental state, the progeny]. (Msb.) And tDm~n Alqaboru Almay~ita The grave had the dead body deposited in it. (TA.) And tDm~n AlkitaAbu ka*aA [and ↓ Daminahu] (assumed tropical:) The writing comprised, or included, such a thing. (S, MA, K.) And tDm~n AlkalaAmu ka*aA [and ↓ Daminahu, as is indicated in the first sentence of this art.,] (assumed tropical:) The sentence, or speech, or phrase, comprehended, or comprised, within its scope, [or implied,] such a thing; syn. HaS~alahu. (Msb.) [And taDam~anati Alkalimapu maEonaY ka*aA and ↓ Daminatohu (assumed tropical:) The word implied such a meaning.]

DimonN * (tropical:) The TaY~, (S, MA, K,) i. e. the inside, (MA, TK,) [lit. the folding,] of a writing, or letter. (S, MA, K, TA.) You say, A^anofa*otuhu Dimona kitaAbiY i. e. fiY Tay~ihi (tropical:) [I sent it, or transmitted it, within the folding of my writing or letter; mean-
ing infolded, or enclosed, in it; included in it; or in the inside of it]. (S, TA.) And fiY Dimoni kalaAmihi [and kitaAbihi] means (assumed tropical:) Among the contents, or implications, of his speech [and of his writing or letter] (fY maTaAwiyhi); and the indications thereof. (Msb.) -A2- A thing that satisfies the stomach: thus, maA A^agonaY Ean~iY fulaAnN DimonFA means Such a one did not stand me in stead, or supply my want, of anything, even as much as a thing that would satisfy the stomach. (IAar, TA.)
