DamanN * (S, K) and ↓ DamaAnN and ↓ DamaAnapN (S, Msb, K) (tropical:) A malady of long continuance, or such as cripples; (S, Msb, K, TA;) an affliction in the body, (S, * K, TA,) by some trial, or fracture, or other ailment; (S, TA;) and ↓ DumonapN signifies the same; (K;) and [simply] a disease, or malady; (S, K;) as in the saying, kaAnato Dumonapu fulaAnK A^arobaEapa A^a$ohurK (tropical:) [The disease of such a one was four months in duration]. (S, TA.) [See also 1, last two sentences.] ― -b2- DamanN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A burden; syn. kal~N: so in the saying, fulaAnN DamanN EalaY A^aSoHaAbihi [Such a one is a burden upon his companions]. (AZ, TA.) -A2- It is also an epithet: see the next pargaraph.

DaminN * (applied to a man, S) (assumed tropical:) Affected with a malady of long continuance, or such as cripples; (S, Msb, K, TA;) afflicted in the body, (S, * K, TA,) by some trial, or fracture, or other ailment: (S, TA:) and ↓ DamanN signifies [the same; or simply] affected with a disease, or malady; applied to a man [and to two and more and to a female; being originally an inf. n.]; having no dual nor pl. nor fem. form: (TA:) pl. of the former DamonaY (S, * Msb, K, * TA) and Daminuwna, or the former of these is pl. of ↓ DamiynN [which signifies the same as DaminN]. (TA.) Aikotataba DaminFA [in the CK DamanFA] means (assumed tropical:) He wrote himself down [as one affected with a malady of long continuance, &c., or] in the register of the DamonaY, i. e. the zamonaY; (S, K, TA;) i. e. he asked that he might write himself down [as such], and took for himself a billet from the commander of the army in order to excuse himself from fighting against the unbelievers: (TA:) of such it is said that God will raise him in that state on the day of resurrection. (S, TA.) maEobuwTapN gayoru DaminapK, occurring in a trad., means Slaughtered not having any disease. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) [Loving: (See DamaAnapN:) or] loving excessively, or admiringly. (K, TA.)
DumonapN * : see DamanN.

DamaAnN * an inf. n.: [see 1, first sentence:] (IAar, S, Msb, K:) [used as a simple subst.,] Responsibility, answerableness, accountability, amenability, suretiship, or guaranteeship; syn. kafaAlapN: (Mgh:) but it is more common [in signification] than kafaAlapN; for it sometimes signifies what is not kafaAlapN, namely, [indemnification; or] restoration of the like, or of the value, of a thing that has perished. (Kull.) [DamaAnu maAlK, and guromK, signify Responsibility, &c., for property, and for a debt, owed by another person. And DamaAnu nafosK, and HuDwrK, signify Responsibility, &c., for the appearance, or presence, of another person, to answer a suit.] DumaAn darak is a vulgar phrase; correctly DamaAnu Ald~araki [expl. in art. drk]. (TA.) -A2- See also DamanN.
DamiynN * : see DAminN: -A2- and see also DaminN.
DamaAnapN * : see DamanN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Love: (K, TA:) [or] excessive, or admiring, love. (TA.)

DaAminN * and ↓ DamiynN One who is responsible, answerable, accountable, amenable, surety, or guarantee: (S, Msb, K:) both are mentioned by IAar as syn., like saAminN and samiynN. (TA.) God is represented by the Prophet as saying, mano xaraja mujaAhidFA fiY sabiyliY waA@botigaA='i maroDaAtiY faA^anaA Ealayohi DaAminN wahuwa EalaY~a DaAminN, meaning [Whoso goes forth as a warrior in my cause, and seeking, or seeking earnestly, to obtain my approval,] I am responsible to him for what I have promised him, to recompense him living and dead; DAmn being made trans. by means of ElY because it implies the meaning of muHaAmK and raqiybN; and the last clause means nearly the same, but is rendered as meaning and he is one who has [a claim to] responsibility on my part, as though care and mindfulness [of him] were obligatory on me. (Mgh.) And it is said in a trad., AlA_imaAmu DaAminN waAlmuw^a*~inu muw^otamanN: (Mgh, JM, * TA:) [the latter clause has been expl. in art. A^mn (voce A^amiynN):] the former clause means, The imám [or leader of prayer] is as though he were responsible for the correctness of the prayer of those who follow him: (JM, TA: [and the like is said, with other, similar, explanations, in the Mgh:]) or it means, the imám is careful, or mindful, for the people [who follow him], of [the correctness of] their prayer. (TA.) ― -b2- DaAminN and ↓ miDomaAnN applied to a she-camel, signify Having a fœtus in her belly: and the pls. are DawaAminu and maDaAmiynu. (IAar, L and TA in art. lqH and in the present art.) ― -b3- DaAminapN applied to rights, or dues, (Huquwq,) is used by Lebeed as meaning maDomuwnapN; [see maDomuwnN;] like as raAHilapN is used as meaning maroHuwlapN. (TA.)

DaAminapN * [fem. of DaAminN, q. v.]. ― -b2- AlD~aAminapu signifies What is included within the middle of any town or country or the like. (TA.) AlD~aAminapu mina Aln~axoli, (AO, S, K, * TA,) occurring in a letter of the Prophet, (AO, S, TA,) means What are included within the cities or towns or villages, of the palmtrees: (AO, S, K, * TA:) or what are surrounded, thereof, by the wall of the city: (K:) but Az says that they are so called because their owners are responsible for their culture and keeping: (TA:) opposed to AlD~aAHiyapu mn Alb~aEoli, which means what are in the open country, of the palm-trees that imbibe with their roots, without being watered. (AO, S, TA. *)

muDam~anN * Water included in a mug or other vessel: and milk included in the udder. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Poetry made to comprise a verse [from another poem]. (S, K. [See 2, last sentence but one.]) And (assumed tropical:) A verse [made to be] not complete otherwise than with what follows it. (S, K. [See 2, last sentence.]) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A sound [made to comprehend with it somewhat of another:] upon which one cannot pause without conjoining it with another: (K:) in the T it is said to be [such as is exemplified in] a man's saying qifo fula [or fulu, for qifo fulaAnu Pause thou, such a one], with making the l to have a smack of the vowel-sound (biA_i$omaAmi All~aAmi A_ilaY AlHarakapi). (TA.)
miDomaAnN * : see DaAminN, last sentence but one.

maDomuwnN * pass. part. n. of 1 in the first of the senses assigned to the latter above: you say $aYo'N maDomuwnN [meaning A thing, such as property, or the payment of a debt, &c., ensured by an acknowledgment of responsibility for it]. (TA.) ― -b2- maDomuwnu kitaAbK means maA fiY Dimonihi and Tay~ihi [i. e. The contents of a writing or letter; or what is infolded, or included, in a writing or letter; what is implied therein; and what is indicated therein]: pl. maDaAmiynu. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlmaDaAmiynu, (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K,) of which the sing. is maDomuwnN, (A 'Obeyd, Msb, K,) and one may also say maDomuwnapN, as meaning nasamapN, (Msb,) signifies What are [comprised] in the loins of the stallions; (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K;) i. e. the progeny [thereof, in the elemental state]: (Msb:) or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, [though the reverse is generally held to be the case,] AlmalaAqiyHu signifies what are in the backs of the he-camels, and AlmaDaAmiynu what are in the bellies of the females. (L in art. lqH.) The selling of the mDAmyn and the mlAqyH is forbidden. (S.) [maDaAmiynu is also pl. of miDomaAnN, q. v.] ― -b4- maDomuwnu Alyadi i. q. maxobuwnuhaA, (K,) meaning maEoluwluhaA [i. e. Diseased in the arm, or hand]; (TK;) applied to a man. (TA. [See 1, last sentence, which indicates a more particular meaning.])

1 Dan~a bihi * , (Mgh, Msb,) first pers. Daninotu bihi, (S, Msb, *) [and one may say Ealayohi, and Eanohu, in the place of bihi, (see DaniynN,)] and DaninuwA occurs, in a verse of Kaanab Ibn-Umm-Sáhib, used by poetic license for Dan~uwA, (S,) aor.
Dana3a ; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and Dan~a, (Msb,) first pers. Dananotu, (S, Msb, *) aor.
Dani3a , (S, Msb, K,) accord to Fr, (S,) or, accord. to Th, Fr said, I have heard Dananotu, though I have not heard A^aDin~u, but this aor. is mentioned by Yaakoob; (TA;) inf. n. Din~N (S, Mgh, Msb, K [in the CK DinaAnFA is erroneously put for Din~FA]) and Dan~N (TA) and DanaAnapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) with fet-h, (Msb, TA,) and Din~apN, (Msb,) or this last is a simple subst.; (Mgh;) He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, stingy, or avaricious, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) of it.
(S, Mgh, Msb. [See also 8.]) You say, Dan~a Ealayohi bika*aA He was, or became, niggardly, &c., to him, of such a thing. (Mgh.) And ↓ A_in~amaA yuDan~u biAlD~aniyni [Only he who clings is to be clung to]: a prov., meaning that you should cling to fraternizing [only] with him who clings to fraternizing with you. (Meyd, and Har p. 42.) And Daninotu biAlmanozili, inf. n. Din~N and DanaAnapN, [I kept tenaciously to, or] I did not quit, or relinquish, the place of alighting, or abode. (TA.)
8 AiDoTan~a * (originally AiDotan~a, TA) He (a man, TA) was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, stingy, or avaricious. (K.) [See also 1.]

Din~N * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, &c.) ― -b2- Also A thing highly esteemed, of which one is tenacious. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence] one says, huwa Din~iY He is the person of whose affection I am tenacious; as also ↓ Din~atiY and ↓ DaniyniY: (TA:) or he is my particular, or special, friend, (K, TA,) mino bayoni A_ixowaAniY [chosen from among my brethren]; (S, TA;) as though I appropriated him specially to myself, and were tenacious of him because of the place that he held in my estimation: as is said in the S, it is like special appropriation [of the person to oneself]. (TA.) [And as Din~N is originally an inf. n., it is used as an epithet applied to a pl. number:] it is said in a trad., A_in~a lil~`hi Din~FA mino xaloqihi yuHoyiyhimo fiY EaAfiyapK wayumiytuhumo fiY EaAfiyapK, (S, TA,) or mino xlqh ↓ DanaAy^ina, (K, * TA,) accord. to different relations thereof, (TA,) i. e. [Verily God has] specially-distinguished individuals [of his creatures, whom He causes to live in a state of freedom from disease, or from disease and trial, and whom He causes to die in a state of freedom &c.]: (K, TA:) the sing. of DanaAy^in is ↓ DaniynapN, of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEurlapN, and meaning a thing that one specially appropriates to himself, and of which he is tenacious because of the place that it holds in his estimation. (TA.)

Din~apN * an inf. n. of Dan~a: (Msb:) or a subst. therefrom signifying Niggardliness, tenaciousness, stinginess, or avarice: (Mgh:) or vehement niggardliness &c.; as also ↓ maDan~apN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also Din~N.

DananN *
Courageous, brave, or strong-hearted. (K.)

DaniynN *
Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, or avaricious, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) bi$aYo'K [of a thing], (S,) or bi$aYo'K nafiysK [of a thing held in high estimation]. (TA.) wamaA huwa EalaY A@logayobi biDaniynK, in the Kur [lxxxi. 24], as some read it, others reading biZaniynK [q. v.], is expl. by Zj as meaning, And he is not a tenacious concealer of that which has been revealed to him: and if Ean or bi were substituted for EalaY, it would be correct. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1. ― -b3- And see Din~N.

DanaAnapN * an inf. of 1 [q. v.]. (S &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, hajamotu EalaY Alqawomi biDanaAnatihimo, meaning (assumed tropical:) [I came suddenly upon the people, or party, in their close state, i. e.,] when they had not dispersed themselves. (TA.) And A^axa*otu AlA^amora biDanaAnatihi (assumed tropical:) [I took to the affair] in its fresh state. (TA.)
DaniynapN * ; and its pl. DanaAy^inu: see Din~N.

maDan~apN * : see Din~apN. ― -b2- h`*aA Eiloqu maDan~apK and maDin~apK [the former mentioned after the latter in the S] This is a thing held in high estimation, of which one is tenacious, (S, K, TA,) and for which people vie in desire. (TA.) [See also EiroqN, last sentence.]

AlmaDonuwnu * a name of [The compound of perfumes commonly called] AlgaAliyapu; (Ez-Zejjájee, S, K, TA;) as also ↓ AlmaDonuwnapu; (Ez-Zejjájee, S, * TA;) which latter is said by As to be a sort of perfume; and so is the former in the A: in the M the former is said to be the oil of ben: it is thus called because one is tenacious of it. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (IKh, TA,) or ↓ AlmaDonuwnapu, (K, TA,) a name of The well Zemzem. (K, TA.)
AlmaDonuwnapu * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1 DanaA=ato * , aor.
DanaAa , (S, M, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. Dano'N and Dunuwo'N; (S, M, O, K;) and accord. to the K, Daniy^ato, but MF says that this latter is unknown, i. e., it is not mentioned in the other lexicons in the sense here assigned to it in the K; (TA;) and ↓ ADnA^t; (S, M, O, K;) She (a woman) had many children: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) [and so Danato and Daniyato, as mentioned in art. Dnw:] and in like manner one says of cattle; (M;) [i. e.] one says, DanaA^a AlmaAlu (S, O, K) and Daniy^a, (O, K,) and SanaA^ati AlmaA$iyapu and Daniy^at, (TA,) [and ↓ ADnA^ and ADnA^t as is implied in the M,] The cattle multiplied, or became numerous or many. (S, O, K, TA.) And DanaA^ato is said to signify She brought forth. (TA.) ― -b2- And SanaA^a fiY AlA^aroDi, (M, K,) inf. n. Dano'N and Dunuwo'N [as above], (M, TA,) He hid, or concealed, himself in the land, or country: (M:) or he went away in the land, or into the country, and hid, or concealed, himself [therein]: (K:) like DabaA^a. (TA.)
4 A^aDonaAa see above, in two places. ― -b2- A^aDonaw^uwA signifies Their cattle multiplied, or became numerous or many. (S, O, K.)

8 ADoTanaA^a lahu * and minohu
He was abashed at, or shy of, and he shrank at, or from, him, or it. (M, K. [See also ADTbA^.]) Et-Tirimmáh uses AiDoTanaA [or AiDoTanaY in this sense,] and yaDoTaniY: meaning ADTnA^ [and yDTny^]: or as being derived from AlD~anaY meaning “ disease. ” (M.)

Dano'N *
Children, or offspring; as also ↓ Dino'N; (S, M, O, K; [and so DanowN and DinowN, as mentioned in art. Dnw;]) the former accord. to El-Umawee, and both accord. to AA: (S, O:) the former signifies the offspring of anything: (TA:) and also, (K, TA, [in a copy of the M ↓ the latter, but this is app. a mistranscription,]) multitude of offspring: it is like nafarN (M, K) and rahoTN, (M,) having no. n. un.: the pl. is Dunuwo'N. (M, K.)

Dino'N *
Origin, root, race, or stock; syn. A^aSolN: (El-Umawee, S, M, O, K:) and the place in which a thing originates; syn. maEodinN. (ElUmawee, S, O, K.) One says, fulaAnN fiY Dino'i SidoqK [Such a one is of an excellent origin or race or stock], (S, O, L,) and fiY Dino'i sawo'K [of a bad origin &c.]. (L.) ― -b2- See also Dano'N, in two places.

DunoA^apN * (M, O, K) and ↓ DunaA='apN (O, K) Necessity, need, or want; or difficulty, or distress; (DaAruwrapN, M, O, or DaruwrapN, K; [both meaning the same;]) that befalls a man: (O:) so in the saying qaEada maqoEada DunoA^ap (M, K) and ↓ DunaA='apK (K) [lit. He sat in the sitting-place of necessity, &c.; meaning he was, or became, in an abject condition]: the phrase denotes disdain, or scorn; and is thought by AM to be from AiDoTanaA^a meaning “ he was abashed, &c. ” (TA.)
DunaA='apN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
DaAniy^N * (S, O, K) and DaAniy^apN (Ks, S, O, Msb, K) A woman having many children: (S, O, Msb, K:) and in like manner, the latter, cattle (maA$iyapN) having numerous offspring. (TA.)

1 Danuka * , aor.
Danuka , inf. n. DanokN and DanaAkapN and DunuwkapN, (O, K,) the first and third of these, (O,) or the first and second, (TA,) accord. to IDrd, used in relation to a place, and the second and third in relation to life, or sustenance, or means of subsistence, (O, TA,) It was, or became, narrow, or strait. (O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And Danuka said of a man, inf. n. DanaAkapN, He was, or became, weak in his judgment, and in his body, and in his soul, and in his intellect. (K.) ― -b3- And Danuka Als~aHaAbu The clouds became thick, collected together, and dense. (O, TA.) -A2- Dunika, like EuniYa, He was, or became, affected with a coryza, or defluxion from the head and nose. (K.)

4 ADnkhu *
He (God) caused him to be affected with a coryza, or defluxion from the head and nose. (TA.)

DanokN * an inf. n. of Danuka: (O, K:) its primary signification is Narrowness, or straitness, and hardship. (Aboo-Is-hák, TA.) ― -b2- And Narrow, or strait; syn. Day~iqN; (S, M, O, K; [in the CK, and in a copy of the S, Diyq, which is also a correct explanation, as shown above; but not what is here meant, as appears from what follows;]) applied to anything, (M, K,) masc.
and fem., (M, K, and Bd in xx. 123,) being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (Bd ibid.) [Like the Pers. tanoG.] One says makaAnN DanokN A narrow, or strait, place. (IDrd, O, TA.) And Eayo$N DanokN A strait life; or strait sustenance, or means of subsistence; (IDrd, O, TA;) as also ↓ Eayo$N DaniykN: (AA, O, K, TA:) and thus maEiy$apF DanokFA in the Kur xx. 123; where some read ↓ DanokaY, like sakoraY: (Bd:) or this means such as is unlawful; (O, TA;) every life that is unlawful being termed DanokN, accord. to Lth, even though it be ample: (O, TA: *) Aboo-Is-hák thinks it to mean [subsistence] in the fire of Hell: but says that most explain this phrase in the Kur as meaning the punishment of the grave: (TA:) thus it means accord. to Ibn-Mes'ood: (O:) or, accord. to Katádeh, Hell: (O, TA:) or, accord. to Ed-Dahhák, forbidden gain: (TA:) or, as some say, AlD~ariyEu [q. v.], and Alz~ak~uwmu [q. v.]. (Bd.)
DunokapN * : see DunaAkN.
DanokaY * : see DanokN.
DanaAkN * : see DinaAkN.

DunaAkN *
A coryza, or defluxion from the head and nose; syn. zukaAmN; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ DunokapN. (K.)

DinaAkN * ; (O, K, &c.;) accord. to El-Fárábee, (O, TA,) and J [in the S], (TA,) ↓ DanaAkN; but accord. to others, with kesr, and this is the right; (O, TA;) Compact in flesh; applied to a woman: (El-Fárábee, S, O:) or plump, and compact in flesh; so applied: (Lth, TA:) or heavy in the hinder part, (K, TA,) and large in body; (TA;) so applied: (K, * TA:) or having much flesh; applied to a male and to a female, without p: (IAth, TA:) and firm in make, and strong; applied to a male and to a female; (K, TA;) of human beings, and of camels, and in like manner of palm-trees and of trees in general: (TA:) and, applied to a she-camel, thick in the hinder part: (TA:) and [large; applied to trees ($ajarN): or] large trees. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

DaniykN * : see DanokN. ― -b2- Also Weak in his body, and in his intellect, (AZ, O, K,) and in his judgment, and in his soul. (K,) ― -b3- And A servant who works for his bread. (AZ, O, K.) ― -b4- And i. q. maqoTuwEN [Cut off; &c.]. (AA, O, K.)

DunoA^akN *
Hard, and firm and compact in flesh; (Lh, O, K;) applied to a man; (Lh, O;) as also DanoA^akN: (K:) fem. DunoA^akapN; (Lh, O, K;) applied to a woman. (Lh, O.) And, applied to a she-camel, Great, (K, TA,) and compact in make: (TA:) as also with p. (K.)
muDonakN * , (TA,) or ↓ mutaDan~ikN, (O,) Affected with a constant, or chronic, pervading disease; or emaciated by disease so as to be at the point of death. (O, TA.)

maDonuwkN *
Affected with the malady termed DunaAk [q. v.]. (S, O,)
mutaDan~ikN * : see muDonakN.

1 Danati AlmaroA^apu * , inf. n. DanaA='N (S, M, K) and DanFA, (M, K,) The woman had many children; (S, M, K;) as also Daniyat: (K:) and so with '. (S.) ― -b2- And DanaA naSiybuhu His share, or portion, became redundant; it increased, or augmented. (Sgh, K.)
DanowN * and DinowN Children, or offspring; (AA, S, K;) like Dano'N and Dino'N; as also ↓ DunFA, accord. to IAar. (TA.)
DunFA * : see what next precedes.

1 DaniYa * , (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
DanaYa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. DanFY; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and ↓ ADTnY signifies the same; He was, or became, slender, and small in body: and hence, (Ham p. 112,) he was, or became, diseased, disordered, or sick; (S, and Ham ibid.;) because disease occasions leanness, or emaciation: (Ham:) or he was, or became, lean, or emaciated: (so accord. to the explanation of the inf. n. in the Mgh:) or he was, or became, affected with a disease, disorder, or sickness, (M, Msb, K,) of long continuance, and settled, (M,) or constant, so that he was at the point of death, (Msb,) or such as infected, or pervaded, him, and so that, whenever he thought himself to be recovering, he relapsed. (K.) -A2- [See also 1 in art. Dnw.]

3 muDaAnaApN *
i. q. muEaAnaApN, (S, K, KL,) both signifying The suffering, or enduring, [or contending with,], the difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience, of a thing; as also muqaAsaApN. (KL.)

4 ADnAhu * , said of a disease, disorder, or sickness, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) It rendered him such as is termed DanFY or DanK: (M, Msb, K:) rendered him lean, or emaciated: (Mgh:) or oppressed him; burdened him heavily; overburdened him; or overcame him, and rendered him heavy. (S, TA.) -A2- And A^aDonaY He kept to the bed by reason of what is termed DanFY [i. e. leanness, or emaciation; or disease, disorder, or sickness, or such as was of long continuance, &c.: see 1]. (TA.)

5 tDn~Y *
He (a man) feigned himself diseased, disordered, or sick. (TA.)
8 ADTnY * : see 1. ― -b2- See also 8 in art. DnA^.

DanFY * : inf. n. of 1. (S, M, &c.) ― -b2- Also, [in some copies of the K erroneously written DaniY~N,] and ↓ DanK; (S, M, Msb, K;) the former applied alike to a man (Fr, IAar, T, S, Msb) and to a woman (IAar, T, S, Msb) and to two persons (Msb) and to a pl. number, (Fr, IAar, T, S, Msb,) because originally an inf. n., (S, Msb,) for *uw DanFY and *aAtu DanFY [&c.]; (Msb;) or some do not dualize it nor pluralize it, because it is [originally] an inf. n., and others dualize it and pluralize it; (M;) but ↓ DanK has a fem. (Msb) and a dual and a pl., (S,) its fem. being DaniyapN (Msb, TA) [and its dual DaniyaAni] and the pl. is A^aDonaA='N; (TA;) [Slender, and small in body: and hence, (see 1,)] diseased, disordered, or sick: (S:) [or lean, or emaciated: (see again 1:)] or affected with a disease, disorder, or sickness, (M, Msb, K,) of long continuance, and settled, (M,) or constant, so that he is at the point of death, (Msb,) or such as infects, or pervades, him, and so that, whenever he thinks himself to be recovering, he relapses. (K.) You say, tarakotuhu DanFY and ↓ DaniyFA [I left him lean, or diseased, &c.]. (S.)
DanK * ; fem. DaniyapN; and pl. A^aDonaA='N: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
DinFY * , [written in the TA DnA, but the final radical is Y,] with kesr, accord to IAar, signifies Pains that cause fear. (TA.)
DanaA='N * , like salaAmN [in measure, The state of such as is termed DanFY or DanK], a subst. from DaniYa. (Msb.)

muDonFY *
Rendered lean, or emaciated; [&c;] (Mgh;) pass. part. n. of 4 [q. v.]. (Mgh, Msb.)

3 muDaAhaA^apN * is syn. with muDaAhaApN, (K, TA, [the w before AlmuDAhApu in the CK should be erased,]) i. q. mu$aAkalapN: (S, O, Msb, TA:) you say, DaAhaA^otuhu and DaAhayotuhu, ('Eyn, S, * O, * Msb, * TA,) i. e. I resembled him; syn. $aAbahotuhu: ('Eyn, TA:) [or I conformed with him:] or DaAhaA^ahu, inf. n. as above, signifies he imitated him; syn. EaAraDahu and baAraAhu; and one says also, DaAhayotuhu, inf. n. muDaAhaApN: (Msb:) the verb is read both with and without ' in the Kur [ix. 30]. (O, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- DaAhaA bihi, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) [or DaAhaA^ahu, like DaAhaAhu, mentioned in art. DhY,] inf. n. as above, (K,) He (a man) was, or became, gentle, tender, or courteous, or he acted, or behaved, gently, &c., with him, or to him. (A 'Obeyd, K, * TA.)

Q. Q. 1
or Q. 1. DahoyaA^a: see art. DhyA^.
DahoyaA^N * and DahoyaA^apN: see art. DhyA^.

1 Dahabahu biAln~aAri * , aor.
Dahaba , (K,) inf. n. DahobN, (TK,) He altered it, (K, TA,) and changed its colour, (TA,) by means of fire. (K, TA.) [See also 2.] -A2- Dahaba said of a man, (O, K,) aor.
Dahaba , (TA,) inf. n. DuhuwbN, (O, K,) (tropical:) He failed of fulfilling his promise (A^axolafa), and was weak, and not like a man: (O, K, TA:) as though likened to meat not thoroughly cooked. (TA. [See 2.]) ― -b2- And Dahobu Alqawomi signifies AixotilaATuhumo [i. e. The people's being mixed, or confused]: (JK, O:) or A^axolaATuhumo [i. e. ↓ DahobN is a subst., signifying a medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of people]. (So in the K. [But I think that this explanation is a mistranscription.]) [Or it signifies The people's multiplying themselves, and hastening: for] it is said in the “ Nawádir ” that haDaba
Alqawomu and DahabuwA and hulabuwA and A^unabuwA and HuT~abuwA all denote AlA_ikovaAr and AlA_isoraAE: so in the T in art. hDb. (TA.)

2 Dh~b * , inf. n. taDohiybN, He roasted (Lth, K, TA) flesh-meat (Lth, TA) upon heated stones: (Lth, K, TA:) or he roasted, (K,) or put into the fire, (AA, TA,) but did not cook thoroughly, (AA, K, TA,) flesh-meat. (AA, TA.) ― -b2- And, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S, O,) He exposed a bow, (S, O, K,) and a spear, (S, O,) to the fire, (S, O, K,) on the occasion of straightening it, (S, O,) or to straighten it. (K.) [See also 1.] ― -b3- And He collected together the fire; (JK;) and so ↓ DahoDaba. (JK, O, K.)
3 muDaAhabapN * signifies Mutual reviling or vilifying; (K;) the addressing each other with bad words. (TA.)

Q. 1 DahoDaba * : see 2, last sentence. [Mentioned in this art., as though Q. Q., contr. to the rule generally observed with respect to words of four radical letters of which the first and third are identical but not the second and fourth.]
DahobN * : see the first paragraph.

qawosN DahobaA='u *
A bow upon which the fire has taken effect [so as to alter its colour]: (O, K:) like DaboHaA='u. (TA.)

DayohabN *
i. q. SayohabN, meaning A place where flesh-meat is roasted [on the ground heated by the sun]; (K; [in the CK, lima$owiY~i All~Hmi is erroneously put for lima$owaY All~aHomi;]) accord. to Lth, any [high ground such as is called] quf~, or rugged ground, or place on a mountain, upon which the sun shines with such heat that flesh-meat will roast upon it: but Az says that what Lth means is SayohabN only, with the unpointed S; (O, * TA;) and if so, the meaning assigned here in the K is not correct. (TA.)

muDah~abN * Flesh-meat roasted, but not thoroughly cooked: (S, A, O:) accord. to El-Mufaddal, flesh-meat cut in pieces; (O;) and thus in the K; (TA;) but IF says that this is nought, unless it be cut in pieces roasted: (O:) it is at variance with what is said by the leading authorities, for they say that it means flesh-meat roasted upon heated stones: or roasted upon the fire, but not thoroughly cooked: (TA:) or cooked in a fryingpan. (TA in art. ErS.) Imra-el-Keys says,
namu$~u biA^aEoraAfi AljiyaAdi A^akuf~anaA
A_i*aA naHonu qumonaA Eano $iwaA='K muDah~abi
[We wipe our hands with the manes of the swift horses when we rise from eating roast meat not thoroughly cooked]. (S, O.)

1 Dahadahu * , (S, L, K,) aor. - There is no diacritic specified in the original text. , (S, L,) inf. n. DahodN; (L;) and ↓ ADThdhu, (as in the L, and in some copies of the K,) or ↓ ADhdhu; (as in other copies of the K;) He overpowered him; subdued him; oppressed him: (S, L, K:) he treated him wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously; (L;) as also bihi ↓ ADhd: (L, K:) he constrained him. (S, L.) ↓ kaAna laAyujiyzu A@liAoDoTihaAda, occurring in a trad., means He used not to allow constraint, or compulsion, or force, in a sale, and in an oath, &c. (L.)
4 A^aDohada see each, in two places, in the preceding paragraph.
8 A_iDotahada see each, in two places, in the preceding paragraph.

DuhodapN *
Force; constraint; compulsion. (L.) ― -b2- huwa DuhodapN likul~i A^aHadK means He is one who may be overpowered, subdued, or oppressed, by every one who desires to make him so. (S, L, K.)

DahoyadN *
Hardy, strong, robust: (L, K:) applied to a man: (L:) [said to be] the only word of the measure faEoyalN (K) in the language of the Arabs; but Kh asserts it to be a forged word: (TA:) DahoyaA^N and EavoyarN are also mentioned as of this measure; [but the latter is disallowed in the S and O, voce EivoyarN;] and madoyanu and maroyamu [which, however, are foreign proper names]. (MF.)
maDohuwdN * and ↓ muDoTahadN A man (L) overpowered; subdued; oppressed; (S, L;) abased; (L;) constrained. (S, L.)
muDoTahadN * : see what next precedes.

AlmuDoTahidu *
The lion. (K.)
Q. 1 DahoDaba * : see 2 in art. Dhb.

DahowapN *
A birokap of water; [i. e. a wateringtrough, or tank, or the like, of water; or a basin, pool, pond, or lake, of water; or a place where water remains and collects, or collects and stagnates;] (M, K;) as though formed by transposition from wahoDapN, which signifies a depressed piece of ground: (TA:) pl. A^aDohaA='N. (M, K.)
DahowaA='u * A woman whose breasts have not become prominent, or protuberant. (Lth, K.) [See also DahoyaA='u, in the next art.]

1 Dahiyato * , aor.
DahaYa , inf. n. DahFY, She was, or became, such as is termed DahoyaA='. (K.)

3 DAhAhu * , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. muDaAhaApN, (S, Msb,) He resembled, or conformed with, him, or it; syn. $aAkalahu; (S, Msb, K;) like DaAhaA^ahu [q. v.]: (S, Msb:) and, like the latter, he imitated him. (Msb, TA. *) It is said in a trad., A^a$ad~u Aln~aAsi Ea*aAbFA yawoma AlqiyaAmapi Al~a*iyn yuDaAhuwna xaloqa A@ll~`hi i. e. [The most severely punished of mankind on the day of resurrection will be] those who imitate by what they make [the creation of God]; meaning the sculptors or limners or the like. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, [or DaAhaY bihi, like DaAhaA^a bh, q. v.,] He was, or became, gentle, tender, or courteous, or he acted, or behaved, gently, &c., with him, or to him; namely, a man, and other than a man. (TA.)

4 ADhY *
He married, i. e. took to wife, a woman such as is termed DahoyaA='. (AA, K.) -A2- And He pastured his camels upon the species of tree called DahoyaA='. (K.)
DahoyFA * : see the next paragraph, in four places.

DahoyaA='u * A woman that does not menstruate: pl. DuhoYN; which necessarily implies that the former is [as above, i. e.] with the long A: but AA mentions ↓ DahoyaApN and ↓ DahoyaAhN, with p and with h, as having this meaning; which necessarily implies that DhyA is with the short A [i. e., accord. to a general rule, ↓ DahoyFA, with tenween, like DahoyaA^N, q. v. in art. DhyA^, though (accord. to a general rule) this should be regarded as a masc. epithet]: (S) or DahoyaA='u, and also with the short A [app. ↓ DahoyFA, as above, not DahoyaA, or, as I rather incline to think, DahoyaA^N (which is mentioned in art. DhyA^) may be here meant], signify a woman that does not menstruate nor become pregnant; (K, TA;) so that she is as though she resembled a man: (TA: [see 3:]) or that menstruates but does not become pregnant: (K, TA:) or that does not bring forth, though she menstruate: (TA:) or whose breasts do not grow forth; (K, TA;) and when this is the case, she does not menstruate: or the former signifies that does not menstruate, being pregnant. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Land that does not give growth to anything; as also with the short A [i. e. ↓ DahoyFA or DahoyaA^N]. (K. [In the TA this meaning is restricted, app. without reason, to the form with the short A.]) -A2- Also, (S, K,) and with the short A [i. e. ↓ DahoyFA or DahoyaA^N], (K,) A species of tree (S, K) of the kind called EiDaAh, (K,) having a baramap [q. v.] and a pod (Eul~afap) [which succeeds the baramap], and many thorns. (TA. [For further descriptions thereof, see DahoyaA^N, in art. DhyA^.])
DahoyaApN * and DahoyaAhN: see the next preceding paragraph.

DahiY~N * , (S, K,) of the measure faEiylN, (S,) The like of another [thing or person]: (S, K:) one says, h`*aA DahiY~u h`*aA This is the like of this: (S:) or huwa Dahiy~uka He is the like of thee. (K.)

Q. 1 DahoyaAa [Accord. to the O and K, Q. Q. 1, being mentioned therein in art. DhA^.] DahoyaA^a A^amorahu He fell short of doing what he ought to have done in his affair, (mar~aDahu, O, K,) and did not decide it, (lamo yaSorimohu, O,) or and did not perform it firmly, or soundly: (K:) like rahoyaA^a. (TA.)

DahoyaA^N * , of the measure faEolalN, or, as some say, faEoyalN; if of the latter, [said to be] the only instance of this measure in the language; DahoyadN
being a foreign proper name; (TA;) or, maroyamu being a foreign proper name; (TA;) or, accord. to Sb, the hemzeh in DahoyaA^N, which is with tenween, is augmentative, because it is syn. with DahoyaA='u, which is with the long A and imperfectly decl., for the Y cannot be augmentative and the hemzeh radical in the latter; (MF and TA in art. DhY;) [a word like DahoyFA and DahoyaA='u (which see in art. DhY) in most, or a some seem to say in all, of its meanings;] A certain tree, resembling the sayaAl, (AZ, O, K,) each of which has its fruit in a sinofap [or pod]; it has weak thorns, and grows in the valleys and on the mountains: (AZ, O:) Ed-Deenawaree [i. e. AHn] says, on the authority of some one or more of the Arabs of the desert, of El-Azd, that the DhyA^ is a great tree of the kind called EiDaAh, having a baramap [q. v.] and a pod (Eul~~afap) [which succeeds the baramap], and many thorns; its pods (Eul~af) are intensely red, and its leaves are like those of the [species of acacia called] samur. (O.) -A2- Also A woman that does not menstruate: and that has neither milk nor breast: as also ↓ DahoyaA^apN: (K:) or the latter is an epithet applied to a woman in these two senses: (O: [in which the former word, without p, is not mentioned:]) Seer says, in his Expos. of “ the Book ” of Sb, that DahoyaA^N, like DahoyaA='u [which belongs to art. DhY], is a subst. as well as an epithet, signifying a woman whose breast has not grown forth: and one who has not menstruated: ― -b2- and also (assumed tropical:) A land that has not given growth to anything: (MF, TA:) or ↓ DahoyaA^apN signifies as above: and also (assumed tropical:) a desert (falaApN) having in it no water: (O, K, TA:) or that does not give growth to anything; app. because it has no water. (TA.) [Accord. to those who hold the Y to be augmentative,] a woman is thus termed because she resembles men (liA^an~ahaA DaAhaA^ati Alr~ijaAla). (O, TA.)
DahoyaA^apN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
R. Q. 1 DawoDawoA * , [inf. n. DawoDaApN and DawoDaA='N, (see the next paragraph,)] They cried out, shouted, or clamoured; first pers. sing. DawoDayotu, the [second] w being changed into Y. (S, TA.)

Daw~apN * [in the CK erroneously written DawAp] A crying out, shouting, or clamouring; (S, K;) so says As, and AZ says the like; (S;) as also ↓ DawoDaApN (S, K) and ↓ DawoDaA='N, (TA in art. DwD, [these two there mentioned as inf. ns., on the authority of IKtt,]) and ↓ DawoDFY. (K in art. DwD.) One says, samiEotu Daw~apa Alqawomi [I heard the crying out, shouting, or clamouring, of the people, or party]. (As, AZ, S.)
DawoDFY * and DawoDaA='u and DawoDaApN; see the next preceding paragraph.

DuwaADK *
Large, big, or bulky; thick; or large in body; syn. DaxomN, (K, TA,) and EaZymN. (TA.)
DuwaADiyapN * : see what next follows.

DuwayoDiyapN * , (K, TA,) in the dim. form, (TA,) A calamity, or misfortune; (K, TA,) because of its greatness; (TA;) as also ↓ DuwaADiyapN. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A stallion [camel] excited by lust. (Sgh, K.)
muDawoDK * A man crying out; shouting, or clamouring; (K and TA in art. DwD; [in the CK erroneously written muDawoDiY~;]) like muDawoDiy^N. (TA in that art.)
1 DawVAa see 4, in two places.

2 Daw~aAa see the next paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- One says also, Daw~aA^otu Eanohu [meaning I brought to light, made visible, discovered, or revealed, him, or it]. (M, TA.) A sheep, or goat, belonging to an Arab of the desert strayed; whereupon he said, Aall~`hum~a Daw~iy^o Eanohu [O God, bring it to light, or discover it]. (A, TA.) -A2- Accord. to Lth, but he is the only authority for it known by AM, (TA,) Daw~aA^a Eani AlA^amori, inf. n. taDowiy^apN, means He declined, or turned away, from the affair. (K, TA.)

4 ADA=' * , (M, Msb, K,) said of a thing, (M,) [as, for instance,] of the moon, (Msb,) or ADA='t, said of fire (Aln~aAr,), (A 'Obeyd, S, O,) inf. n. A_iDaA='N; (Msb;) and ↓ DaA='a, (M, Msb, K,) or DaA='at, (S, O,) aor. yaDuwo'u, (M,) or taDuwo'u, (S,) inf. n. Dawo'N (S, M, O, Msb, K) and Duwo'N, (S, O, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) but the former verb is preferred; (TA;) It gave light, was light or bright, shone, or shone brightly. (Msb, K, * TA.) [See also an ex. of ↓ the latter verb in a verse cited voce A^ufuqN; and cited here in the TA.] And A^aDaA^otu lahu [I gave light to him]. (M.) -A2- The former verb is also trans.: you say, A^aDaA='atohu Aln~aAru [The fire made it to be light or bright, to shine, or to shine brightly]: (S, O:) and A^aDaA^otuhu and ↓ Daw~aA^otuhu [I made it to give light, to be light or bright, to shine, or to shine brightly]: (M, Msb, * K:) and A^aDaA^otu bihi Albayota and bihi ↓ Daw~aA^otuhu [I lighted, or illumined, with it (i. e. with a lamp or the like) the house, or chamber, or tent]. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ADA=' bibawolihi (tropical:) He ejected his urine [so as to make its drops to glisten]; or emitted it and then stopped it; syn. Ha*afa bihi; (K, TA;) or xa*afa bihi; (so in a copy of the M, as on the authority of Kr;) or, as in the A, A^a*oraEa bihi. (TA.) ― -b3- And they said maA A^aDowaA^ahu [How light, or bright, is it!]. (S voce A^aZolama [q. v.].) ― -b4- And ADA=' signifies also A^aSaAba Dawo'FA [He saw (lit. lighted on, or found,) light, or brightness]. (T voce A^aZolama [q. v.])

5 tDw~A^ *
He stood in the dark to see people by the light of their fire, (AZ, K, TA,) without their seeing him. (AZ, TA.) And tDw~A A@moraA^apF [He stood in the dark to see a woman by the light of her fire, without her seeing him]. (TA.)

10 AisotaDaA^utu bihi * [I sought to obtain light by means of it; I made use of it for light]. (M, K.) laA tasotaDiyw^uwA binaAri A^aholi Al$~iroki [lit. Seek not ye to obtain light by means of the fire of the people of belief in a plurality of gods], (O, K,) a saying of the Prophet, (O,) means (tropical:) seek not ye counsel, or advice, of the believers in a plurality of gods, in affairs: (O, K:) because he whose affair is confused and dubious to him is as though he were in darkness. (O.)

Dawo'N * and ↓ Duwo'N and ↓ DiyaA='N (S, M, O, K) and ↓ DiwaA='N, (M, K,) the last of which is [erroneously] written in the L DawaA='N, (TA,) signify the same, (S, M, O, K,) i. e. Light, syn. nuwrN, (K, TA,) accord. to the leading lexicologists; but see what follows: (TA:) and Dawo'N is an inf. n. of DaA='a, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) and so is ↓ Duwo'N, (S, O, K,) or this is a simple subst. from DaA='a, and so is ↓ DiyaA='N, which is also, sometimes, written ↓ Diy^aA='N, from A^aDaA='a as syn. with DaA='a: (Msb:) the pl. of Dawo'N (M, TA) and ↓ Duwo'N (M) is A^aDowaA='N; and ↓ DiyaA='N is sometimes a pl., (M, TA,) as Zj states it to be: (TA:) some say that Dawo'N has a more intensive signification than nuwrN, and that hence God has likened his direction [the Kur-án] to Aln~uwr rather than to AlD~awo'; because if it were otherwise, no one had erred: and that hence, also, [in the Kur x. 5,] the sun is termed ↓ DiyaA='; and the moon, nuwrN: it is also said that Dawo'N signifies the rays that are diffused by what is termed nuwrN: the kádee Zekereeyà affirms that these two words are syn. by their original application, but that Dawo'N is more forcible accord. to usage: and some say that AlD~awo'u signifies that [light] which subsists by itself, as [that of] the sun, and fire; and Aln~uwru, to that which subsists by some other thing [as does the light of the moon]. (MF, TA.)
Duwo'N * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
DiwaA='N * : see Dawo'N.
DiyaA='N * and Diy^aA='N: see Dawo'N, in five places.
2 Dw~H * : see 2, in two places, in art. DyH.

DaAdN *
The name of one of the letters of the alphabet. (L, Msb, K.) See the letter D.
1 DaArahu * , aor. yaDuwru: see DaArahu, aor. yaDiyru, in art. Dyr.

5 tDw~r *
He writhed by reason of the pain of beating, (M, A, K,) or of hunger: (K:) he cried out and writhed on being beaten, (Lth, S, A,) or
by reason of vehement hunger: (S, A:) he writhed and cried out and turned over, by reason of the vehemence of fever: (TA:) he manifested harm, injury, or hurt, that he suffered; and was in a state of agitation: (IAmb, TA:) he manifested weakness: (Abu-l-'Abbás, in TA: [but for taDoEiyfN, as the explanation of the inf. n., in the TA, I read taDaE~ufN:]) he (a wolf, and a dog, and a lion, and a fox,) cried out (M, K) with hunger. (M.)

1 DaAzahu Haq~ahu * , aor. yaDuwzuhu, i. q. DaAzahu, aor. yaDiyzuhu: see art. Dyz. (K.) You say also DaAzaniY, aor. yaDuwzuniY, meaning naqaSaniY [He made me to suffer loss]. (Kr, M, TA.) -A2- And DaAza, aor. yaDuwzu is also [intrans.] like DaA^aza, q. v. (TA in art. DA^z.)

qisomapN DuwzaY *
i. q. DiyzaY: see art. Dyz. (M, TA. *)

div1.div2: DwD For words mentioned in the K under this head, see art. Dw.

div2.entryFree: 1 DaAEahu * , (aor. yaDuwEuhu, S, O,) inf. n. DawoEN, He, or it, put it, or him, into a state of motion, commotion, or agitation; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ Dw~Ehu, inf. n. taDowiyEN: (TA:) and disquieted, or disturbed, him, or it: and frightened him: (S, O, K:) and some say, roused, or excited, him: and ↓ Dw~Ehu, also, has the last but one, or the last, of these meanings. (TA.) One says, laA yaDuwEan~aka maA tasomaEu minohaA i. e. [By no means let that which thou hearest from her move thee, or disquiet thee, or frighten thee; or] do not thou be moved by what thou hearest from her; or do not thou care for it, or regard it. (TA.) And DaAEahu A^amoru ka*aA waka*aA Such and such things frightened him. (AA, TA.) ― -b2- And, said of the wind, It made it to incline; namely, a branch: (K:) and it (the wind) bore heavily upon it. (TA. [The object of the verb in this sense is not there mentioned.]) ― -b3- And i. q. $aAqahu [He, or it, excited his desire]: (so in the O, on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád:) or i. q. $aAq~ahu [he acted with him contrariously, or adversely, and inimically; &c.]. (So in copies of the K.) ― -b4- And DAE AlA_ibila, (O,) or Ald~aAb~apa, (K,) said of journeying It rendered lean, or emaciated, (O, K,) the camels, (O,) or the beast. (K.) ― -b5- And DAE faroxahu, (IAar, O, K,) aor. as above, (IAar, O,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) It (a bird) fed its young one with its bill. (IAar, O, K.) When you command the bird to do so, you say DuEo DuEo. (IAar, O.) -A2- DaAEa is also intrans.: see 5, in two places.
2 Daw~aEa see 1, first sentence, in two places.
4 maAA^aDowaEahu * , said of odour, means How sweet [or fragrant] is it! (Har p. 670.)

5 tDw~E * said of the wind, It became in motion. (TA.) And tDw~Et raAy^iHapu AlT~iybi The odour of the perfume diffused itself, or became diffused. (O.) And tDw~E Almisoku, (S, K,) as also tDy~E; (S;) or tDw~E Al$~aYo'u; (Msb,) and ↓ DAE, (S, O, Msb; K,) aor. yaDuwEu, (O, Msb) inf. n. DawoEN; (Msb;) and DAE, aor. yaDiyEu; (Har p. 670;) The musk, being put in motion, diffused its odour, or fragrance; (S, O, K, TA;) or the thing diffused its odour: (Msb:) so in a verse of Imra-el-Keys cited voce ray~aA, in art. rwY: [in which, in the place of taDaw~aEa, some read yaD~aw~aEu, for yataDaw~aEu:] (TA:) and in like manner one says of a stinking thing. (IAar, K.) And tDw~E misokFA [It diffused the odour, or fragrance, of musk]. (S, O.) ― -b2- And tDw~E minohu raAy^iHapF He snuffed, or scented, or smelt, from him, or it, an odour. (TA.) -A2- Also, said of the [bird called] DuwaE, It cried, or uttered a loud cry or crying. (AHát, O.) ― -b2- And, (O,) said of a child, (K,) He writhed, (K,) or cried out and writhed, (O, K, * TA,) in weeping; (K, * TA; in the former, mina AlbukaA='i; but correctly, fiY AlbkA='i; TA;) as also ↓ DAE, (Lth, O, K,) aor. yaDuwEu, (Lth, O,) inf. n. DawoEN: (TA:) both signify he cried, or uttered a loud cry or crying, in weeping; as one does when beaten: or the former, mostly said of a child, signifies he writhed in weeping with vehemence, and raising the voice; as expl. by Lth: (TA:) or it signifies also he (a child) wept vehemently: (O:) and, said of a young bird, it writhed, or cried out and writhed; (O, K;) as when said of a child; and so ↓ AnDAE, said of both: (K:) or ↓ AnDAE, said of a young bird, (S, O, K,) as also tDw~E, (O, K,) signifies it spread its wings to its mother in order that she might feed it with her bill. (S, O, K.)
7 AnDAE * : see the next preceding sentence, in two places. ― -b2- Also He was frightened at a thing, and cried out at it, or uttered a loud cry or crying by reason of it. (TA.)

DuwaEN * (S, O, Msb, K) and DiwaEN (AHeyth, O, K) A certain night-bird, (S, O, Msb, K,) [a species of owl, i. e.,] of the kind termed haAm: (S, O, Msb:) or [a male owl;] the male of the buwm; (S, O, Msb, K;) accord. to El-Mufaddal: (S, O:) said by ADk to be a bird that utters a scream when it perceives the daybreak: (O:) or the karawaAn [a name now given to the stonecurlew, or charadrius œdicnemus]: (K:) or a certain black bird, resembling the guraAb [or crow], (Et-Táïfee, O, K,) smaller than this, but red in its wings, these being of a roseate colour: so says AHát, on the authority of Et-Táïfee: accord. to others, he says, it is a small bird, less than the dux~al and the Hum~ar; (O;) and in like manner says Th: (TA:) also that the ↓ DuwaEap [which may be the fem. or a n. un.] is of a colour inclining to yellow, dusky and blackish externally, and yellow and ash-coloured within, short in the neck and tail, smaller than the sparrow; and that it is thus called because of the cry that it utters at the commencement of daybreak: accord. to El-Hanashee, the DuwaE is a bird such as is termed A^abogav [q. v.], resembling the domestic hen, (O,) the flesh of which is good: (O, K:) but he adds that it has been said by some to be not a bird: and in another place of the book he says that the ↓ DuwaEap is black, like the guraAb, a little larger than the Dujorap, red in the xawaAfiq: (O: [but AlxawaAfiq is an obvious mistranscription for AlxawaAfiY: see xaAfiyapN:)] the pl. is A^aDowaAEN [a pl. of pauc.] and DiyEaAnN. (S, O, Msb, K.)
DuwaEapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
DuwaAEN * The cry of the bird called DuwaE. (S, O, Msb, K.)

DawaAy^iEu * , applied to camels, (O, K,) and to other beasts, (O,) Lean, and lank in the belly: (O, K:) or emaciated: (TA:) app. from DaAEa said of journeying, meaning “ it rendered lean, or emaciated: (O:) by rule it should be DaAy^iEapN. (TA.)
AlD~aw~aAEu * , like $ad~aAd, [in the O erroneously written AlDuwaAEu,] The fox. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
maDuwEN * pass. part. n. of DaAEahu. (O, TA.)
1 DaAfa Eanohu * , inf. n. DawofN: see 1 in art Dyf.
maDuwfN * : see art. Dyf.
maDuwfapN * : see art. Dyf.
1 DaAma * , aor. yaDuwmu, inf. n. DawomN, a dial. var. of DaAma, aor. yaDiymu, inf. n. DayomN: (K:) Dumotuhu, like Dimotuhu, signifying Zalamotuhu [I wronged him, &c.]. (M, TA.)
1 DawonapN * , (K,) an inf. n. of which the verb is DaAna, aor. yaDuwnu, said of a man, (TK,) The having numerous offspring; as also ↓ taDaw~unN. (K.) [Probably from DayowanN.]
5 taDaw~ana see the preceding paragraph.
DawonN * The A_inofaHap [i. e. runnet, or runnet-bag, of a hid, or lamb]. (K.)

DaAnapN *
A nose-ring of brass (burapN M, K, mino SuforK M) for a camel: (K:) or a [camel's nose-ring such as is termed] xizaAmap; accord. to Sh: mentioned in the K in art. DA^n; but this is its proper place, for it is without. (TA.)

DawonapN *
A young female child. (K, TA. [In the CK, AlZ~aboyapu is put for AlS~abiy~apu.])

DayowanN * , (S, M, K,) of the measure fayoEalN, not faEowalN, because the former is the more common, (IB, TA,) extr. [in respect of rule], preserving
its original form, (M,) without A_idogaAm [i. e. not having its w incorporated into the Y so as to become Day~anN, as it should by rule,] because it is a primitive noun, (S,) like Hayowapu, which is a proper name of a man, (S, M,) but more extr. because that is allowable in a proper name which is not allowable in another kind of word, (M,) [A he-cat;] i. q. sin~aworN [q. v.]; (M:) the male sin~awor: (S, K:) or a certain small beast resembling the sin~awor: (M:) pl. DayaAwinu, (S, K,) in which the w is unaltered because it is so in the sing.: (S, TA:) Sb says, the dim. is ↓ Duyay~inN, like A^usay~idN [dim. of A^asowadu], but he who says A^usayowidN may say ↓ DuyayowinN. (S.)
Duyay~inN * and DuyayowinN: see what next precedes.

1 DawiYa * , aor. yaDowaY, inf. n. DawFY, He (a child, Msb) was, or became, lean, or emaciated, (S, Msb, K,) and small in body: (Msb:) or slender in the bones, and spare of body, naturally. (M, K.) [See also 4.] -A2- DawaY A_ilayohi, (S, M, K,) aor. yaDowiY, (S, K,) inf. n. DuwiY~N (S, M, K) and DaY~N, (M, K,) He adjoined himself, got him or got himself, betook him or betook himself, repaired, or resorted, to him; syn. AinoDam~a; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ AnDwY; (Har p. 73;) and he had recourse, or betook himself, to him for protection, or refuge. (S, * M, K.) ― -b2- And DawaY A_ilaY~a minohu xayorN, inf. n. DaY~N and DuwiY~N, i. q. saAla [i. e. Bounty flowed to me from him]: (M, TA:) accord. to the copies of the K, DwY AlY xabarihi sA^l; which is wrong. (TA. [In my MS. copy of the K, AlY xayorh saA^la.]) ― -b3- And DawaY signifies also It came by night: (M, K:) you say, DawaY A_ilayonaA xabaruhu The news, or tidings, of him, or it, came to us by night. (M, TA.) -A3- DuwiYa, said of a camel, He was, or became, affected with the tumours termed DawFY, (Lth, TA,) or with what is termed DawaApN [q. v.]. (M.)

4 ADwY *
He (a man, TA) was, or became, slender (K, TA) in his body. (TA. [See also DawiYa.]) And ADwY Alqawomu The people's cattle became lean, or emaciated; like ASwY Alqwm. (IKtt, TA in art. SwY.) ― -b2- And He (a man) had offspring such as is termed DaAwiY~ born to him: and in like manner ADwt is said of a woman [as meaning she brought forth such offspring]; (M;) or she brought forth a boy such as is so termed. (K.) AigotaribuwA walaA tuDowuwA, (S, M, Msb,) occurring in a trad., (S,) means Marry ye among women that are remote in respect of relationship, (S, M, Msb, *) and not among the relations of your paternal uncles, (S,) or and not among your near relations, lest your offspring be such as is termed DaAwiY~: (M, Msb:) for the Arabs assert that a man's offspring from his near relation is meagre, though generous, of the nature of his people. (S, Msb.) -A2- ADwAhu He rendered it weak. (S, Msb, K *) You say, ADwY AlA^amora (tropical:) He rendered the affair weak; (S, TA;) did not render it firm, or sound; or did not perform it in a firm, or sound, manner. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- And ADwAhu Haq~ahu (assumed tropical:) He curtailed him, or defrauded him, of his right, or due. (IAar, M, K. *) -A3- ADwAhu All~ayolu A_ilayohi The night made him to have recourse, or to betake himself, to him for protection, or refuge. (TA.)
7 A_inoDawaYa see 1, second sentence.
DawFY * inf. n. of DawiYa [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

DawaApN * [mentioned in the TA as from the K, but not in the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K inserted in the margin,] A ganglion (gudadapN, M, or gud~apN, K, TA) beneath the lobe of the ear, above the nakafap [q. v.]: (M, K, TA:) or, accord. to Az, [a thing] resembling a gud~ap. (TA.) And A tumour occurring in the fauces of camels and other animals: pl. ↓ DawFY: (M:) or this latter [is properly termed a coll. gen. n., of which DawaApN is the n. un., and] signifies tumours accidental to the camel, in his head, having an overpowering effect upon his eyes, and rendering it difficult to attach to him the [halter called] xiTaAm; and sometimes it is in the side of the mouth. (Lth, TA.) And (M, TA) A siloEap [or ganglion] (S, M, TA) in a camel, (S,) or in any part of the body. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also A certain thing, or small thing, (hanapN,) that comes forth from the she-camel's vulva before the coming forth of the fœtus. (M, K, TA.)
DaAwK * : see the next paragraph. -A2- Also Coming by night; syn. TaAriqN [which Golius here explains as meaning “ Lucifer, ” and supposes to be for DaAwiy^N]. (M, K.)

DaAwiY~N * , (S, M, Msb, K,) of the measure faAEuwlN, [originally DaAwuwYN,] (S, Msb,) and ↓ DaAwK, (Msb, TA,) applied to a boy, (S, M, K,) and with p applied to a girl, (S, Msb, K,) Lean, or emaciated, (S, Msb, K,) and small in body: (Msb:) or slender in the bones, and spare of body, naturally: (M, K:) and likewise applied to any species of animal: (M:) accord. to the T, the offspring of an incestuous union. (TA.) AlD~aAwiY~u, (T, TA,) not without teshdeed, as the text of the K implies it to be, (TA,) was the name of A certain horse, (T, K, TA,) belonging to Ghanee. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also the former, disordered, or diseased, and near to dying: [so I render HaAriDN, q. v.:] and weak; in a bad, or corrupt, state. (TA.)

fiyhi DaAwiy~apN *
In him is leanness or emaciation [&c.]: (S:) i. q. DawFY [the inf. n. of DawiYa, used as a subst.]. (TA.)
maDowiY~N * , applied to a camel, part. n. of DuwiYa [q. v.]. (Lth, TA.)
1 DaAHa All~abana * : see 2, in two places. -A2- DaAHati AlbilaAdu The tracts of land became vacant, (K, TA,) by reason of drought. (TA.)

2 Dy~H All~abana * , (S, O, K,) inf. n. taDoyiyHN, (S,) He mixed the milk with water, (S, O, K,) so that it became DayoH; (S;) as also Daw~aHahu, as heard by Az from an Arab of the desert; (TA;) and ↓ DaAHahu, (O, K,) inf. n. DayoHN, but this last is said by IDrd to be obsolete: (O:) or ↓ DaAHahu, inf. n. DayoHN, he poured water into it, it being thick, and then stirred it about until it became of a uniform consistence. (T, TA.) ― -b2- And Dy~Hhu He gave him to drink thin milk, mixed with water, such as is termed DayoH; (S, K;) as also Dw~Hhu. (K.)
4 ADAH * , said of the muqol [or fruit of the Theban palm] It became what is termed DayoH, and fit to be eaten. (O.)

5 tD~yH *
It (milk) became what is termed DayaAH; (K;) i. e. it was diluted with water, and stirred about until it became of a uniform consistence: and so any medicine, or poison. (TA.) ― -b2- And He (a man) drank what is termed DayaAH. (K.)

DayoHN * and ↓ DayaAHN Thin milk, mixed (S, O, K, TA) with much water: the former expl. by As as meaning milk in which is much water: the latter expl. in the T as thick milk into which water is poured, and which is then stirred about until it becomes of a uniform consistence: also, both words, milk, whether it be fresh or such as is termed raAy^ib [q. v.], upon which water is poured until it has become thin: and ↓ DayaAHN and ↓ muDay~aHN any medicine or poison having water poured into it, and then stirred about until it becomes of a uniform consistence: or, accord. to Lth, only milk is termed DayaAH. (TA.) [See an ex. voce xaDaArN.] ― -b2- DayoHN also signifies Honey. (O, K.) ― -b3- And Ripe muqol [or fruit of the Theban palm]: (O, K: [see 4:]) this is of the dial. of El-Yemen, universally. (O.)

DiyHN *
i. q. DiH~N [q. v.]: (K:) ascribed by IDrd to the vulgar. (TA.) ― -b2- Also an imitative sequent to ryH, (K,) [i. e.] a corroborative of ryH, (O,) in the phrase jaA='a biAlr~iyHi waAlD~iyHi [expl. voce DiH~N], and therefore having no meaning if used alone. (O, * TA.)
DaAHapN * The sight: (O, K:) one says, maA A^ajowada DaAHatahu [How good, or excellent, is his sight!]: (O:) or the eye. (K.)

DayoHapN *
A single drink, or draught, of thin milk, such as is termed DayoH. (TA.)
DayaAHN * : see DayoHN, in two places.
muDay~aHN * : see DayoHN.
Eayo$N maDoyuwHN * (tropical:) A turbid life; syn. mamo*uwqN. (Fr, O, K, TA.)

mutaDay~iHN * (tropical:) Coming to the watering-trough when
most of the contents thereof has been drunk and there remains but little, mixed, (IAth, * O, K, TA,) and turbid; (IAth, TA;) this being likened to milk mixed with water: (TA:) or coming to water the last of the people. (AHeyth, TA.)

1 DaArahu * , aor. yaDiyru, inf. n. DayorN; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also DaArahu, aor. yaDuwru, inf. n. DaworN; (S, M, K;) It (a thing, M, K) harmed, injured, hurt, mischiefed, or damaged, him; i. q. Dar~ahu, (S, M, K,) or A^aDar~a bihi. (Msb.) You say, h`*aA mim~aA laA yaDiyruka [This is of the things that will not harm thee]: and lawo faEalotahu lamo yaDiroka [Hadst thou done it, it had not harmed thee]: and laA Dayora Ealayoka [No harm shall befall thee]. (A.) And maA yaDiyruka EalaY AlD~ab~i SiyodN i. q. maA yaDur~uka q. v. (A in art. Dr.) And Ks says that he had heard (from one of the people of El-' Áliyeh. TA) the phrase laA yanofaEuniY *`lika walaA yaDuwruniY [That will not benefit me, nor will it harm me]. (S, TA.) See also a reading of a phrase in a trad. cited in art. Dr. conj. 3.

1 DaAza * , (S, K,) aor. yaDiyzu, inf. n. DayozN, (TA,) He deviated from the right course; or acted unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically; (S, K;) fiY AlHukomi in the judgment: (S:) like DaA^aza. (TA in art. DA^z.) ― -b2- DaAzahu Haq~ahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, He deprived him, or defrauded him, of a part, or the whole, of his right, or due: (S, M, K:) like DaAzahu, aor. yaDuwzuhu: (K:) he refused it to him, or withheld it from him: (AZ, M, TA:) and sometimes one says DaA^azahu, aor. yaDoA^azuhu, inf. n. DaA^ozN. (S, TA.)

qisomapN DiyzaY *
An unjust, (S, M,) or a defective, (K in art. DA^z,) division: (S, M, K:) as also DuwzaY: (M:) DyzY in the Kur liii. 22 is read by all without hemz: (TA:) it is of the measure fuEolaY, like TuwbaY and HubolaY; but the D is with kesr in order that the Y may remain unchanged; for there is not in the language an epithet of the measure fiEolaY; this being a measure of substantives, like Al$~iEoraY and Ald~ifolaY: (S:) or, accord. to Aboo-' Alee, it is not an epithet, but an inf. n., like *ikoraY, as though the meaning were qisomapN *aAtu jaworK: (Har p. 524:) Fr says that some of the Arabs say DaA^ozaY, and Duw^ozaY: and AHát mentions AZ's having heard the Arabs say Diy^ozaY, with hemz. (S.)

1 DaAEa * , aor. yaDiyEu, inf. n. DayaAEN and DayoEapN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and DayoEN and DiyEN, (K,) It (a thing, S, Mgh, O, Msb) perished, came to nought, passed away, or became lost. (S, O, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad. of Saad, A_in~iY A^axaAfu EalaY AlA^aEonaAbi AlD~ayoEupa i. e. [Verily I fear, for the grapes,] their [lit. the] perishing, or becoming lost. (TA.) ― -b2- And DAE, (K, TA,) inf. n. DayaAEN and DayoEapN, (TA,) It (a thing) was left; left, or let, alone; or neglected. (K, TA.) Hence, DAEt AlA_ibilu, and DAE AlEiyaAlu, The camels, and the family, or household, were left untended, and unminded; and were left alone, or neglected. (TA.) -A2- DAE, aor. yaDiyEu, said of perfume, or sweet odour, i. q. DAE having for its aor. yaDuwEu. (Har p. 670.) [See 5 in art. DwE: and see also 5 in the present art.]

2 Dy~E Al$~aYo'a * , (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. taDoyiyEN; (S;) and ↓ ADAEhu, (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iDaAEapN; (S;) both signify the same; (S, O, Msb, K;) He made, or caused, the thing to perish, or become lost; he destroyed it, wasted it, or lost it. (Msb, K, TA.) Hence, Day~aEuwA fulaAnFA is used by the vulgar as meaning They beheaded such a one with the sword. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AlS~ayofa Day~aEoti All~abana [In the spring, or in the summer, thou losedst the milk], in which the t is with kesr when the words are addressed to a male, or to a female, or to a pl. number, because originally addressed to a woman, the wife of a wealthy man, whom she disliked because of his being aged, wherefore he divorced her, and a poor man married her, and she sent to her first husband requesting a gift, and he answered her thus; (S, O, K; *) AlSyf being in the accus. case as an adv. n.: so says Yaakoob: (S, O:) or El-Aswad Ibn-Hurmuz divorced his wife El- ' Anood Esh-Shenneeyeh, (O, K,) of the BenooShenn, (TA,) preferring to her a beautiful and wealthy woman of his people; (O, K; *) then there occurred between them what led to their separation, and he sought to obtain [again] El- ' Anood, and sent a message to her; but in replying to him she said,
A^ano$aA^ota taTolubu waSolanaA
fiY AlS~ayofi Day~aEota All~abano
[Thou hast begun to seek our union: in the spring, or in the summer, thou losedst the milk]: (O, * K:) the t in this case being with fet-h. (K. [See more in Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 197-8, or in Har p. 577; in both of which, however, and in the O, Dy~Et is with kesr in the latter case, as in the former.]) [One says also, Dy~E Eahodahu, meaning He broke his compact, contract, or covenant]. The phrase, in a trad., nahaY Eano AlmaAli ↓ A_iDaAEapi means He forbade the expending of wealth otherwise than in obedience to God, and the squandering thereof, and extravagance. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

4 ADAE Al$~aYo'a * : see 2, first sentence, and last but one. ― -b2- Also, [and app. ↓ Dy~Ehu likewise, accord. to the K,] He left the thing; left it, or let it, alone; or neglected it. (K, TA.) You say, ADAE EiyaAlahu He neglected his family, or household; omitted taking good care of them, or being mindful of them. (TA.) wamaA kaAna A@ll~`hu liyuDiEa A_iymaAnakumo, in the Kur [ii. 138], means And God will not neglect [or make to be lost] your prayer. (TA.) A^aDaAEuwA AlS~alaApa, in the same, [xix. 60,] means Who neglected, or omitted, prayer, (Bd, TA,) altogether: (TA:) or deferred it: (Bd:) or who performed it in other than its right time: but the first explanation is more suitable, for the unbelievers are meant thereby. (TA.) -A2- ADAE [is also intrans., and] may signify He found his affair to be coming to nought. (Ham p. 33.) ― -b2- And His estates (DiyaAEuhu) became wide-spread, (S, O, K,) and many, or numerous. (S, O, Msb, K.)

5 tDy~E * , said of the wind, It blew: because it [often] destroys that upon which it blows: so says Er-Rághib. (TA. [But it may be from what here follows.]) ― -b2- Said of musk, It diffused its odour, or fragrance: (S, O, K;) a dial. var. of tDw~E: (S:) or an instance of substitution [of Y for w]. (O.) [See also 1, last explanation.]
maAta DiyoEFA * and DiyaEFA: see DayaAEN.

DayoEapN * an inf. n. of 1. (S, &c.) ― -b2- See DayaAEN, below, last sentence but one. ― -b3- Also A single case, or occasion, of perishing, coming to nought, passing away, or becoming lost; or of being left, left or let alone, or neglected. (TA.) ― -b4- tarakotuhu biDayoEapK means I left him unsought-after, or unminded, or unmissed. (TA. [See also a similar phrase voce DayaAEN.]) -A2- Also i. q. EaqaArN [meaning An estate consisting of land, or of land and a house, or of a house or land yielding a revenue, or of a house and palm-trees, or the like]; (S, O, Msb, K;) and [particularly] land yielding a revenue; (K;) or with the people of the towns and villages and cultivated lands it signifies the property, of a man, consisting of palm-trees and grape-vines and land: but the Arabs [of the desert] know not the word in this sense: (Az, TA:) IF says, I do not reckon the application of this word as a name for the EaqaAr to be of the original language, but think it to be an innovation in speech; and I have heard it said that this is termed a DyEp because, when frequent attention to it is neglected, it perishes; and if it be so, this is an evidence of what we have said, that it is of the innovated speech: (O, TA:) the dim. is ↓ DuyayoEapN, for which one should not say DuwayoEapN: (S, O, K:) the pl. is DiyaAEN and DiyaEN, (S, O, Msb, K,) as though the latter were a contraction of the former, (Msb,) and DayoEaAtN: (K:) accord. to Lth, the first of these pls. signifies places of alighting or abode or settlement; which are thus called because, when the paying frequent attention to them, or taking good care of them, and the keeping them, or putting them, in a good state, or state of repair, is neglected, they come to nought: and DayoEaAtN occurs in a trad. as meaning the means of subsistence. (TA.) And, (T, O, Msb, K,) as used by the Arabs [of the desert], who know not the word in any other sense than this, (T, O,) A craft, or handicraft, by which one gains his subsistence; a mode, or manner, of gain; or any
habitual work or occupation of a man; (T, O, Msb, K) as the sewing of skins or boots and the like; and the twisting of ropes; and the weaving, or plaiting, of palm-leaves; and the culture of palm-trees (Eamalu Aln~axoli); and the pasturing of camels; and the like thereof; (T, O;) including the sowing, or tilling, of land: (TA:) or the DayoEap of the Arabs was the management, or tending, of camels and of sheep and goats: and the term includes a man's craft, or handicraft, or means of gain: (Sh, O:) and his traffic: (Sh, O, K:) one says to a man, qumo A_ilaY DayoEatika [Arise to thy craft, &c.]: (Sh, O:) and kul~u rajulK waDayoEatahu, [Every man should occupy himself with his proper craft, &c.] (Msb.) A^afo$aY A@ll~`hu, DayoEatahu, occurring in a trad., means God made or may God make, his means of subsistence to be abundant. (TA.) And one says, fa$ato DayoEatuhu, [or, more commonly, fa$ato Ealayohi DayoEatuhu, as in the TA in art. f$w, &c.,] which is said to mean His property was, or became, large, or abundant, [or wide-spread,] so that he was unable to collect it together: and [hence] his means of attaining his object [or his affairs (as in the TA in art. f$w)] became disordered so that he knew not with which of them to begin: (TA:) or he took to doing an affair that did not concern him: (TA, and Ham p. 33:) it is nearly like the saying Ait~asaEa Alxaroqu EalaY Alr~aAqiEi [expl. in art. xrq]. (Ham ibid.) And A_in~iY laA^araY DayoEapF laA yuSoliHuhaA A_il~aA DajoEapN [Verily I see property that nothing but a sleep will restore to a right state] a prov.; said by a pastor whose camels had dispersed themselves, and who, desiring to collect them together, and being unable to do so, sought aid of sleep. (O.)
maAta DiyEapF * : see the next paragraph.

DayaAEN * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, &c.) [Hence] one says, maAta DayaAEFA, as also ↓ DiyaEFA, and ↓ DiyoEFA, and ↓ DiyEapN, He (a man, TA) died unsought-after, or unminded, or unmissed. (K, TA. [See also a similar phrase voce DayoEapN.]) ― -b2- Also A family, or household: (ISh, O, K:) or the meaning is EiyaAlN Duy~aEN, (Mgh, O, K, *) i. e. a family, or household, neglected, untended, and unminded; (TA;) or such as are exposed, or liable, to perish, (biEaraDi A^ano yaDiyEa,) as young children, and those who are crippled, or deprived of the power of motion, who cannot manage their own affairs: (Mgh:) occurring in a trad., in which it is said that when a man died leaving such as are thus termed, (taraka DayaAEFA,) they were to be brought to the Prophet, (Mgh, O,) to be maintained by means of the government-treasury: (Mgh:) a prefixed noun is to be understood [i. e. it is for EiyaAla DayaAEK or the like]: (Mgh:) or it is an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly thus termed]: (Mgh, O:) or, accord. to one relation of the trad., the word is ↓ DayoEapF [which is likewise an inf. n., and in this case to be expl. in the same manner]: (Mgh:) if read DiyaAEFA, it would be pl. of DaAy^iEN. (Mgh, O.) -A2- Also A sort of perfume, or odoriferous substance. (K.)
DuyayoEapN * dim. of DayoEapN, q. v. (S, O, K.)

DaAy^EN *
Perishing, coming to nought, passing away, or becoming lost: (Mgh, * Msb:) [and being left; left, or let, alone; or neglected:] part. n. of 1: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. DiyaAEN (Mgh, O, Msb, K) and Duy~aEN. (Mgh, O, * Msb, K. *) [See an ex. of the latter pl. in a verse cited voce daAna, in art. dyn. See also saAy^iEN, in art. swE.] ― -b2- And A man in a state of poverty: or having a family, or household, to sustain: or in a state of circumstances by means of which he is unable to subsist. (TA.) ― -b3- fulaAnN yaA^okulu fiY miEFY DaAy^iEK means jaAy^iEK [i. e. Such a one eats into a hungry, or an empty, gut]: and it was said to the daughters of ElKhuss, “ What is the sharpest thing? (maA A^aHad~u $aYo';) and she answered, naAbN jaAy^iEN yuloqiY fiY miEFY DaAy^iEK [A hungry canine tooth that throws the food into an empty gut]. (S.)
A^aDoyaEu * means A^akovaru DayaAEFA: so in the saying, fulaAnN A^aDoyaEu mino fulaAnK [Such a one is in a more perishing state than such a one]. (TA.)

muDiyEN * act. part. n. of the trans. v. ADAE. (TA.) [See misoyaAEN, in art. swE.] -A2- And part. n. of the intrans. v. ADAE; as such signifying One whose estates (DiyaAEuhu) are becoming wide-spread, and many, or numerous. (S, TA.)

maDiyEapN * and maDoyaEapN i. q. DayaAEN [an inf. n. of 1, q. v.]. (Mgh, O, Msb, K.) So in the saying, taraka EiyaAlahu bimaDiyEapK or bimaDoyaEapK [He left his family, or household, in a state of perishing, &c.]. (Mgh.) So too in the saying, Als~aAriqu laA yuqoTaEu fiY maAlK bimaDiyEapK [The thief shall not suffer amputation of his hand in the case of his stealing property in a neglected state]. (Mgh.) And so in the saying, huwa bidaAri maDiyEapK (S, * O, K) and maDoyaEapK (O, K) [He is in a place (lit. an abode) of perdition, &c.]: or as meaning in this saying, abandonment, and ignominy. (TA.) And huwa muqiymN bidaAri maDiyEapK or maDoyaEapK means [He is dwelling in the abode of indolence; or] his characteristic in his affairs is indolence. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, [or perhaps the latter only, as meaning A cause of perishing &c., this latter being app. of the class of maboxalapN and majobanapN &c.,] A desert, or waterless desert, that is cut off [from inhabited regions]: or, as expl. by IJ, a place in which a man perishes, or is lost. (Msb.)
muDay~iEN * : see what follows.

rajulN miDoyaAEN lilomaAli *
i. q. lahu ↓ muDay~iEN [i. e. A man who wastes, or squanders, wealth, or property]. (S, O, K.)

1 DaAfa * , (M, K,) [aor. yaDiyfu,] inf. n. DayofN; (TK;) and ↓ ADAf, (M,) and ↓ tDy~f, and ↓ Dy~f; (K;) He, or it, inclined, (M, K,) and approached, or drew near; A_ilayohi [to him, or it]. (M.) ― -b2- And DAft Al$~amosu, (S, M, Mgh,) or DAft Al$ms liloguruwbi, (O,) aor. taDiyfu, inf. n. DayofN; (M;) and ↓ tDy~ft, (S, M, Mgh,) or tDy~ft llgrwb; (O;) and ↓ Dy~ft, (S, M, Mgh,) Dy~ft llgrwb; (O;) The sun inclined, (S, Mgh, O,) or drew near, (M,) to setting. (S, M, Mgh, O.) ― -b3- And DAft said of a woman, aor. as above, She menstruated; (O, K;) because she who does so inclines, or declines, from a state of pureness to menstruation. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And DAf Als~ahomu, (M,) or DAf Alshm Eani Alhadafi, (S, O,) The arrow turned aside from the butt: (S, M, O:) like SAf. (S, O.) And DAf Eani Al$~aYo'i, inf. n. DawofN [and DayofN], He, or it, turned away from the thing: like SAf, inf. n. SawofN [and SayofN]. (M in art. Dwf.) ― -b5- And DAf said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He feared; as also ↓ ADAf. (M.) And minohu ↓ ADAf (assumed tropical:) He feared it, or was cautious of it; namely, an event, or affair; (S, M, O, K, TA;) as also DAf minohu: (TA:) or (tropical:) he was cautious of it with the caution of one encompassed, or beset, thereby. (Z, TA.) -A2- Difotuhu, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor. A^aDiyfuhu, (O, K,) inf. n. DiyaAfapN, (S,) or DayofN, (Msb,) or both; (M, O, K;) and ↓ taDay~afotuhu; (S, M, O, K;) I alighted at his abode; (M, Msb;) and inclined to him: (M:) or I alighted at his abode (S, M, O, Msb, K) as a Dayof [or guest], (S, O, K,) or and became his Dayof [or guest]. (M, O, Msb. [See also 3.]) And DAf Alqawoma, and ↓ taDay~afahumo, He alighted at the abode of the people, or party, as a Dayof [or guest]. (Mgh.) And ↓ taDay~afotuhu I came to him as a Dayof [or guest]. (L, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] DAfhu Alham~u (assumed tropical:) Anxiety befell him. (S, M, * O. [See, again, 3.]) ― -b3- And Difotuhu signifies also I sought, or desired, of him entertainment as a Dayof [or guest]; and so ↓ taDay~afotuhu; (M;) or this latter, (L, Msb,) and ↓ AisotaDafotuhu, (M,) I asked of him such entertainment. (M, L, Msb.)

2 Dy~f * , intrans.: see 1, first and second sentences. -A2- As trans.: see 4, last sentence, in four places. ― -b2- [Hence,] Day~afotuhu signifies also (assumed tropical:) I protected him, or defended him, from him who sought, or pursued, him: (Msb:) (tropical:) I rendered him safe, secure, or free from fear; and became at peace with him; thus used metaphorically. (TA.)

3 DAyfhu * [app. signifies He straitened him: (see 6:) or, perhaps, he became his guest; like DaAfahu, &c]. ― -b2- [Hence one says,] DAyfhu Alham~u (tropical:) [Anxiety straitened him: or, perhaps, befell him; like DaAfahu]. (TA.) ― -b3- [And DAyfhu, inf. n. muDaAyafapN, signifies also It was, or became, correlative to it; as, for instance, fathership to sonship. See also the next paragraph.]

4 ADAf * , intrans.: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Also, said of a man, He ran, and hastened, made haste, or sped, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) and fled, or
turned away and fled: (K:) and said of a dog as meaning he ran away, or fled. (TA in art. jbn.) ― -b3- And ADAf EalaY Al$~aYo'i i. q. A^a$orafa Ealayohi [He looked upon, or viewed, the thing from above: or he was, or became, on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of the thing: &c.]. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b4- tuDiyfu A_ilaY Sawoti AlfaHoli, said of a she-camel, means She hears with desire of going to him the voice, or sound, of the stallion. (M.) ― -b5- And AlA_iDaAfapu and ↓ Alt~aDaAyufu signify Correlation, or reciprocal relation, so that one of the two cannot be conceived in the mind without the other; as in the case of AlA^ubuw~apu and Albunuw~apu [i. e. fathership and sonship]. (KT. [See also 3.]) -A2- ADAfhu A_ilayohi He made it to incline towards it; (S, M, * O, Msb, K; *) namely, a thing (S, O) to a thing. (S, O, Msb.) He made it to lean, rest, or stay itself, against it, or upon it. (M, TA.) You say, ADAf Zahorahu A_ilaY AlHaAy^iTi He leaned his back against the wall. (MA.) And ADAf A_ilayohi A^amorFA (tropical:) He rested, or stayed, upon him an affair, and desired him to do what would suffice. (TA.) ― -b2- And He made him to have recourse to it, or to betake himself to it for refuge. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And He adjoined it to it. (Msb.) ― -b4- And hence AlA_iDaAfapu as a conventional term of the grammarians; because the first [of two nouns in the case to which it applies] is adjoined to the second: (Msb:) [for] A_iDaAfapu AlAisomi A_ilaY AlAisomi is [The prefixing the noun to the noun so that the former governs the latter in the gen. case] as when you say gulaAmu zayodK; in which instance, glAm is termed ↓ muDaAfN, and zyd is termed A_ilayohi ↓ muDaAfN: and this is done for the purpose of particularizing or appropriating, and of making known or definite: therefore the A_iDaAfap of a thing to itself [i. e. the prefixing a noun in this manner to one identical therewith in meaning] is not allowable, because a thing does not make known, or definite, itself; (S;) unless by an ellipsis, as when you say Haq~u Alyaqiyni for Haq~u Al$~aYo'i Alyaqiyni; or, accord. to Fr, the Arabs used to do so because of the difference of the two words themselves. (S voce jaAmiEN.) [AlA_iDaAfapu is also often used as meaning The state of being prefixed in the manner explained above; or the connection of a noun so prefixed with its complement. The various kinds of A_iDaAfap are sufficiently explained in the grammars of De Sacy and others: they are not proper subjects of a lexicon, though much is said respecting them in the O, and more in the Msb. ― -b5- Hence also, biAlA_iDaAfapi A_ilaY ka*aA meaning In comparison with (lit. to), or in relation to, (like biAln~isobapi A_ilaY,) such a thing; as though in juxtaposition to it: a phrase of frequent occurrence: see an ex. in Bd ii. 6.] ― -b6- A^aDafotuhu (inf. n. A_iDaAfapN, Msb) and ↓ Day~afotuhu (inf. n. taDoyiyfN, O) both signify the same, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) from AlD~iyaAfapu; (O;) i. e. both signify I made him a guest, or lodged him, or gave him refuge or asylum, syn. A^anozalotuhu, (S, M, Msb,) with me, as a Dayof [or guest], (S,) and entertained him: (S, M, Msb:) A^aDaAfuwhu and ↓ Day~afuwhu both signify A^anozaluwhu: (Mgh:) accord. to Th, A^aDafotuhu signifies I lodged him at my abode as a Dayof: and I gave him (i. e. one in fear) protection, or refuge or asylum: (Msb:) and ↓ Day~afotuhu is also expl. as meaning I fed him: and ↓ Dy~fhu as meaning he made him to be in the condition of A^aDoyaAf [or guests]. (TA.)

5 taDay~afa intrans.: see 1, first and second sentences. ― -b2- taDay~ufN signifies also The being collected together. (KL, from the Mj.) ― -b3- And The being a taAbiE [or follower, &c.]. (Id.) -A2- As trans.: see 1, latter half, in four places.

6 taDaAoyafa see 4. -A2- tDAyf as said of a valley, [from DiyfN “ a side, ”] It became narrow; syn. taDaAyaqa. (S, M, O.) taDaAyafona Ealayohi, a phrase used by a poet [describing camels following an old camel], They became near to him, (S, M, O,) by his side. (S, M.) And you say, tDAyfhu Alqawomu The people, or party, became on both sides of him (biDiyfayohi). (TA.) And taDaAyfuh Als~abuEaAni The two beasts of prey hemmed him in on both sides. (TA.) And taDaAyafati AlkilaAbu AlS~ayoda and taDaAyafato Ealayohi [The dogs hemmed in the object of the chase on both sides, or round about]. (TA.) [In the TA, all these are said to be tropical; but why, I see not.]
7 AnDAf A_ilayohi * signifies He, or it, became joined, or adjoined, or added, to him, or it: and he joined himself to him: but is perhaps postclassical.]

10 A_isotaDoyafa see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- You say also AisotaDaAfaniY, meaning He desired me, or asked me, to grant him protection, or refuge. (Msb.) And AstDAf fulaAnN A_ilaY fulaAnK Such a one had recourse, or betook himself, to such a one for protection, or refuge. (IAar, M.)

DayofN *
A guest: and guests: (MA:) so called because adjoined to the family and fed with them: (Ham p. 124:) it is applied to one, and to a pl. number, (S, M, MA, O, Msb, K,) and to a male and to a female, (S, O, Msb, K,) because it is originally an inf. n.: (MA, Msb:) [as a sing.,] i. q. ↓ muDay~afN, (M,) which is syn. with naziylN: (TA:) and applied to a pl. number, it may be pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of ↓ DaAy^ifN, which is syn. with naAzilN; thus being of the class of zawozN and SawomN: (M:) and it is also pluralized, having for its pls. A^aDoyaAfN and DiyfaAnN (S, M, MA, O, Msb, K) and DuyuwfN (S, M, MA, O, K) and DiyaAfN, (MA, TA,) the first of which is properly a pl. of pauc., but is also used as a pl. of mult.: (M:) and a female is termed DayofapN as well as DayofN: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) El-Ba'eeth says,
laqFY Hamalatohu A^um~uhu wahoYa DayofapN
[A castaway with whom his mother became pregnant while she was a guest]: (S, M, O:) or, accord. to AHeyth, the meaning here is that which follows. (O.) ― -b2- DayofapN applied to a woman signifies also Menstruating: (O, K:) so says AHeyth with reference to the citation above from El-Ba'eeth. (O.)

DiyfN * The side (T, S, M, O, K) of a valley (T, M) and of a mountain (M) [&c.: see 6]: and, as metaphorically used by an anonymous poet, of the *akar: (M:) and ↓ maDaAyifu signifies the sides of a valley. (TA.) ― -b2- And one says, fulaAnN fiY Diyfi fulaAnK, meaning Such a one is in the vicinage, or quarter, of such a one. (M.)

DayofanN *
One who comes with a guest: (S, O:) or who so comes intruding without invitation: (K:) or one who follows a guest: derived from DayofN, accord. to Sb; but said by AZ to belong to art. Dfn: (M:) [accord. to J and Sgh] the n is augmentative: the pl. is DayaAfinu. (S, O.)

DiyaAfapN * an inf. n. of Difotuhu in the first of the senses assigned to the latter above. (S, M, O, K.) ― -b2- [And] a subst. from A^aDafotuhu and Day~afotuhu [as such signifying The entertainment of a guest or guests; i. e. the act of entertaining: and an entertainment as meaning a repast, given to a guest or guests; a banquet, or feast]. (Msb.) [Hence, daAru AlD~iyaAfapi The house of entertainment of guests.]
DaAy^ifN * A man alighting as a guest; syn. naAzilN: (M, TA:) see DayofN: its [proper] pl. is Duy~afN. (TA.)

muDaAfN * ; and muDaAfN A_ilayohi: see 4. ― -b2- The former signifies also (tropical:) One who is made an adjunct, or adherent, to a people, or party, (S, M, O, K, TA,) and made to incline to them, (M,) not being of them. (M, TA.) One says, maA huwa A_il~aA muDaAfN (tropical:) [He is none other than an adjunct, or adherent].
