(TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) One whose origin, or lineage, or parentage, is suspected; or who makes a claim to relationship not having it: (O, K, TA:) and (K) whose origin, or relationship, is referred to a people, or party, of whom he is not a member. (O, K, TA.) ― -b4- And One who is constrained to betake himself to a place of refuge, (M, O, K, TA,) to a narrow, or confined, place, and who is burdened with evil: (TA:) El-Bureyk ElHudhalee says,
wayaHomiY AlmuDaAfa A_i*aA maA daEaA
[And he protects him who is constrained to betake himself to a place of refuge, when he calls for aid]. (M.) And ↓ musotaDaAfN signifies the same as muDaAfN [app. in the last of the senses expl. above]: so says IB; and he cites the saying of Jowwás Ibn-Heiyán El-Azdee,
Ei waA^aHomiY AlmusotaDaAfaA ↓ walaqado A^aqodamu fiY Alr~awN
[app. meaning And verily I advance boldly in the case of fear, and I protect him who is constrained to betake himself to a place of refuge]. (TA.) [See also maDuwfN.] ― -b5- Also One who is beset, hemmed in, or encompassed, in war, or battle: (S, O, K: said in the TA to be tropical:) or one falling among the horsemen and men of valour, having in him no strength. (M.) [See, again, maDuwfN.] ― -b6- And One in a state of fear. (TA.)

maDuwfN *
Beset by distress of mind: (TA:) [accord. to Freytag, as from the Deewán of the
Hudhalees, constrained to seek refuge: (see also muDaAfN:)] it occurs in the saying of the Hudhalee,
A^anota tujiybu daEowapa AlmaDuwfi
[Thou answerest the prayer, or call, of him who is beset &c.]; and is formed after the manner of buwEa for biyEa. (M, TA.)

maDiyfN * a dial. var. of maSiyfN [q. v.]. (TA.) [ISd says that] maDiyfFA occurring in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb [as some relate it], cited voce karabapN, [where the reading of maSiyfFA is given,] is for DaAy^ifFA, meaning Turning aside; crooked. (M.)

muDiyfN *
Fleeing; or turning away and fleeing. (Ibn-'Abbád, O. [See also its verb.])

muDaAfapN *
Hardship, or difficulty, or distress. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

maDuwfapN * , an anomalous word, by rule maDiyfapN, (Kh, Sb, TA in art. Dwf,) Anxiety; and want, or a want; (O and K in that art.;) and ↓ maDiyfapN and ↓ muDiyfapN signify the same; (O in that art. and in art. Dyf;) or these two signify anxiety, and grief: (K in this art.:) or maDuwfapN signifies an affair, or event, that is feared, or of which one is cautious; (S and M in this art.;) thus accord. to As; and ↓ maDiyfapN and ↓ muDaAfapN signify the same. (S, L, TA.)
maDiyfapN * and muDiyfapN: see both in the next preceding paragraph; the former in two places.
maDoyafapN * , of the measure mafoEalapN, A place of DiyaAfap [i. e. entertainment of a guest or guests: pl. maDaAyifu]. (TA.)
muDay~afN * : see DayfN.
muDay~ifN * The master of an abode in which guests are entertained; as also ↓ maDaAyifiY~N. (TA.)
miDoyaAfN * [One who often entertains guests]. (Har p. 579.)
maDaAyifu * [pl. of maDoyafapN: ― -b2- and also of a sing. not mentioned]: see DiyfN.
maDaAyifiY~N * [from maDaAyifu pl. of maDoyafapN]: see muDay~ifN.

A_isomaA='N mutaDaAyifapN *
Correlative nouns; i. e. nouns significant of the existence of persons, or things, whereof the existence of one necessarily indicates the existence of another; as A^abN and AibonN [father and son]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
musotaDaAfN * : see muDaAfN.
musotaDiyfN * [act. part. n. of 10, q. v.:] Asking, or calling, for aid, or succour. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

1 DaAqa * , aor. yaDiyqu, inf. n. DayoqN (S, O, Msb, K) and DiyqN, (S, O, K,) or this latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) It was, or became, narrow, or strait; contr. of Ait~asaEa; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ tDy~q, [or rather this signifies it was, or became, rendered narrow, or strait, being quasipass. of 2,] and ↓ tDAyq: (K:) it is said of a thing, (S, O, Msb,) and of a place. (Msb.) [See also DayoqN below.] DaAqato Ealayohimu A@loA^aroDu, in the Kur ix. 119, means The earth became strait to them. (Bd, Jel.) And one says, DaAqato bihi AlA^aroDu [meaning, in like manner, The earth, or land, became narrow, or strait, with him]: 'Amr Ibn-El-Ahtam says,
laEamoruka maA DaAqato bilaAdN biA^aholihaA
wal`kin~a A^axolaAqa Alr~ijaAli taDiyqu
[By thy life, or by thy religion, countries have not become narrow with their inhabitants, but the dispositions of the men become narrow]. (O, TA.) [DAq bihi often signifies, and so does bh ↓ tDAyq, It was, or became, choked, surcharged, or overfilled, with it; for instance, a water-course with water, and a place with people.] And ↓ tDAyq bihi AlA^amoru means DAq Ealayohi (tropical:) [The affair was, or became, strait to him]. (O, TA. [See an ex. in art. rHb, conj. 6.]) One says also, DAq Ealayohi maEaA$uhu: see 4. [And DAq Alwaqotu (assumed tropical:) The time became strait, or contracted.] And DAq Sadoruhu (assumed tropical:) His bosom, or mind, became strait, or contracted: (Msb:) and DAq Eanohu Sadoruka (assumed tropical:) [Thy mind became so contracted as to be incapable of it: or thy mind shrank from it]. (K.) [And yaDiyqu AlEaqolu Eano taqodiyrihi (assumed tropical:) The intellect is incapable of determining its limit, or limits, or the like.] And DAq Eani AljawaAbi and biAljawaAbi (assumed tropical:) [He was straitened, or embarrassed, so as to be unable to reply, or to answer; he was incapable of replying, or answering]: both signify the same. (TA in art. znd.) And DAq bAlA^amori *aroEFA, (S, * O, * Msb,) meaning (assumed tropical:) The thing, or affair, was difficult, or distressing, to him, (Msb,) originally DAq *aroEuhu bihi, (S, * O, * Msb,) i. e. his ability [was straitened by it, or was inadequate to it]; and his power: (Msb:) or his art, or artifice, or cunning: or his way, course, mode, or manner, of acting (ma*ohabuhu) [was straitened, or rendered difficult, or distressing, by it]. (O. [See more voce *aroEN: and see a similar phrase in the Kur xi. 79 and xxix. 32.]) And hence, app., the saying DAq AlmaAlu Eani Ald~uyuwni (tropical:) The property was inadequate to the debts. (Msb.) And you say, DAq Eanoka Al$~aYo'u [meaning lamo yasaEoka (assumed tropical:) The thing was not allowable to thee]: one says, laA yasaEuniY $aYo'N wayaDiyqa Eanoka, (S, O, * TA, [in the O, erroneously, lA ystgnY,]) i. e. waA^ano yaDiyqa Eanoka (assumed tropical:) [A thing will not be allowable to me conjointly with its being disallowable to thee, waA^ano yaDiyqN meaning maEa Dayoqihi]: balo mataY wasiEaniY $aYo'N wasiEaka [but when a thing is allowable to me, it is allowable to thee]. (S in art. wsE.) And DAq, (aor. yaDiayqu, K, inf. n. DiyqN, TA,) (tropical:) He was or became, niggardly, or avaricious. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.)

2 Dy~qhu * , (Msb, K,) inf. n. taDoyiyqN, (Msb, TA,) He made it strait, or narrow; (Msb, K;) namely, a place [&c.]; (Msb;) as also ↓ ADAqhu, (K,) inf. n. A_iDaAqapN. (TA.) You say, Day~aqotu Ealayohi AlmakaAna, (S,) or Al$~aYo'a, i. e. I straitened, or made narrow, to him [the place, or the thing; or I scanted it, or made it scanty]; contr. of was~aEotuhu Ealayohi. (O.) And Day~aqotu Ealayohi [alone, used elliptically, I straitened him, properly speaking; and also, (assumed tropical:) his circumstances &c.]. (Msb.) And Duy~iqa EalaY fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one was straitened]. (TA.) lituDay~iquwA Ealayohin~a, in the Kur [lxv. 6, (assumed tropical:) In order that ye may straiten them], implies relation to expenses and to the bosom. (TA.) [See 3. Alt~aDoyiyqu bayona $ayoy^ayoni, occurring in the S and K in art. HwS, means The making a coarctation between two things.]

3 DAyqhu *
He straitened him: (MA:) [see also 2: or, properly, he straitened him, being in like manner straitened by him: see 1 in art. zHm: and] (tropical:) he treated him, or behaved towards him, with hardness, or harshness; (O, * K, * TA;) fiY ka*aA [in, or in respect of, such a thing]. (TA.)
4 ADAq * (tropical:) His means of living became strait (Ealayoih maEaA$uhu ↓ DaAqa); (TA;) his property went away; (S, O, Msb, K;) and he became poor. (TA.) -A2- See also 2.
5 taDay~aqa see 1, first sentence.

6 taDaAoyaqa see 1, in three places. tDAyqwA They straitened one another; pushed, or pressed, one against another; or crowded one another; in a place of assembly; syn. zaHama baEoDuhumo baEoDFA: (Msb in art. zHm:) or they became straitened in a place, or (assumed tropical:) in disposition. (S, O.)
10 AstDAqt bidurojapK * [She endeavoured to constrict her vagina by means of a pessary], (O, K, TA,) or biAlA^adowiyapi [by means of medicaments]; (A, TA;) said of a woman. (A, O, K.)

DayoqN * an inf. n. of 1, (S, O, Msb, K,) as also ↓ DiyqN, (S, O, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.: (Msb:) [both, used as simple substs., signify Narrowness, or straitness:] accord. to Fr, [both seem to signify thus; but the latter, properly; and the former, tropically; for he says that] AlD~ayoqu is in that which does not [really] become wide, like the mind (AlS~ador): (O:) or it is maA DaAqa Eanohu Sadoruka [that of which the mind by its being contracted is incapable, or from which the mind shrinks; an explanation not given in the K as on the authority of Fr, and deviating from his words as given in the O; whence it appears that, for maA, we should perhaps read fiymaA]: (K:) but ↓ AlD~iyqu is in that which may be [really] wide, like the house and the garment: (O, K:) and the former [is also used as an epithet, being a contraction of Day~iqN in this case, and as such] has a dual and a plural and a feminine; but the latter has not: (O:) or ↓ both are alike [in signification]: (K:) and ↓ DayoqapN is syn. with DiyqN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ DayaqN, accord. to AA, (O, [the latter there expressly said to be biAlt~aHoriyki,]) or the former and ↓ DiyqN, (K, [said in the TA to
be a mistake for DayaqN, but see what follows,]) Doubt (AA, O, K) in the heart: (K) the first is more common than the second, in this sense; and occurs in the Kur in xvi. last verse and xxvii. 72: (O:) [but] Ibn-Ketheer read, in both of these instances, ↓ Diyq; and this and Dayoq are dial. vars. signifying straitness of mind. (Bd.) -A2- See also Day~iqN, in two places: ― -b2- and DayoqapN, second sentence, in two places.
DiyqN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.
DayaqN * : see DayoqN, latter part.

DayoqapN * : see DayoqN, latter part. ― -b2- Also (S) (tropical:) Poverty; and an evil state or condition; (S, O, K, TA;) and so ↓ DiyqapN: (K, TA:) and the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] (Fr, S, K, TA) of the former (Fr, S, TA) is ↓ DayoqN: (Fr, S, K, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, DiyqN:]) Fr says, when you see ↓ AlD~ayoq to have occurred in the place of AlD~iyq, it is in [one of] two cases; either it is the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of AlD~ayoqapu; or it means the narrow, or strait, thing, DayoqN being a contraction of Day~iqN. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlD~ayoqapu, (O,) or Dayoqapu [without the article], (JK, O, TA,) or ↓ AlD~iyqapu, (K, [app. a mistake, for in the O, in every case, whether as a proper name or not, AlDyqp is written AlD~ayoqapu,]) is the name of A certain mansion of the moon, (JK, O, K, TA,) [not one of the Twentyeight Mansions,] close by Alv~uray~aA [or the Pleiades]: (JK, O, TA:) or, as IKt says, on the authority of Ibn-Ziyád El-Kilábee, sometimes the moon falls short of Ald~abaraAn and alights in AlDyqp, i. e. two small stars, near together, between Alv~uray~aA and Ald~aAbaraAn: (TA:) it is asserted by the Arabs to be an inauspicious place. (O, * TA.) Hence the saying of El-Akhtal,
fahal~aA zajarota AlT~ayora layolapa jiy^otahaA
biDayoqapa bayona Aln~ajomi waAld~abaraAni
[And wherefore didst not thou draw an omen from the flight of birds on the night when thou camest to her, when the moon was in Deykah, between the Pleiades and Ed-Debarán?]: he notifies that the moon, in the night of their coming together, was making its abode [in the neighbourhood of] AldbrAn, which is inauspicious: (O, TA:) or [the latter hemistich, as J relates it, app. on the authority of A 'Obeyd, is thus,]
biDayoqapi bayona Aln~ajomi waAld~abaraAni
from AlD~ayoqapu as syn. with AlD~ayoqu; (S;) and as AA relates the verse, it is [thus] with kesr to the p in bDyqp; the word not being made the [proper] name of a place, but the meaning being bDyqp maA bayona Alnjm wAldbrAn [i. e. in the narrow space between the Pleiades and Ed-Debarán]. (TA.) ― -b4- DayoqapN is also the fem. of DayoqN the contracted form of Day~iqN. (S, O, TA.)
DiyqapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, former half, in two places.

DuwqaY * and DiyqaY are fems. of ↓ A^aDoyaqu; (S, O, K;) the former [as well as the latter] is [originally] of the measure fuEolaY, (TA,) [each being originally DuyoqaY,] the Y being changed in the former into w because quiescent and preceded by dammeh: (S, O, TA:) the former occurs in the saying of a woman to her fellowwife, contending with her for superiority,
maA A^anoti biAlxuwraY walaA AlD~uwqaY HirFA
[Thou art not the better nor the narrower &c.; xuwraY being in like manner fem. of A^axoyaru]. (TA.) Accord. to Kr, the former is pl. of ↓ Day~iqapN; (TA;) and he says the same of DiyqaY also; (TA voce kay~isN;) but ISd says, I know not how this may be, for fuEolaY is not of the measures of pls. except of the kind of pl. which differs not from its sing. otherwise than in the latter's having p [as an affix], like buhomaApN and buhomaY [q. v.]. (TA in the present art.)
DiyaAqN * : see miDoyaAqN.
DaAy^iqN * : see the next paragraph, in four places.

Day~iqN * and ↓ DayoqN, (S, O, K,) the latter a contraction of the former, (S,) the two being like hay~inN and hayonN [&c.], (O,) and ↓ DaAy^iqN, (K,) Narrow, or strait: (S, * O, * K:) or Day~iqN is an epithet used in this sense when permanence [of the attribute] is meant [and so therefore is its contracted form]; and ↓ DaAy^iqN as meaning [being, or becoming, narrow or strait; or] temporarily narrow or strait: (Msb:) the fem. of the first (TA) and of the second (S, O, TA) [as well as of the third] is with p: (S, O, TA:) see also DuwqaY: [the pls. of the first and second, applied to rational beings, is Day~iquwna and Dayoquwna, like may~ituwna and mayotuwna: and] the pl. of ↓ DaAy^iqN is DaAqapF. (TA.) You say $aYo'N Day~iqN (O, Msb) and ↓ DayoqN (O) A narrow, or strait, thing. (O, * Msb.) And SadorN Day~iqN (assumed tropical:) A strait, or contracted, mind; (Msb;) and nafosN Day~iqapN [meaning the same]. (TA.) And bihi Sadoruka ↓ waDaAy^qN, in the Kur [xi. 15], means (assumed tropical:) And thy mind is temporarily strait or contracted thereby. (Msb.) Day~iqN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Niggardly, or avaricious. (KL.) [And Day~iqu Alxuluqi (assumed tropical:) Narrow, or illiberal, in disposition.]
A^aDoyaqu * [More, and most, narrow or strait or contracted]: (S, O, K:) see its fems. DuwqaY and DiyqaY, above. [See also three exs. voce AisotN, in art. sth.]

maDiyqN *
A narrow, or strait, place: (K:) [a pass: a place of narrowness or straitness] of land; and of the vulva; and (assumed tropical:) [a place, or state, of straitness] of life, or of the means of subsistence: (K in art. Azm:) and (tropical:) a narrow, or strait, affair or case: (K, TA:) pl. maDaAyiqu. (TA.)
A^amorN muDay~aqN * (assumed tropical:) [An affair rendered strait]. (TA.)

miDoyaAqN * , (JK, and O on the authority of Ibn- 'Abbád, and TA,) or ↓ DiyaAqN, like kitaAbN [in measure], thus in all the copies of the K, (TA,) [but probably, I think, taken from a mistranscription,] A pessary (durojapN) of rag and perfume, with which a woman endeavours to constrict her vagina (tasotaDiyqu bihaA). (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

4 A^aDoyalati AlA^aroDu * and A^aDaAlat
The land had in it [trees of the species called] DaAl: (Fr, S, O:) or ADAl AlmakaAnu and A^aDoyala the place gave growth to DAl: (AHn, M, K:) or had in it many DAl. (IKtt, TA.)

DaAlN * The wild [species of lote-tree called] sidor [q. v.]: (S, O, K:) or such of the sidor as are watered only by the rain; (M, K:) the sidor of the mountains, which is thinner in its wood than that of the rivers: AHn says, it grows in the plain, or soft, tracts, and in the rugged; and the bow that is made of it, when it is pared, is pared so as to be thick, in order that it may be stronger, because of the lightness of its wood: (M:) n. un. with p. (S, M, O, K.) [See also EuboriY~N, and EumoriY~N.] ― -b2- Also Another species of tree; (M, K;) AHn says, it is a tree of the shrub-kind, found in the borders of El-Yemen, rising to the height of a cubit, in its manner of growth like the cypress, and having a yellow [fruit of the sort called a] baramap, of a very pungent odour, so that its odour comes to you before you reach it: it is not of the sidor thus called. (M.)

DaAlapN * n. un. of DaAlN [q. v.]. (S, M, O, K.) ― -b2- Also Arrows, (M, O, TA,) and bows, (TA,) made of the [species of lote-tree called] DaAl: (M, TA:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) or arrows, (IB, K,) because they are made thereof: (IB:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (O,) all kinds of weapons. (O, K.) One says, raA^ayotuhu yaromiY biAlD~aAlapi [I saw him shooting arrows]. (TA.) And xaraja wafiY yadihi DaAlapN i. e. [He went forth having in his hand] a bow. (TA.) And A_in~ahu lakaAmilu AlD~aAlapi Verily he is complete in respect of weapons. (O.) And xaraja fulaAnN biDaAlatihi Such a one went forth with his weapons. (O.)

1 DaAmahu * , (S, Msb,) aor. yaDiymuhu, (S,) inf. n. DayomN, (S, * Msb,) [as also DaAmahu, aor. yaDuwmuhu, inf. n. DawoN, (see art. Dwm,)] He wronged him; treated him wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: (S:) he harmed, injured, hurt, or damaged, him: (Msb:) and ↓ AstDAmhu signifies the same. (S.) And DaAmahu Haq~ahu, (M, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (M,) He defrauded him of his right, or due, partially or wholly; (M, K;) as also ↓ AstDAmhu. (K.) ― -b2-
And Dumotu I was wronged, &c.: of which there are three dial. vars.; one says of a man Diyma; and Duyoma, with [the pronunciation termed] A_i$omaAm; and Duwma; like as we have said respecting biyEa. (S.) One says, maA Dimotu A^aHadF wamaA Dumotu [I have not wronged any one, and I have not been wronged]; i. e. no one has wronged me. (TA.) It is said in a trad., as some relate it, laA tuDaAmuwna fiY ruw^oyatihi [or ↓ tuDaAm~uwna or ↓ taDaAm~uwna Ye will not be wronged in the seeing Him]. (M. [For other readings and explanations of this trad., see 3 in art. Dr.])
3 DaAoyama and 6: see the preceding paragraph.
10 A_isotaDoyama see 1, in two places.

DayomN *
Wrong; i. e. wrongdoing; or wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, treatment: (S, K:) an inf. n. which is pluralized; its pl. being DuyuwmN. (M, K.)
DiymN * The side of a mountain, (S, M, K,) and of an [eminence such as is termed] A^akamap. (M.)

DaAy^imN *
Wronging, or a wrongdoer: pl. DaAmapN: the latter occurring in the prov., taA^otiY bika AlD~aAmapu Eir~iysa AlA^asadi [The wrongdoers bring thee, or cause thee to come, to the covert of the lion]; meaning, the wrong of the wrongdoers requires thee to cast thyself into destruction: applied in offering an excuse for venturing upon that which is perilous: or, as some relate it, AlD~aAm~apu, from AlD~am~u; meaning “ want, or the object of want, that brings thee and causes thee to have recourse [to a thing]. ” (Meyd.)

maDiymN *
Wronged; treated wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: as also ↓ musotaDaAmN. (S, K, * TA.)
musotaDaAmN * : see what next precedes.
